TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minster for National Development and Energy. Is it true that a joint Federal-State study three years ago showed that more than half of the land used in Australia for cropping and grazing purposes needed treatment against degradation? Was it then estimated that at 1975 prices the cost of this work would be $675m or, in current prices, well over $1,000m? Is it true that the value of fixed investments under threat, as identified by that study, is of the order of $12,000m? What is the current Government program in relation to soil conservation? Is it a fact that the Government has withdrawn all funding from soil conservation programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking the last part of the question first, the answer is no. The Government was to have allocated some $3m to soil conservation but in the in globo picture of a Budget it was decided that the money should be spent by the States on State conservation; so the States themselves will pursue it. The fact is that the protection and ownership of land is essentially within the States' sovereignty and the major soil conservation work has always been regarded as a State matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that a study was done some years ago. As to whether the details set out by Senator Button are as he says I am unable to recall from memory. It is true that the preservation of the topsoil of land against erosion is one of the major responsibilities that we have in respect of our heritage. It is abundantly true that the primary responsibility for the preservation of land, and one which should be enforced by the States, rests with the owner of the land. In fact what is necessary for good conservation lies in good farming practices and good animal husbandry. It is true that Crown land can contribute to degradation and that must, of course, be the responsibility of the Government that is responsible for that Crown land. I accept the significance of soil conservation. That has been accepted by the States over the years. Basic State programs for soil conservation do exist. Very good tax concessions are in existence, and they have been for years, as incentives to individual farmers to undertake soil conservation. I suggest that the responsibility of the individual should be emphasised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister a supplementary question. I just want to seek clarification of that part of the Minister's answer relating to the $3m. Subsequently the Minister indicated that in his view it was a State responsibility, but I am not clear whether that $3m has been made available to the States. Is there no other aspect of Commonwealth involvement in soil conservation programs?

—Let me say that my clear knowledge is that the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions recommended that soil conservation should be wholly a State matter since it was predominantly so. My belief is, but it would be subject to checking in the precise and final details, that an absorption process was adopted. I will need to check that. If what I say now is different from what the Budget does, I will inform Senator Button, but my understanding is that an absorption of the order of $3m was taken into account. That does not mean that the Government abdicates its responsibilities. It simply means, as in many things, that it would have made provision for the States to carry on with the programs that were envisaged.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Has the Minister noted a statement by Mr Carter, the General Manager of the Aluminium Division of Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd, at a recent seminar in which Mr Carter cautioned that unreasonable demands on industry for the financing of infrastructure would inhibit the future development of New South Wales resources? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether Mr Carter was referring to any Commonwealth Government demands for such infrastructure which, as Mr Carter put it, service social objectives and are only indirectly associated with the project?

—I do not believe that I saw the actual report. But the demands in Australia for infrastructure for the very many national development enterprises that are foreshadowed will, of course, exceed the capacity of the nation as a whole to fulfil. The pressure upon borrowing programs, be they public borrowing programs or borrowing programs of enterprise, will be such that the competition for money, men and materials will not allow all the infrastructure to be done. Of course, if the competition were intense it would heat the economy and put up inflation and interest rates. The Commonwealth has an infrastructure program in relation to the States. The States themselves before Loan Council meetings put up their priorities and there are discussions at Loan Council upon the priorities of infrastructure. They mainly concern power stations. They concern such matters as power stations and pipelines. In order to keep the public borrowing down, in order to keep the Commonwealth and the States from competing and overheating industry, there is a need for commerce and industry to undertake a considerable amount of infrastructure. I would need to know in detail about the particular infrastructure to be able to comment at all but, in general, there will be competition. Those who read this morning the editorial in the Australian Financial Review will have noted that that journal commented that there was a very significant expansion of investment development and resources development in Australia and, therefore, a pressure upon resources. That will reflect upon the infrastructure demands.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that environmental groups are opposing the inclusion of Kakadu National Park in the World Heritage List? Since the World Heritage Commission is to meet in Australia next week, what action does the Government intend to take to ensure that the Park is included in the World Heritage List?

—The last information I had was that Kakadu National Park is to be included in the World Heritage List and that the first steps have been taken to bring this about. I understand that some environmental groups are opposed to the inclusion on the ground that there may be uranium mining within the Park. I do not believe that that is an adequate reason for opposing the inclusion of the Park. Kakadu was nominated by the Australian Government for inclusion in the World Heritage List. It is up to the World Heritage Committee to decide whether the area should be listed. It is not up to anyone else. I understand, however, that the technical review undertaken for the World Heritage Committee by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources included consultation with the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service before concluding: 'Kakadu National Park meets both cultural and natural criteria and the nomination should be approved as submitted'. In view of that endorsement, I do not believe that it is appropriate to seek to set that aside.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Government give an assurance that uranium will never be mined in Kakadu National Park if it is placed in the World Heritage List?
—I do not believe that I am able to give such an assurance. I will transmit that question to the Minister.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORT EXAMINERS OF AIRMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to an article in today's Australian in which Qantas Airways Ltd pilots are reported as saying that they may refuse to fly into Wellington, New Zealand, until they receive assurances that bureaucrats in the cockpit will not interfere with the captain's authority during flights. The article explained how on a Brisbane to Wellington flight recently a Department of Transport senior examiner of airmen forced a Qantas captain to divert to Sydney because of a minor hydraulic pump fault. The captain protested that it was an allowable deficiency which would not have affected the safety of the flight. However, it was stated, the captain was threatened with loss of licence if he did not do what the bureaucrat told him. I ask: Is the Minister able to report to the Senate on whether that article is factual? If so, what disciplinary action was taken against that officer? How on earth can a bureaucrat who flies a simulator for a few hours a year as well as spending a few hours flying Jumbo aircraft, at great expense to the Australian taxpayer, be allowed to tell the captain of an aircraft who flies hundreds of hours a year how he will control the aircraft? Finally, will the Minister ask the Minister for Transport to take a fresh look at the matter of how much money should be spent on training examiners of airmen because surely this example points to the fact that the examiners should spend less time spending taxpayers' money flying and more time studying handling procedures before they again interfere with a flight, at great cost to Qantas, and perhaps cause a partial strike, again at great cost to that carrier?

—I am afraid that I have not seen the article in the Australian to which Senator Townley referred, and I do not have any information from the Minister in connection with it. The honourable senator raised a number of very detailed questions and matters of very great concern not only to the flying public but also to the Australian Government. I would need to refer all the questions he has asked to the Minister. I undertake to bring down an early reply for him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Does he recall a statment he made in this chamber on 26 August 1980-I quote from Hansard-which states:

QUESTION.PARA: The Rundle shale oil project is a classic example of the effectiveness of the Government's import parity pricing policy.

In the light of his statement yesterday in this place in reply to a question from Senator Jones, does he now believe that the Government's policy on import parity pricing is ineffective and needs to be reviewed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Sibraa would reflect, the fact is that, if one wants to put in position synthetic crude projects so that Australia is ready when oil production falls off in the world and is not available, one needs to inject the stimuli that would make the synthetic crude cost effective with oil. My comment then was very clear. It was that the Rundle partners had said that the primary reason that they had set about the oil shale project was that our import parity pricing, as projected, would make it cost effective with synthetic crudes. That was a correct statement then; it remained a correct statement; and it was the reflection of the partners.

ANSWER.PARA: Happily, in the period that has followed, the members of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries have been persuaded to stabilise reasonably the price of oil in the world so that, contrary to the predictions of the Australian Labor Party and Mr Keating in particular, the price of oil in real terms fell in the last year. As a result of that, two things are happening. There are those who feel that, for the time being, some kind of alteration should be made of lead time in the production of synthetic crudes. That is a matter of judgment on their part. There are those who say that, since the extrapolation of the price of OPEC is not as steep as before, the cost effectiveness may not at this time be real. Lest anyone should misunderstand this, let me make it perfectly clear. The world is using oil at twice the rate it is finding it. There is an inevitability that the world will run short of oil in the decades ahead. Equally, despite the knockers and Jeremiahs, there will be an essential need to put in place the synthetic crudes, be they from shale or coal or at least in the early stages to put in place the technology and pilot plants so that, when we need to replace the oil, we can do so.

Happily, if we go on finding more oil in Australia and if we can keep the level of 67 per cent or 70 per cent self-sufficiency extended for some years-well, we may do that now for some years ahead-we push the need for synthetic crudes further into the next decade. That ought to be good news and not news for the knockers. The answer therefore is that what was said in August was true. The world pricing of oil is the stimulus for synthetics. Quite apart from my saying so, the International Energy Agency, with the voice of 21 nations, has said that the imperative need for an energy policy to do all the things that are necessary, including encouraging synthetic crudes, is to cost oil at its world price. That is precisely what I said in August last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, concerns the segment on the television program 60 Minutes on the weekend about so-called 'prison ships' off the Australian coast being delayed by selective union bans on flags-of-convenience registered ships and the filming of the bulk coal carrier Mineral Transporter near the end of that program, which implied that seaworthiness and extensive corrosion are the reason for the bans.
