ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis asked a number of very detailed questions. I do have some information in respect of the matter he raised but I am unable to help him with some of the particulars. It is true that the Mineral Transporter did collide with another vessel at the anchorage off Port Kembla on 10 July this year. Apparently, marine surveyors of the Department of Transport did examine the vessel for structural damage and its general condition at that stage. Since then it has been delayed in Sydney due to industrial action to force the ship owner to carry out repairs in Australia. However, agreement has now been reached for major repairs to be made overseas. Temporary repairs are being carried out in Sydney to enable the vessel to sail. The routine inspection of the Mineral Transporter discovered some 70 defects, mainly in lifesaving and fire appliances. Many were due to rust and other kinds of deterioration. Those defects will be required to be fixed before the vessel leaves Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In the meantime, proceedings were instituted against the master for faulty lifesaving and fire appliances. I understand that he was fined $2,000. The vessel will be given a short term certificate in relation to the condition of its hull, et cetera, by the classification society with which it is classed to enable it to get to a port where a full overhaul can be undertaken. As to the questions of cost in relation to lost exports in respect of this or any other matter about which Senator Lewis seeks information, I will endeavour to obtain that information from the Minister for Transport, but reference may need to be made to another department. In relation to several of the other points which the honourable senator made in the question, I will refer those to the appropriate Ministers also.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the report of the Torres Strait Advisory Council which was submitted to the Premier of Queensland. Has the Minister received a copy of that report? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the outcomes of the survey reported upon by the Advisory Council which were that 95 per cent of Islanders who completed the questionnaires wanted freehold tenure of land and that 99 per cent of those who voted at public meetings wanted control by Islanders of their own affairs? Since the number of Islanders who completed the questionnaires was 1,102 out of a total population of 2,372, over the age of 15 years, will the Minister not agree that this survey represents a democratic expression on the part of the peoples of the Islands for possession of their own lands and control of their own affairs?

—I am aware of the survey which was conducted by the Torres Strait communities within their own area. I believe the figures which were set out by Senator Macklin do accurately represent the results of that survey. I would have to make sure that the figures are exactly right, but I believe he has set out the sentiment that was expressed and the overwhelming support on two questions which he outlined. The survey has been a valuable input from the Aboriginal people. It is needed at this time to know what people in the Torres Strait are thinking. I believe the results of the survey have been made available not only to me but also to the Government of Queensland and to other interested people. I hope that the findings will be noted and taken into account in any contemplated resolution of the present problems.

—I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether the Federal Government has formed an interdepartmental committee chaired by the head of his Department for the purpose of drawing up a suggested code of practice to govern relationships between exploration companies and Aboriginal communities. I further ask the Minister: Inasmuch as the granting of title of on-shore mining tenements in the States is the exclusive responsibility of State governments, have talks taken place between the Commonwealth and State governments on this matter? Have talks on this matter taken place between the Commonwealth and mining companies? Inasmuch as the companies are required to seek such titles from the State governments, what is their attitude?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether Senator Crichton-Browne's question has been prompted by some recent newspaper articles in which the Minister in Western Australia has made some comments. I thought when I read that article that he was probably referring to moves which the Commonwealth Government initiated following events at Noonkanbah. The Commonwealth Government wrote to the Premiers of all States in September last year seeking their co-operation in consultations between governments and industry groups 'on the question of mining and petroleum exploration on land involving Aboriginal interests'. To that extent there has been some Commonwealth action. Since then there have been discussions with mining and petroleum industry organisations on what might be achieved. I have also sought the views of the National Aboriginal Conference for any opinions it might have on the same matter. Officers of the Government are considering whether it is possible to prepare a document for discussion with all interests involved. Those interests, of course, would include State government interests.

ANSWER.PARA: I am more heartened by the statement issued by Mr Jones on 30 September in which he said that he and his colleague, the Minister for Community Welfare, applauded the book of guidelines which has been issued by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association. The Minister said that that book was practical and realistic in its approach to the issue and was based on the least used law of all, the law of common sense. I thought that was a very helpful statement. I am sure that officers will be paying a great deal of attention to the document issued by APEA and to any similar document on policy issued by the Australian Mining Industry Council in its deliberations. Having said all that, I am trying to make the point that the kind of co-operative help which might have been very effective at the time of Noonkanbah is what we are seeking to bring about. Anything we produce would be a basis for discussion and there is no attempt to impose upon anyone, to denigrate or to play down the proper constitutional responsibilities of any part of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Is it a fact that import parity pricing for crude oil was introduced into Australian Government revenue raising at a time when sales tax was confined to a few and major items of family expenditure? Does the Government intend to adhere to import parity pricing if its proposed across the board sales tax takes effect on its passage through Parliament? What calculation has the Government made of the cumulative effect on the rate of inflation that the imposition of both of these indirect taxes might be expected to have?

—Import parity pricing was introduced some three or four years ago when sales taxes were at different rates. Some sales taxes were higher than they will be under these Bills. Some sales taxes were lower. A great deal has been made of these sales taxes. The fact is that there will be an increase in indirect tax this year of 3.7 per cent compared with an increase of 8 per cent in sales tax in the last Hayden Budget of the Whitlam Government. It ought to be perfectly clear, therefore, that the kind of government that puts up indirect tax heavily is the Labor Government and not this Government. The Government proposes to continue with import parity pricing. It has worked. Import parity pricing has been acknowledged by other governments as being correct. It has been acknowledged by the International Energy Agency as doing the four things necessary for an energy policy in Australia. It conserves, and there is a significant conservation of energy. It converts away from oil to other fuels, and that is happening. It encourages exploration. Indeed, the IEA has said that there could hardly be a better set of incentives for exploration than that which exists in Australia at the moment. It also encourages the introduction of synthetics. Why would one move away from a policy that is so eminently successful? Indeed, why would one wish to challenge this Government on sales tax when the Australian Labor Party put up indirect tax by 8 per cent and this Government has put it up by only 3.7 per cent?

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. The Minister has misunderstood entirely my question, which at no stage put forward the proposition that import parity pricing for new oil should be abandoned. My question related to the cumulative impact of both indirect taxes on the rate of inflation. I take it from the Minister's inability to answer that in fact the Government has not worked out the figures on that cumulative impact.

—Had Senator Tate addressed himself to the answer I gave to the previous question he would have been reminded that in fact the real price of oil, because there has been no move up in the import parity price of oil over this year whilst the cost of living otherwise has risen, has meant that there has been a fall and that the combination of the two has not had the effect he considers. I remind Senator Tate that, contrary to the Labor Party's melodramatic pronouncements before the last Federal elections that all disaster was going to happen to such prices, nothing of the sort has occurred. Bearing in mind that that was one of the major issues on which the Labor Party sought the endorsement of the people, who were sensible enough to reject it, the stabilisation of import parity pricing has meant a reduction in the real price of oil in Australia.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health confirm that the Commonwealth has withdrawn support for the country's only independent review of drug therapy, the Australian Prescriber. If this is true, what guarantees can the Government give that the medical and pharmaceutical professions will continue to have access to unbiased and comprehensive reports on drug therapy, adverse drug reactions and new drugs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the bulk of commentaries printed in the Australian Prescriber are provided by specialists in private, hospital or academic medical practice or pharmacalogical practice, not by the Department of Health, and that in reviewing the functions of my colleague's Department it was decided that the information that had been provided in the Australian Prescriber until now was properly the responsibility of professional or academic publications. In view of the small contribution rate of my colleague's Department to this publication, along with the Government's policy to reduce expenditure and also to work within staff ceiling requirements, the decision was taken to cease publication of the Australian Prescriber. I am advised that that decision will take effect from May 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Medical Association has approached the Minister for Health, offering to conduct a feasibility study into providing the information contained in the Australian Prescriber in the Medical Journal of Australia. The Minister intends to have this offer evaluated in order to ascertain what assistance will be needed for the dissemination of these commentaries in another publication. The offer from the AMA does not, of course, preclude offers from any other professional organisation to provide a similar service or publication as the Australian Prescriber.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FAMILY LAW: CUSTODY AND PROPERTY MATTERS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Is it the case that problems have continued to arise from time to time in the administration of family law arising out of the limited jurisdiction of the Commonwealth, due to the Constitution, in relation to certain property and custody matters? Is it the case that the Victorian and New South Wales governments have on at least five separate occasions in the last three or four years offered to refer to the Commonwealth under section 51 (xxxvii) of the Constitution effectively the full range of powers needed if the Family Court is to have complete jurisdiction in all family law matters of day to day practical significance but that so far, for unexplained reasons, the Commonwealth has refused to accept those offers?

QUESTION.PARA: Is it also the case that the Tasmanian Government has regularly indicated its support for the New South Wales and Victorian governments' initiatives and that similar support has been indicated by the South Australian Government, at least under the Labor administration but not so enthusiastically under the present lot, and that only Western Australia and Queensland have continued to refuse further family law powers to the Commonwealth? Would it not have been possible for the jurisdiction of the Family Court to have been safely extended well beyond the new extensions that were mapped out in the Bill introduced by the Attorney-General yesterday if the Commonwealth had accepted these referrals from the States I have mentioned which have offered them? Why has the Commonwealth not accepted these referrals and legislated accordingly?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans's question contains a mixture of fact and fiction. Many questions have been asked in the Senate on this subject and I have given a number of answers to them over a period. I have made it clear over and over again that the Commonwealth was most desirous of obtaining a reference of power in this area, that four States-Victoria, New South Wales, Tasmania and South Australia-were considering making that offer and that the only States that had stood out were Queensland and Western Australia. I have been negotiating, to the extent that the Commonwealth has any say in the matter at all, with those States to obtain this reference. But the reference of power has to be made in the terms of an agreement which the States want to enter into with the Commonwealth. There has not yet been a final determination of that agreement. I do not want to go into details of disputes or differences between States. There have been differences between Victoria and New South Wales as to the terms of the agreement.
—Why does there have to be agreement between those two States before you can proceed?
—Because that is the way the thing has proceeded.
—You can do it at any time, and you know it.
—Is the honourable senator saying that the Commonwealth should take a reference from New South Wales?
—Yes.
—That is a different proposition. It may be one that we will look at at some stage.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to the outstanding Defence statement made by the Minister for Defence in the House of Representatives yesterday with reference to the intention to build two FFG-type ships at the Williamstown Naval Dockyard subject to satisfactory resolution of a number of problems affecting productivity there. This is a delightful euphemism which, of course, we would expect from this Minister. Can the Minister give the House an assurance that unless all doubts about Williamstown Naval Dockyard being able to honour its contracts are removed, by the unions entering into a legally binding undertaking not to strike, indulge in bans or demarcation disputes, the Government will place the two FFG follow-on destroyer contracts with other Australian yards? In this regard, will the Minister include North Queensland Engineers and Agents, the builders of the Fremantle class ships, with other Australian yards?
—Senator MacGibbon's question asks for an assurance from the Minister for Defence. I will refer that question to the Minister and ask him to provide an early answer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer her to the debate on the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) in the Senate last night, at which time I raised the issue of a letter from the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Perth to a Mr Pidcock stating that magazines and newspapers purchased by subscription were to be subjected to sales tax which would be payable at the post office each time a magazine was received. In response, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: The advice given to him was not correct. Individual importation of books and magazines may be made free of tax under item 145 of the First Schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act provided, firstly, that the value for duty does not exceed . . .

I ask the Minister: As there is a lot of consternation and confusion in the community with regard to the importation and the subscription to various magazines, journals and text books what is the true situation with regard to all of those three items on both the local and the imported market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I recall Senator Coleman's raising this matter in the debate last night. I did undertake to get some information for her urgently. I am able to advise that the Commissioner of Taxation is taking urgent action to correct the advice that was given to Mr Pidcock in the letter dated 9 October to which Senator Coleman referred last night. I also gave the honourable senator last night advice that I received from the officers who were present in the chamber. I will now repeat that advice, which will clarify the matter that the honourable senator has raised. She quoted advice, received by a taxpayer from the Australian Taxation Office in Perth, which stated that sales tax would be payable at the Post Office each time one received a magazine. There are a number of points which I must clarify for the honourable senator and anyone else who is interested in the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The advice that was given by the Australian Taxation Office in Perth, concerning the application, from 1 January 1982, of the proposed sales tax on magazines, books and so on is unfortunately not correct as far as individual magazines imported by Australian subscribers are concerned. Goods, including magazines and books, sent from overseas to Australians will, basically, be subject under the proposed measures to a tax of 2.5 per cent, but may qualify for an overriding exemption from sales tax that is contained in item 145 of the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. That exemption is a long-standing one and applies to imported goods entering Australia which are classified for customs purposes as being of insubstantial value. 'Insubstantial value', for customs purposes, means that the value for duty of the goods does not exceed $250 or, alternatively, that the tax and duty payable do not exceed $5. Accordingly, in the ordinary case of a person who makes an individual subscription to an overseas magazine that is received through the mail from the overseas publisher, no sales tax will be payable. As I said last night, the information given to Senator Coleman's constituent is not correct and the Commissioner will be taking urgent action to correct it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Leader of the Government as Minister representing the Minister for Education, refers to the Government's estimates of revenue from fee collection. I ask: Is it a fact that in early July the Government estimated that in 1982, $8m would be collected from fees for further degree students and certain post-graduate students? In light of the statement in the 1981-82 Federal Budget Papers that the revenue for 1982 is expected to be $4m, will the Minister explain whether the Government has changed its basis for estimating the amount of fees that will be collected and, if not, give the explanation for this apparent change in the estimate?

—The simple answer is that the earlier estimate was for a full financial year. The Budget statement is for that part of the financial year, the second half, that can be accommodated in the Budget. A great deal of controversy has arisen in regard to the number of students involved. A great deal of the discussion in this place has indicated that there would be a wide impact upon students. Recently I received from the President of the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations an estimate that, of approximately 21,500 students who might be expected to enrol for second qualifications next year, some 17,631 would be exempt from paying fees. In other words, as I said some months ago in this place, a very large number would be exempt. On those figures supplied by FAUSA some 3,800, out of 21,500, would be obliged to pay fees. FAUSA even states that that figure may include an over-estimate of 10 per cent to 20 per cent. FAUSA has provided its analysis of the figure and I have asked the Department of Education to comment on it. I make the point, as I have previously, that a significant number of students will not be affected by the fee requirement. The strict answer to Senator Martin is that the first amount, $8m, was in respect of a full year and that the second, $4m, was in respect of the half year dealt with in the Budget.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs: Who are the members of the task force investigating the future of the Community Youth Support Scheme beyond 28 February 1981? Is there any community representation on the task force? Is it correct that the members of the task force are all officials of the Minister's Department? Will the Minister consider broadening the membership of the task force to include representatives of the community, the Department of Education and, at a State level, tertiary and further education and youth and community services agencies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have information that would advise me of the names of the people who are on the task force. But I have in front of me the note that was released on 15 October by the Minister in which he said that the task force will be headed by Mr Bob Turnbull, the recently retired New South Wales regional director of the Department, and will include officers from the Office of Youth Affairs in the Commonwealth Employment Service. The Minister also stated that letters would be sent out to community interests throughout Australia inviting them to make written submissions to the task force. I think I would need to find out from the Minister what appointments have been made. Perhaps he could also inform me whether some of the suggestions that were made in the question in respect of the membership of the task force could be adopted, if it is not already fully appointed. In any case, I undertake to draw the question asked by Senator Siddons to the attention of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs who I feel sure will be interested in the suggestions that have been made in it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Following last week's High Court decision in the Nancy Law case is the Department of Veterans' Affairs expediting the processing of claims that have been held pending the High Court's judgment? If such processing is proceeding, is this occurring at all levels, namely, with claims held by the Department of Veterans' Affairs and with appeals to the Repatriation Commission and the Repatriation Review Tribunal? Can the Minister advise how many claims are pending at each level and how long it will be before the backlog is cleared at each of those levels?

—I understand that overall about 800 appeals have been deferred pending the outcome of the decision in the High Court in the matter of Mrs Law. Those are now being processed in due course through the various levels of appeal within the Department of Veterans' Affairs and, of course, the Repatriation Review Tribunal. I would need to obtain some detailed information for Senator Colston in respect of the details of the number of cases at each level. That could perhaps take a little time. As to the clearance of the total number of cases that are outstanding, as I have indicated, it is a matter for due process. We are taking steps to ensure that, given the circumstances, they are handled as quickly as possible.

—I wish to address a question to Senator Chaney. However, as he is not in the chamber at present, perhaps the Leader of the Government in the Senate might answer my question. I refer to a recent statement that increased tax concessions for manufacturing industries may be introduced to compensate for tariff cuts. Is this statement notice to the manufacturing sector that further tariff reductions are imminent? Is it still the Government's resolve to maintain a viable manufacturing sector in Australia? Is this statement the most appropriate means of achieving viability? Does the Minister believe that the leaders of manufacturing companies are satisfied by this statement? Can the Minister explain how continuing loss of market share or loss of market itself can be offset by tax concessions? Alternatively, can the Minister provide the formula to achieve this objective?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, let me say that it is the Government's objective to maintain and, indeed, to expand a viable manufacturing industry in Australia. There has been a growth of resource development industries. Those industries plus the service industries will demand more manufacturing industries operating at a higher level of technology to service them. Equally, the best possible stimulus for manufacturing in Australia is so to dispose our inflation-our general costs-by contrast with our trading partners, particularly our Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development partners, that we have a trading advantage. I remind Senator Watson that some seven years ago we had been virtually traded out of world trade because of soaring interest rates. The best incentive that can be given to manufacturing is the pressure down on inflation and interest rates in Australia, and that is the thrust of the Budget itself.

ANSWER.PARA: As to any tariff reductions, the honourable senator is aware that there is a tariff review. The Government has made no decisions at all. The Government has indicated quite clearly that any tariff reductions that might occur in Australia would be in a very gradual condition. Australia has brought about tariff reduction over the years and has nothing to be ashamed of by comparison with many of our trading partners.

As to the tax incentives, I am not aware of where the Government would rate them in terms of their application by contrast, or in comparison, or in parallel with tariff reductions. I suggest to the honourable senator that first of all we direct all our attention to an economy whose cost efficiency by way of inflation is such that it allows us to trade viably. It is one of the exciting things in this country that quite a number of our industries are now so cost competitive that they are going off-shore and they are competing favourably in those countries. That is a very healthy sign indeed. As to the remainder of the question, I suggest we bide our time until we come forward with the review of tariffs and whatever incentives should go with them. But I stress that it is our aim that we should have in Australia a viable and growing manufacturing industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on the question asked by Senator Watson I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce to the report in the Press, to which Senator Watson referred, in which the Treasurer is reported to favour the lowering of protection to Australian industry in order to reduce inflation. Is this not a rather simplistic and short-sighted approach for the Treasurer to be taking, especially in view of the likely impact of such a change of policy on the manufacturing industry work force? Is the Minister aware that if motor vehicle industry quotas are abolished and tariffs reduced, Australia would be flooded with Japanese imports and the Australian car manufacturing industry could be wiped out? Is the Minister also aware of a study by the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research which shows that if tariff levels were reduced by 7 1/2 per cent and import quotas doubled to 20 per cent, over 51,000 jobs throughout the economy would be lost in just the first three years of such a policy change? I should point out that this study also indicates that lowering of taraffs would have only a minimal effect on the inflation rate and that any possible benefits would be swamped by the downturn in manufacturing industry. Can the Minister indicate when the Government is likely to reach a decision on future protection levels for the motor vehicle industry, or is the Government unable to do so because of conflict within the coalition parties over this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very lengthy question on a very complicated subject and I do not propose to canvass all the matters which were raised by the honourable senator. I can, however, assure him that the timing of any decision on the car industry is not being dictated by inter-party conflict which I think was the final point he made in that very long question. I have not seen the remarks that were attributed to the Treasurer in some report and which apparently was referred to in an earlier question. The honourable senator's description of them as simplistic and short-sighted leads me to think that they were either misreported or misunderstood by the honourable senator. The Government has a record of a very careful approach to tariff matters. The Government indicated in its response to the Crawford report-the report of the Study Group on Structural Adjustment-the general approach which it would adopt.

ANSWER.PARA: On prior occasions I have assured the honourable senator that when the Government is examining matters of protection obviously one of the considerations which is uppermost in the Government's mind and which is given very careful consideration is the question of employment. It is a matter which is of concern to the Government, as it is to all Australians and, I think, all members of the Senate. I will ensure that the reports and so on referred to by the honourable senator in his question are drawn to the attention of the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I can assure him that the area about which he is concerned-namely, the motor industry-will be given the most careful attention by the Government. I am not in a position to predict when decisions will be made. I will ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether he is able to give some indication. I stress that no decision will be made by the Government until, after examination of all the facts and considerations, it is quite clear in its mind that it knows what the right decision is.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to the optimistic report of Mr Ken Richards, the Chairman of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, as reported in the Adelaide Advertiser of 13 October, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Oil reserves will grow at an average rate of 200m barrels a year for the rest of this century.

Has the Department of National Development and Energy upgraded its estimates of Australian oil and gas reserves? In particular, has the Department upgraded its estimates in relation to the Cooper Basin in South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —To answer that question one must first of all keep in mind that two years ago the generally accepted thesis regarding our oil reserves, based on Bass Strait as our main supplier, plus Barrow Island and Moonie, was that, whereas we were 67 per cent self-sufficient then, we would drop to 50 per cent self-sufficiency by 1985, to 40 per cent by 1990 and to 10 per cent or 20 per cent by the turn of the century. That would have been a very gloomy situation. That estimate was supported by the Bureau of Mineral Resources and other objective observers. The impact of our import parity pricing policy, particularly for new oil, has been such that what were sub-economic pools before have been developed and brought into being and there has been an upgrading of our reserves, so much so that the last forecast put out by my Department some months ago showed a more healthy response. Indeed, it showed that the production of synthetics would be slid down further in lead time.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been an upgrading. I do not want to be too optimistic because the fact is that, whatever supplies we have, we will run out of oil in decades ahead, whether it be two, three, four or five decades. The fact is that nobody believes that we will strike a bonanza in Australia. The BMR and others believe that we will find a number of small and modest deposits that will help us. Our aim is to find as many as we can as quickly as we can. Exploration has speeded up very rapidly in that regard. There is great interest in the Cooper Basin at this moment. Although there are encouraging signs at the Strzlecki well and other wells, at the moment there is not a proven oil field. The fact that the Cooper Basin pipeline to Whyalla will be bringing down something like 35,000 barrels of liquid a day by January 1983 does add to our forecast. The answer is yes. We have upgraded the situation. We hope to be even more optimistic for the future. But, against that, there should be no complacency in Australia because inevitably we will need substitutes for indigenous oil in the decades ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is she aware of a study by Mr Peter Davies for the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System which shows that 87.3 per cent of nominee shares in Peko-Wallsend Ltd and 74 per cent of nominee shares in Western Mining Corporation Holdings Ltd were held on behalf of foreign residents? Did the Treasurer cite this study in a reply to a question on notice in the other place last week? Does this mean that this brings Australian equity in the Ranger uranium project to 68.54 per cent, not 75 per cent, and 40.1 per cent, not 51 per cent in the Roxby Downs project? Can the Minister explain how, when the Treasurer has admitted that the Government has the power to ascertain beneficial ownership of nominee shareholdings, this situation could arise? Has the Treasurer made such investigations? Will the Foreign Investment Review Board be instructed to remedy the situation, restore Australian equity, and examine other proposals to ascertain whether Australian equity is similarly overstated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of detailed questions were raised by Senator Childs. I suggest that they be placed on notice and I will refer them to the Treasurer for his response and for the provision of whatever information is available. I am not aware of some of the matters as stated, but, if they are factual and if they are able to have a response from the Treasurer, I will see that a response is expedited.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and ask whether he has noted a Press report indicating that ICI Australia Ltd has shelved a $500m petrochemical project in Victoria because of high local costs and the rise in the value of the Australian dollar? Is the Minister aware that another prime reason for this decision involved the doubts associated with the capacity of that company to deliver its product on the international market due to the general industrial disruption affecting the Australian waterfront? As my attention has been drawn to other companies in Australia which are in a similar position and which are contemplating withdrawing from Australia-two of them are considering establishing their industries in South Africa and Indonesia because of the assurance that their products can be delivered on the world market on time-I ask whether the Government is proposing to do anything to retain in Australia these industries which are so important to employment opportunities in this country? Also, does the Government propose to do anything in the interest of restoring our credibility as a reliable international trading partner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clearly the wish of the present Government to establish an environment in which investment in business is attractive to those with capital. I would have thought that one of the signal successes of the Government over the last year or two would have to be regarded from all parts of this chamber as the high level of investment, not merely in the mining industry, where perhaps greatly increased investment was expected, but also in manufacturing industry. In fact, there is a very healthy level of investment in this country at the moment, and that healthy level, on the last figures I saw, is continuing. It is, of course, a matter of concern to the Government when projects do not go ahead. A number of reasons have been put forward with respect to the project mentioned by the honourable senator in his question. It goes without saying, I would have thought, that if one has a record of industrial strife of the sort which we have had on the waterfront in Australia in recent times, if one has a consistent push for shorter working hours and so on, it is likely that some projects will become marginal and will not warrant investment in them. I am not able to give the precise reason for the ICI decision not to proceed, but I have little doubt that it is associated with many of the factors which were mentioned in the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: I will refer the question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch, who has within the last day or so mentioned to me his concern about the variety of reasons which do inhibit investment in these projects and which indicate, as I said before, that notwithstanding the very healthy state of investment in this country, there are some problems. The Opposition ought to try to get its act together. Mr Keating made a speech the other day in which he stressed the very healthy state of investment in this country, particularly in the mining industry. He referred to the existence of the so-called boom which honourable senators opposite seem so keen to deny. I would like to see some acknowledgement on the other side of the chamber and on the other side of politics of the factors which Labor can influence in trying to ensure that we maintain a healthy economy in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier Senator Button asked me a question about soil conservation. In the course of my reply I said my understanding was that an amount of $3m of Commonwealth funds was absorbed so that the States would get the additional money continuously. I am advised that that $3m was part of the $69m which was added to the payments to the States at the Premiers Conference to compensate for functions transferred to the States as a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORT EXAMINERS OF AIRMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Townley asked me a question in connection with an article which appeared in today's Australian regarding some reported dog fight between the captain of a Boeing 747 and a departmental examiner en route from Brisbane to Wellington. I have to report that the details of that Press article are incorrect. In fact, the Department's examiner did not require any diversion of the aircraft to Sydney for repairs. The decision to go to Sydney from Brisbane rather than continue to Wellington was, in fact, taken by the captain and there was absolutely no question of any threat of the loss of any licence. In general terms, the examiner's part in the surveillance of revenue passenger flights is not any kind of command role.

—Recently Senator Lewis asked me a question about subscriber trunk dialling charges in relation to the new AUSTPAC service and requested that I obtain information on this. Senator Lewis was concerned that STD charges were very high. I am able to advise the honourable senator that some STD charges will not be increased, although some of them will, but there will be reductions in STD charges for longer distance calls in line with the McKinsey report recommendations. I also inform the Senate that AUSTPAC uses an entirely new technology for data transmission, which is different from the old DATEL system. In this new system the cost of the transmission component is much lower than that for STD traffic. This explains why there is a different charging rate for AUSTPAC compared with STD. I am advised that AUSTPAC charges will be higher than the present DATEL charges for short haul data traffic but lower over a longer distance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Can the honourable sentor give some indication as to why she wishes to make a personal explanation?
—Yes. I claim to have been misrepresented in the worst possible way by an article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator may proceed.
—I wish to rebut something that was contained in this article. I do not want it repeated--
—Again and again and again?

—Again and again and again. I say at the outset that I have no quarrel with the content of the article which appeared on page 3 of this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. What I am complaining about is that having stated that the Australian Democrats spokesman on social security, Senator Haines, made a particular statement the article went on to refer to me in every other case by using the male personal pronoun. I take strong exception to this, not because I have any disregard for men. In fact, some of my best friends are men. However, I would like to make the point that I feel that some correction needs to be made to the impression engendered-pardon the pun-I presume in readers of the Sydney Morning Herald that I am male, furthermore, that I may be thinking of becoming a male or that overnight I did become male. I do not intend to take steps to prove that I am not male at the moment. I simply ask that my word be taken on the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: On a more serious note, at the moment there is a record number of women in the Senate and the House of Representatives. As I think was made quite apparent earlier this week from preceedings in that other place, there are members not only of parliament but also of the community generally who are having a little trouble getting used to the fact that women have risen to such giddy heights. I am proud to be a female member of this place. I am proud to be a member of this place when there is a record number of women here. I hope that in the future years after subsequent elections the number will rise even further. I hesitate to say--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Haines, I suggest that you are getting away from the personal explanation and that you are running a bit of a campaign.

—Mr President, I take your point although I add that I think it is the dearth of women in this place in the last few years and certainly further into the past that has led some people to assume that all members of the House of Representatives and the Senate automatically have to be male. That is probably behind the slip in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. The journalist concerned is female. She and I are quite well acquainted with each other. I do not wish to cast any aspersions on her assessment of my sexuality. I assume that the mistake was made by a proof reader or an unimaginative sub-editor.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Grimes proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The difficulties and uncertainty caused by the Government's policies in the area of children's services.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is raised today because of the uncertainty and the anxiety which currently exists for those involved in children's services in this country. This anxiety and uncertainty arises out of speculation from statements by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), from statements by various Government members and from the leaking of the so-called Spender report on this matter. It is appropriate, I believe, in Child Care Week that we discuss this subject and hopefully, we can have a clarifying statement from the Minister concerned, Senator Chaney. If we achieve nothing more than that and create some sort of certainty in the minds of the people involved in children's services as to their future, I think we will have justified raising this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: This Parliament's involvement in children's services arises largely out of the Child Care Act of 1972 which was introduced by Sir Phillip Lynch, the then Minister for Labour and National Service and now, ironically, the leader of the razor gang, the very group which is determined to cut Commonwealth involvement in areas such as this. The aims of that Act were to provide good quality child care to a wide cross-section of children in the community. I believe there is now a concern that this aim has been neglected by the present Government. Since 1975 the total amount spent on the program has diminished in real terms. Had the $75m which was allocated by the Government in that year been indexed to retain its value it would have been now in excess of $110m rather than the approximately $80m which it is. I do not argue for such an increase but the figures demonstrate the restrictions of the program since those days in 1975 and reflect the strains on those operating under the present funding system.

I think all of us have had representations from family day care groups and child care groups which have had to cut staff, restrict entries and restrict the quality of their care. The Act was designed to provide Federal money to develop a program of children's services and to increase the quality and quantity of child care for children under school age. This dual stress on quality and quantity was repeated throughout the second reading speech of Sir Phillip Lynch in 1971. The quality was to be guaranteed by funding existing and future services with qualified staff who could provide children with appropriate development and social activities rather than just minding them. Quantity was to be provided through capital and recurrent grants being made available to non-profit organisations which were prepared to run such services.

One can quote some of the words of Sir Phillip Lynch as to why the Commonwealth felt that it should have become involved at the time and why the Act was introduced in the way it was. I quote from page 2289 of Hansard of 10 October of that time. Sir Phillip, referring to the surveys that had been done, said:
. . . they reveal that child care facilities had not kept pace with the rapid growth in the female labour force during the 1960s-
I think one could reflect on whether they have in the 1970s-

And that, as a consequence, existing child care facilities were inadequate, qualitatively and quantitively, for the growing numbers of children needing them. Not only were there too few centres but in many cases the provision was only for child minding and not for the quality of child care appropriate to the educational, emotional and developmental needs of the young children involved.
Later he went on to say:

The purpose of the scheme is to meet this existing problem-to help the children of working and other parents insofar as they are deprived of proper child care either because good quality facilities are not available or because the cost is presently too high. The scheme is not intended either to encourage or discourage mothers from entering paid employment.

From some of the statements one hears these days one wonders whether the changes are not designed to try to force women out of paid employment. A third and quite separate tier of funding was to be provided to ensure that children who could not afford the ordinary level of fees could have their fees subsidised. This was designed to reduce fees below the rate which was then the market rate for care. That 1972 market rate was established in centres which had little or no trained staff and barely met the minimum standards of State authorities. As the then Minister said:

. . . child care which was beneficial to the child's overall development was prohibitively costly for the large body of parents, and secondly, that the childminding arrangements that most parents could afford fell far short of the quality that was required in the interests of child welfare.

Therefore, the assumption at the time was that the 1972 Act would provide nearly all children with the subsidy needed to ensure that their parents could afford the necessary quality of care and that, in addition, subsidies would allow access to those children who needed additional help on the basis of economic need. This is a total contradiction of the concept in the present Minister's proposal that parents should pay the real cost of care and that only the very needy-presumably a very limited group in view of this Government's definition of 'needy'-should be eligible for any form of subsidy. Why the current Minister and the current Government should assume that in 1981 parents can afford the full cost of quality care when his predecessor recognised in 1972 that they could not I really cannot imagine, particularly in these difficult economic times.

The Commonwealth's commitment to quality care in the time since that Act was introduced has actually raised the overall costs of care with greater professional costs for trained staff and higher salaries for untrained staff. These, together with the requirements of the Child Care Act, would put unsubsidised quality care out of the reach of almost all people. Only the very wealthy could afford it. The benefit of having subsidised care of the type we have had has been that the 60,000 or more children in community-based services have received the quality of care that they deserve and that, in most cases, they could afford.

One of the worst aspects of the proposed changes in the program that have been floated or put around in recent days is, I believe and most people involved in the area believe, that they could do nothing to alleviate the real problems in child care. The proposals, as we have seen and heard of them from various Government spokesmen, tinker with the payment system, trying to redistribute subsidies amongst existing services and children. They ignore the very real problem, that there is still insufficient provision of child care spaces in the community. The Minister himself has just sent letters of rejection to more than 500 applicants for new services under the program. Although all of them were not necessarily for child care, the Minister has admitted that $5m worth of high priority services ready for funding were amongst those that were rejected. Recommendation of the funding of these centres was made by Mr Spender and his committee.

Existing services in the public and private sector generally are not meeting the needs in new areas and low income areas, particularly in regard to children under the age of three years. Although many services have been established through the Office of Child Care in areas of high need over the last five years, they are still inadequate to meet the needs of these areas. We all know about them. We have heard of the service in Penrith, New South Wales, which has 50 places and some 200 or 300 children on the waiting list. In Marrickville, New South Wales, 125 are on the waiting list, 70 of whom are two-year-olds. The need is no respecter of area or class. A centre in Lane Cove in Sydney has 120 children on the waiting list and another in Ryde has 80 children on the waiting list. We know that family day care schemes in Canberra and Sydney have had to close their books because they could not cope with the demand and others have had to cut down on the qualified staff and the co-ordinating staff they have, so affecting the efficiency of their organisations. Some schemes are handling the equivalent of over 150 full time children, although the schemes are designed for 100 children. In every State-including my own, Tasmania-there is a desperate need for care in low income housing areas and in some of the newly-developed areas. All of us know of and have received correspondence about people who have worked to get schemes off the ground but who cannot do so, and about other schemes which have had to close.

The real problem that the Government ought to be facing is the provision of services for those whose access is limited by the unavailability of services, rather than maintaining that the problem is largely one of fees charged. The lack of services affects both the comfortably off and the desperately poor. The level of care provided for the women with children under school age who are in paid work is inadequate. All of us know that if we add to them the women who are studying, the women who are sick, the men who take the responsibility for the care of children and the women who need time to themselves there is an unmet demand for care in this area. The bulk of children using some form of centre-based care or care supervised through, say, the family day care scheme use these schemes for less than 20 hours a week. Only half of those using care outside the family for more than 30 hours a week are in some form of formal, supervised care. Many are still cared for through informal arrangements and often by a mixture of care systems unless they can get access to some stable form of care.

I have received reports and correspondence from people pointing out the real difficulties. I have heard from a woman who is involved in the child care area, who knows how the system operates, who is professionally qualified and who is sufficiently well off to pay for child care. She has pointed out the problems which have arisen in New South Wales where, for example, there were only 403 children under two years of age in centres in the whole of the State in 1980. She is exactly the sort of woman who should be able to use the system, who should be able to cope with the problems. However, with a child who is now nearly two and a half years old, she went through six changes of care within a period of just over 12 months. Finally she managed to find a place in a centre. Her problems and the problems of her child must be being repeated in thousands of other cases, often with less happy endings. The issue for her, her husband and her child was not cost as she could afford to pay; it was the lack of stable care arrangements and the lack of opportunity to get into such arrangements.

I suggest that the response of the Government, from what we have heard, is either indifference or a lack of realisation of what is going on. One can interpret Cabinet's refusal to allocate the $5m proposed by the Spender report only as a reflection of this. These were high priority, needed programs and one can report such a response only as indifference. However, this indifference does not extend just to the Cabinet and the matter of expending a small amount of money, such as that $5m. When one looks at the remarks and the actions of the Minister in the last few weeks one can understand how the level of anxiety and concern in the users and providers of child care has risen.

His statement on Budget spending started this process. He forestalled an expected rush on the Office of Child Care by anxious applicants by pointing out that this year's funding would allow for little or no new project spending; the money was already spent. However, at the end he stated that he was looking at the imposition of a common means test aimed at making parents pay the full cost of care. This was surrounded by the usual rhetoric about making sure taxpayers' money went to those most in need. It sounded innocuous except for the business of the real cost. People became more sensitive to the Minister's statements and the Press releases which were going out. They sought advice on what was meant by the real cost. Then letters went out to the existing programs funded by the Office, reminding them of their obligations under the Child Care Act to give priority access to certain groups and to use funding to reduce the fees of the needy with other parents making a significant contribution towards the cost of care.

It seems bizarre that the Government that removed the economic needs category of subsidy in 1977, as part of the funding of child care centres, should remind the centres of their obligation to offer such subsidies themselves. It was in the original Child Care Act. It was quite clear that economic need was a basis for additional funds being made available to the centres. This ensured that subsidising these fees did not necessarily draw money away from the main program or from the special subsidies for migrants who might put additional demands on a centre's staffing. However, with the withdrawal of the Health Insurance Act in 1976, which removed the definition used in the Child Care Act of 'disadvantaged', this section of the Act was made inoperable. So we have the situation that the Government which claims to care for the needy does not specifically subsidise them in centre-based care and now asks centres to rearrange their funding so they can apply the fee subsidies on the basis of need. This the centres do, claiming for instance the lone parents subsidy for a wealthy lone parent and using the amount to subsidise the fees of, say, a handicapped mother. This has added to the confusion and difficulties of these people. Is all the Government funding designed for the needy or is the Government partly funding the quality component of the services, as proposed by Sir Phillip Lynch?

To return to the actions of the current Minister and the confusion and difficulties they are causing, the letter sent to the administrators of schemes, reminding them of the present obligations and conditions, had a final paragraph or two which confirmed the anxieties raised in the earlier Press releases. It said:
The Office of Child Care is currently reviewing the funding arrangements for centre based and family based day care, and examining the possibility of introducing standardised means tests . . .
Once the Government has carefully considered all the options, and reached decisions, the Minister will make an announcement concerning the new policy approaches.

These suggested major policy changes had serious implications and caused concern to those who were providing the care. Then the final factor entered into the discussion. The Minister had earlier this year asked Mr Spender, a back bencher in the House of Representatives, to chair an internal review of the Children's Services Program. The other members of the committee were in fact public servants.

The report went to the Minister around June this year. Since then news of the review has leaked out to various groups in the community whose anxiety had already been raised by the questions asked. Then copies of the report began to appear all over the States in this country. The media obviously have it and many community groups have it. It seems that only members of parliament and some public servants are refused access to this report, even when they attend meetings with community groups which obviously have copies of it and obviously are quoting from copies. This situation, I suggest, is absurd. The Minister should table the report and, if he is unwilling to do so, I will certainly table the terms of reference and the recommendations of the report--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ooh, ah!
—I do not think Senator Chaney would mind. I do not understand why he does not do it himself; if he does not do so I will table the whole of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report contains many recommendations which cause concern. One recommendation which causes concern is, of course, the matter of the standardised means test determined by the Department of Social Security. It relates to the introduction of a common means test administered by the Department which in fact would provide or some people paying the full fee and some people paying a reduced fee. This has caused considerable anxiety because of the possibility, if the means test is strict, as most means tests introduced by the Government are, of people on ordinary wages and in ordinary circumstances being in difficulties. We will end up with a situation of child care on a very low level for the poor, the rich being able to afford their own child care and in between others having to fight their own way.

It is for this reason and other reasons which will be brought forward by Senator Giles that we have raised this matter today. We seek some clarification from the Minister and the Government of just where they are going so that we can remove this anxiety from the people concerned in the area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the bringing of this matter of public importance before the Senate during Child Care Week. I agree that the matter of children's services is of wide public interest and I think some discussion of it can help to clarify some doubts which exist in the community. In the same way I welcomed the questions which were asked with respect to this program in Senate Estimates Committee G. But that of course is a slightly less public forum than the chamber itself, particularly on a broadcast day.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is perhaps an element or two of both the debate today and the public debate which has preceded it which I regret. At least part of the debate seems to have been designed to raise the level of concern rather than to clarify matters or to raise serious questions. Indeed at times I feel that one is in danger of being 'damned if you do and damned if you don't'. I get almost eloquent pleas from my opposite number, Senator Grimes, in favour of open government and putting the facts on the table. But there is very little incentive to do so when one does try to make the facts clear and then has the position represented in a way which casts it in a quite peculiar light. Let me refer very quickly to the statement which I issued at Budget time, very much in the interests of presenting a position which would be clear to the many people who are interested in this matter. That statement has already been referred to in debate by Senator Grimes. I made it quite clear what level of funding would be available, what the level of increase was and that there was little or no ability to fund new services, given that level of funding. I thought it was right that the large number of applicants with outstanding applications with the Department should have a very clear indication of the fact that they were unlikely to get funding in this financial year. I followed that up by actually notifying them of that individually. I was trying to make the position as clear as possible. I went on again to point out as follows:

In line with the Government's overall welfare policy of directing assistance to those in greatest need, the Government will examine the development of a common means test for all day care services supported through the children's services program.
I emphasise the words:
. . . the Government will examine the development of a common means tests . . .
Later in the Press release I said:
The Office of Child Care will consult with Government supported day care service sponsors in the development of the means test.

I would have thought those words made it quite clear that no policy decision had been taken with respect to that matter and that there would be a process of consultation before the Government moved towards decison making in this area. I therefore regret that in the interests of open government and free and fair debate on these matters Senator Grimes issued a Press release on 22 September in these terms:
Senator Chaney's announcement of the introduction of a standardised means test incorporating the full cost of care for users of child care services, has caused deep concern . . .

I think that puts an emphasis which does not accurately reflect the statement I made in which I said that the Government would be considering this matter. Senator Grimes went on later in the Press release to say:
Such groups-
Referring to the groups which are interested-
Must be consulted prior to announcements being made and provided with such guarantees of funding levels which will allow them to have confidence in the services they offer.

I point out to the Senate that the Press release I issued expressly drew attention to the fact that I proposed, through the Office of Child Care, to follow consultations. I also draw attention in my initial Press release, that is the Budget Press release, to these words:

The objective of a common means test would be to replace the existing range of means tests and fee scales and to assist parents who, because of low incomes, would otherwise be unable to meet all or part of child care costs.

I have tried to make it fairly clear that I have not made a decision in these matters. I am examining what I regard to be serious questions as to what is the proper level of contribution. I have, through the Department, tried to gather information which will enable the Government to make a sensible decision. I suggest that the statements which have been made both in the Press release that I have quoted and other statements which I have seen reported and of which I have seen copies rather gild the lily. I am very pleased to have the chance to make the position clear.

I do not want to see difficulties and uncertainties in an area which I regard as important. I will endeavour to illustrate, in the brief time which is available in these debates on matters of public importance, the basic approach of the Government. I will draw attention to the fact that I have outlined that basic approach in a number of public forums, both personally and in speeches approved by me and delivered by the head of the Office of Child Care on my behalf. Where there are areas that the Government is examining with a view to ascertaining whether there should be a policy change, I have made that public and known so that people may have a chance to contribute in the way that they are currently contributing.

Unfortunately, there is a dilemma here. If one takes that relatively open approach the fact is that we will get a sense of uncertainty and concern on the part of some of the users. The alternative, of course, is to proceed secretly and make decisions and simply announce them so that nobody has a chance to be concerned. That is not the course which I have followed since I became Minister for Social Security. It is not a course which I would like to follow, and I trust that my opposite number in the Opposition will not in the end force me into a position which I regard as a less than desirable approach to the matter.

I am pleased that in this debate it has been acknowledged that it was the Liberal Government, under Mr McMahon, which introduced the Child Care Act. I adopt the words of Sir Phillip Lynch when he introduced the Child Care Bill in 1972. He said:
The purpose of the legislation is to ensure the development of child day care facilities of good quality throughout the Commonwealth.

That remains a view or an ambition to which I would subscribe. The fact of the matter is that since the introduction of that legislation there has been a very great increase in the amount of child care facilities available and many would say that there has been a very considerable increase in the quality of child care services available. I do not want to spend time putting a lot of statistics on the record but I point out that in 1970 there were estimated to be 560 child care centres operating throughout Australia with a total capacity of 14,000 places and in 1980 the child care survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimated that 90,500 children were using child care centres. That is a very considerable expansion. It is an expansion which has very largely occurred, as I will show in a moment, under Liberal governments. I would have thought that it provided some earnest of our intentions in this area. The fact that I have raised difficulties which I see in the existing program I make no apology for. I do not believe that they should be used to suggest that we are not concerned.

Not long after the passage of the Child Care Bill of 1972, we had an election. I acknowledge that the incoming Government paid some attention to this area of activity and increased considerably the expenditure in regard to it. Unfortunately, I believe most people would say in retrospect that it did over concentrate on pre-schools. I note that Senator Grimes, in a recent speech, did acknowledge this when he said:

We made some mistakes when we introduced the Children's Services Program. We allowed ourselves to become captives of various vocal groups who pushed their own barrows, in particular the people committed to the extension of single purpose services offering pre-school education rather than care.
I believe that, in retrospect, it would now be a widely held view that the emphasis on pre-schools from 1972 to 1975 was mistaken.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that in 1976, when the Fraser Government came to office, it took a rather different approach. It took the approach that it should change the emphasis to providing for child care rather than pre-school care. In statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that was made clear when the Office of Child Care was established under the present encumbent, Marie Coleman, who had served the previous Government on the Social Welfare Commission. In a statement on 20 May, the Prime Minister said:
The important point is the priority the Government is giving to the provision of child care within the overall program.
He went on:

Many children from needy families have not only been without the advantages of pre-school education but too often without the benefits of basic adequate care. It is essential to concentrate the Government's resources in areas of greatest need and the Government wishes to give greater emphasis to child care for children of needy families in the development of the Childrens Services Program.

In what I have said over the last few months I have not been saying anything very radical. I have been reaffirming the fundamental objectives established by the Government in 1976. When I ask my Department to send letters to child care organisations reminding them of the social and welfare objectives of the Government in this program, I make no apology for so doing. I am sorry if it causes people to be worried. It is proper that in the expenditure of a very large amount of the taxpayers' money we should as far as possible direct our attention to objectives which are defined by government.

I again draw the attention of honourable senators briefly to the fact that in 1976 and 1977 my predecessor, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, went to some pains to put on the public record the fact that we were concerned to establish social priorities. We said that we wanted people such as the children of single parents, the children of Aboriginals, the children of ethnic parents, who had a particular social need for child care, to have priority of access. That was defined years ago and I am doing no more at the moment than reaffirming those objectives and trying to ensure that they are pursued by those whom we fund.

With respect to those people who are, in a direct economic sense, unable to afford the cost of services, we indicated in those early years of the Fraser Government-and I affirm it now-that we believe that, where one has to share available moneys, priority should be given to those who would not, without the assistance of their fellow taxpayers from whom the money comes, be able to have access to services. Again, I make no apology for that. I would have thought that the social priorities of the Government in this program would have been welcomed by the Opposition. Recently I opened a child care centre in a Labor electorate. The Labor member did point out to the audience with great fairness that the present Government had shown a proper concern for social priorities. A great number of these centres are in Labor electorates where, as he pointed out, the greater needs often arise. I am very pleased that we have avoided a situation in which money has gone where the votes are, rather than where the need is. If I have a prediction about this program and its risk in the future, it is that, like most areas of social welfare, there will be a great temptation for governments, of whatever colour, to put the money where the votes are rather than where the welfare needs are.

I do not believe that any understanding of the Government's position could be complete without an examination of the figures of recent years. I am aware that many people in the field would like to see additional expenditure made. I am aware, as a member of the Government, that funds are not unlimited. But I suggest that, when honourable senators examine the funding for the Children's Services Program from 1973-74 to the present, it will become clear to them that the Government has placed great emphasis on the expansion of child care services as against the emphasis placed by the previous Government on pre-school services.

I intend to seek leave of the Senate to incorporate a table in Hansard. I have shown it to Senator Grimes. It makes clear that, in 1974-75, $37m was spent by the Government on pre-schools and some $8m in round terms on other services. Some 81 per cent of funding was devoted to pre-schools and some 18 per cent to other services. In 1980-81, the figures are $31m for pre-schools and $42m, almost $43m, on other services. The shift in emphasis is revealed by the fact that 42 per cent was spent on pre-schools and 57 per cent on other services. It is interesting to see the change in the level of funding for other services-from just over $8m in 1974-75 to $42,850,000 in 1980-81. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate the table in Hansard.
Leave granted.
