TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I am concerned that in this area of the development of policy there should be a clear public understanding of the position. As I said earlier, I regret it if people in the field feel uncertain about the Government's intention. Therefore, I propose to refer very briefly to a couple of statements that I have made publicly-as it happens through the mouth of a public servant, at my request. The speeches had my personal approval before they were delivered. I refer first to a statement made in Victoria at the opening of the Curzon Street Child Care Centre when, after dealing with figures such as I have just mentioned, I pointed out that all of the increases in funding this year were in the non-pre-school area. I went on:

SPEECH.PARA: Increasingly, though, the Commonwealth has concentrated its assistance on meeting the child care needs of low income families, single parent families, disabled children, migrants, Aboriginals and children in isolated areas, and has developed a policy of priority of access for child care facilities which it funds. These services are asked to give priority to children in special need of care, for example to children whose mother is under stress because of ill-health, to children of single parent families and to other children where the need for child care is likely to be particularly high. Child care services funded by the Commonwealth are asked to monitor their enrolments constantly to ensure that these priority groups are the ones that they do indeed serve.
I went on to say, through the mouth of Marie Coleman:

Alongside this policy of priority of access, the Commonwealth also has a policy that its child care subsidies should be directed, as far as possible, to ensure that assistance with the cost of child care is directed to those parents in economic need. All Commonwealth funded child care services are expected to apply a sliding fee scale and to ensure that those parents who can afford to pay make a significant contribution to the full cost of providing the service.

While we believe that child care facilities should be readily available to meet the needs of Australian families, we also believe that those who can afford to pay for such services should do so while those on lower incomes should not be disadvantaged in relation to access to child care facilities.

I do not mind the Opposition stating that we should spend more in this and other fields. That is a legitimate approach. It is a complaint that a party which believes that higher levels of taxation or larger deficits are possible is entitled to take but I ask members of the Opposition to acknowledge the basic fairness of this Government's policy objectives. I would have thought that, if one had in this chamber an honest debate in which people really spoke their minds, there would be widespread support for the social priorities established there. Because of the suggestion that we are in some way trying to keep these things under cover, I propose to table that speech.

I also refer to what I had to say to the Australian Capital Territory Family Day Care Association, although again not in person. Family day care is an area in which expressions of concern have been made to me. I understand that concern given that subsidy rates have not changed for some years. But in that speech I indicated our commitment to the maintenance of a healthy family day care network in Australia. I have referred to the very substantial expansion of those programs under the present Government and to the fact that family day care represents overall a very cost-effective way of providing child care.
Perhaps most significantly, I went on to make it quite clear again that family day care should not be regarded as under attack. I said:

The Office of Child Care within my Department is currently collecting up-to-date information on the present cost structures of family day care schemes, their pricing practices and the types of means tests they apply.
I hope to have the results of these investigations available to me by the end of this year. I will then ensure that there is consideration of the level of funding.
I went on to say-this is the last quote that I will use:

Whatever the outcome of that review process, it is important to bear in mind that the Government's basic priorities in the child care area remain the same as they were when it first came to office nearly six years ago.

Again, because I do not have time to quote all of the speech, I table that document. The importance of proper care for Australian children is not something which ought to be the subject of debate in this chamber. Rather, I think we should be directing our attention to the best means of achieving that proper level of care. Because I am a member of the Government, unlike Senator Grimes I have to take some cognisance of the fact that there are limits on the amount of expenditure that can be made in any year. I assure the Senate that the Government proposes to ensure as best it can that it will direct the available resources to the priorities which I have outlined and that it will examine the funding position of child care in the light of the information which it is at present gathering with a view to ensuring that there can be a maintenance of the child care health situation in Australia to which people of modest means and people of high social need have access and that to the extent there are limits on government funds, which there must be, funds will be directed with these priorities in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Grimes wishes to seek leave to table some documents.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I wish to table two documents to which I referred in my speech, namely, the terms of reference and the recommendations of the committee of inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a spirit of ecumenicalism we would like to offer our contribution to a debate which we believe certainly has a place in the Senate, namely the difficulties and uncertainty caused by the Government's policies in the area of children's services. In relation to the specific question of means tests of which standardisation in theory has a superficial appeal, we would like to point out that this could lead to flagrant inequities which can be avoided at present where each community centre sets its own income levels which reflect the realities of that community. As an example, if the current income levels in use for eligibility for disadvantaged status in health care were used, a couple with two dependent children and with a household income of $210 per week might be ineligible for the highest level of assistance in respect of child care whereas such a family in Mount Newman would be amongst the poorest in a community where the cost of living is astronomical. We have every confidence that the inquiries being conducted by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) at the moment will lead to decisions based on the best possible information available. We hope to see some built-in provision for special circumstances such as the ones I have just mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, we might also ask, apropos means testing as a principle, whether child care is welfare or whether it is a community service such as education. I also point out that children in private schools are all supported by the Federal Government regardless of parental means, regardless of whether the parents are able to pay. It has been recently suggested that the Minister is being urged to implement a new proposal as a result of pressure from commercial interests. In fact, $300,000 has been allocated to a pilot study which is being planned. We are unaware of any approaches from the clients of commercial centres or from parents who might be described as potential clients excluded from usage by prohibitive costs. On the contrary, our experience is that, given a choice, parents opt for the quality which is synonymous with community child care.

Much of the commercial sector takes its role seriously and maintains high standards. Some child care centres are run as proprietors' hobbies. They have working proprietors who expect a return from their investment which is a little more than wages and a modest profit. Some authorities estimate that a charge of $100 per child per week would be required to maintain high standards and return a sizable profit. The position is analagous with that in many private nursing homes where the proprietor or lessee who is also the matron or administrator places his or her professional competence and integrity on the line and is not primarily interested in an impressive return on capital. This happy state of affairs where a high standard is maintained does occur. But in too many instances the provision of a government subsidy is simply an open invitation to those with capital to invest with no concern at all for the quality of the service.

Companies with chains of nursing homes have rapidly established themselves within the industry and as formidable lobby groups. I might add that the home-grown variety is not necessarily preferable to the imported or transnational one. I do not intend my comments to be taken as a blanket condemnation of private nursing homes or of privately run child care centres. Some provide a high standard of care and invariably that standard is reflected in good industrial relations. There is, however, a regrettable tendency among the less scrupulous to circumvent regulations and standards in order to increase their profits despite the best efforts of overworked and understaffed inspectorates which simply cannot eliminate these practices. It is impossible, in addition, to enforce industrial awards while so many young women particularly are prepared to accept any job under almost any conditions. The hazards of essential services on the cheap were further demonstrated when funds were made available for homeless persons initially some years ago and private profit organisations, as distinct from charitable or community groups, sought to accommodate homeless males in one instance of which I know and made a submission for a rental of $1,000 per month which was in fact the mortgage repayment on a very valuable piece of real estate.

Care of the very young or of any vulnerable group is much too important to be left, even in part, to the vagaries of the private enterprise group in our community and, at worst, the exploitation of private enterprise. Family day care cost to the consumer is largely the same as or just a little less than the average cost of day care. To my knowledge it is $30 to $35 per week. To the extent that it is the genuine choice of consumers, there may be a case for a decent subsidy to provide a proper return to a woman-this could also apply to a man-who cares for, say, five children in her own home. Perhaps two of the children are her own. At present she receives considerably less than the minimum wage for a job which is intensely demanding in every aspect and in every sense of the word.

Failure to utilise child care centres in some cases, particularly in less affluent areas is, I suggest, closely associated with a lack of access to employment for women in those areas. Where the mothers are more affluent they tend to be better educated, more mobile and more likely to have jobs. They are also likely to have their own transport and a real choice of child care centres from which to choose. Less fortunate women-the majority-are limited to the work available close to their homes, for which they will probably be paid less than $5 per hour, and a part time job of 16 hours which is the average for part time jobs in Australia at present. This is barely enough to cover the cost of placing two children in commercial care.

It is most disappointing to discover that the Minister apparently is prepared to accept advice which can only lead to deteriorating standards of care and employment rather than seeking to ensure the funding philosophy which would see an accelerated expansion of and accessibility to good quality community care. To point up my remarks I would like to draw attention to a report in today's West Australian in which the State Minister for Community Welfare states:

'We must strike a proper balance between the needs of developing children and the economic realities of day care', Mr Hassell said. 'If staff-child ratios are too high or staff qualifications are too demanding, private day care will cease'.
The Government thought that there were many experienced mothers capable of playing a part in child day care, he said.
They needed no academic qualifications to work successfully in this field, provided that there was skilled guidance.

I am greatly concerned at the possibility of a State government in this case looking at providing child care on the cheap with untrained workers. I am not implying that the people are unskilled workers, as he has, but rather people who are not specifically trained for this very demanding and very valuable field of activity. It seems to indicate once again that the work that women customarily do is being undervalued and that the Government, if it is possibly able to do so, will provide these services-which are generally accepted as essential, as the Minister for Social Security acknowledged today-at a far lower-priority than they should attract from Government expenditure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance that has been raised today by the Opposition is so broad that it has allowed the Opposition's imagination to run wild. We have just had a pretty good example of that from Senator Giles who made all sorts of suggestions such as the one that the most disadvantaged people in the community will be paying fees. She was talking about women on low incomes and women with part time jobs not being able to meet the means tested fees that the Government supposedly will apply. Whenever the Opposition claims that the difficulties and uncertainties in these areas are caused by Government policies and they bring them forward for discussion as matters of public importance, we can see immediately who is causing the uncertainties and who is whipping up the concern in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes made a speech on 17 October in which he claimed that the total amount spent on the Children's Services Program had diminished considerably in real value since 1977. He said that had the $75m that the Australian Labor Party had allocated to this program been indexed the Government would now be spending $110m instead of the $80m that it has allocated this year. He claimed today that he was not asking for this sort of expenditure but he did not say what sort he was asking for. Certainly the inference is that an amount similar to the amount of $110m should be put up. In other words, governments should go on spending and spending, never having a review and never having a look to see whether the amount is justified. They should go on handing out money at the level which is indexed to the figure allocated some six or seven years ago. I guess that is the philosophy of a big spending government. It is the philosophy of the Labor Party that got us into so much trouble in those three dark years for overspending and it is nothing more than we should expect from the present supporters of the Opposition.

The largest amount of money spent on children's services is in the area of the provision of day care facilities. Both Senator Grimes and Senator Giles stuck to that area and I intend to do so too. There are two subsidised systems in this area. There is the centralised system under which mothers bring their cildren to a centre that is subsidised by the Commonwealth Government or paid for by other agencies. The mothers leave their children there for a full day if they are a working mother or for a few hours if the mother just needs a few hours to herself. There is also the family day care system under which individual women look after children in their own home. They apply to the Federal Government for a subsidy under the special needs area that we are talking about.

I would like to explain the centralised system. In 1970, as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has already said, there were only 560 centres in Australia catering for 14,000 children. Forty of those centres were assisted by some organisation such as a State government or a local government. There was no Commonwealth contribution at all. In 1972 the then government bought into this area and the Budget allocation for the centralised system was $2.49m. The allocation now is $42.85m. I really do not believe that Senator Grimes or Senator Giles can possibly say that enough money is not being spent in this area. There has been a considerable increase. In the period between 1970 and 1980 the number of centres has increased from 560 to 1,350 and they are now looking after 90,000 children. Of that number of centres, 518 have Commonwealth aid and 813 are privately run. The rest are run by the States and non-profit organisations. We have come a long way in the provision of these services since 1970. The main problem associated with the 518 Government subsidised centres is that just costs are not being applied to the mothers using them. The Commonwealth subsidises these centres and each centre sets its own rates depending on the costs and services. The rates vary considerably. Frankly, the fees vary so much from State to State and from centre to centre that there is simply no justice in the present system. We have been told that some mothers are paying $80 per week and others are paying $45 a week. There is also quite a large range in the rates which apply to those who are categorised as disadvantaged and who get an extra subsidy.

The policy of the Government has been very clear, as the Minister has said. From the beginning he has said that the money should go to those mothers who are not only most in need but also who cannot afford to pay. Broadly speaking, this involves the children of lone parents; children whose both parents are in the work force and on low incomes; children from ethnic minority groups; children who are in isolated circumstances; children with a physical, intellectual or emotional handicap and so on. There is a long list of the sorts of children who are in need. I believe that the Minister has incorporated that list in Hansard. The Government has spelled out its priorities very clearly to all centres. Yet, as I said, depending on which State people live in and which centres their children go to, the fees charged by the centres vary widely. Consequently, the Government has decided that we need to review and thrash out some of the problems in this area. So we will have a year of consolidation and review to see just what is happening, where the gaps are and to enable consultation-as the Minister very clearly stated in his speech-with all the people working in this area. We know that access for some of the more disadvantaged groups is very difficult as there is no child care centre in their area. We have to look at access and make sure that those in real need are able to get a subsidy.

We have suggested that a common means test for parents ought to be looked at. Naturally, that would put more emphasis on those in need. There is no method of subsidising a mother attending the 813 private enterprise centres I mentioned just a minute ago even though the mother may be in real need. This is also an area that has to be looked at. I noticed that in an answer to one of the questions asked by Senator Grimes during an Estimates committee meeting the Minister suggested that a pilot scheme be established. Senator Giles has left the chamber, but I gather she must have got that matter very confused because there is no scheme presently in action and there is no intention of setting up such a scheme immediately. It is being looked at. I am particularly interested in this pilot project. If private enterprise decides to set up a child care centre in a certain area because it believes there is a need in that area, let it set it up. If mothers who fit into the Government guidelines I mentioned a little earlier come to the centres the Government could subsidise those mothers. I believe that this is the way we can make the taxpayer's dollar go a lot further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you say that it should be our policy to subsidise the child rather than the centre?
—We should subsidise the mother. I do not believe that the child should be subsidised. I definitely believe that we should subsidise the mother rather than the centre.
—You cannot be coached from the sidelines.

—Senator Mulvihill, I was asked a question and you are wasting valuable minutes. I believe that the question Senator Thomas asked me is crucial to the matter. I am quite sure that Senator Mulvihill would agree with me. I am talking about the mother in real need who has to go out to work to support her family, the single mother or the mother whose husband is unemployed or has a very low income. For a thousand reasons women have to go out and seek a job. I believe that those women on low incomes, whose total family income is low, justifiably should be subsidised by the taxpayer. The woman who just wants to go out to work and whose husband is well able to support the family comfortably has every justification for going out to work but she must not ask the taxpayer to subsidise the care of her child. I believe that Senator Mulvihill and I would be in accord in this area. As I explained earlier, the subsidy to the family day care centre is about $400 a child per annum, whereas the subsidy at big centres that the Commonwealth subsidises averages $1,100 a child per annum. That is a tremendous difference. I believe that this points up what is happening. Parents who can well afford to pay the full cost of the care of their children are not being asked to pay the full cost.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that we have to remember that the prime responsibility for looking after children is with the parents. Senator Giles put it as a question-she did not really say that she came down on that side but the inference certainly was there-that child care should be looked at as a community service, not as welfare, that it should be looked at in the same way as education. I think that is an appalling suggestion. Since when should any mother give up the responsibility of looking after her child? Why should the community take on the responsibility of looking after a child of mine that I am well able to look after and capable of paying for? I think that is the sort of big brother concept that the whole of Australia would shrink from. Every mother worth her salt would shrink from that.

We have to remember that it is not the responsibility of the community to look after and bring up children; it is the responsibility of the community to help the mother who is financially unable to bring up or at risk in bringing up her child in the best possible way. I suppose this gets back to the fact that the Government and the Opposition have different philosophies. The Government's philosophy is that the responsibility for children is still with the family, the parents; that governments do not interfere unless the need is really there. The Opposition's philosophy, so clearly expressed by Senator Giles, is that the responsibility for looking after and caring for children could be part of a community service, such as education. It is nothing of the sort. The community has to realise that that is one of the the basic differences in philosophy between the Opposition and the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing a matter of public importance about the difficulties and uncertainty caused by the Government's policies in the area of children's services. Specifically we are looking at these matters in relation to the direction of funding, the criteria used and the consequences of these matters, rather than the amount of funding which is actually provided, since, as Senator Grimes pointed out at the beginning of his contribution, we were not planning on debating the differences that could have occurred had indexing applied from the introduction of the Act. Like Senator Walters and other speakers, I will follow Senator Grime's lead in limiting my comments almost exclusively to child care centres and not take in the broader aspect of other things in the community relating to children's services.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been pointed out by earlier speakers that Government expenditure on children's services in the community will rise in the coming year. However, as will be apparent to anyone who looks at the breakdown, only in the vicinity of $6m is really available to be distributed among a range of projects required in the area of children's services. As Senator Grimes noted earlier, this has led to a situation in which new programs are not being accepted for funding and furthermore, in which existing services are not able to be expanded or extended. This in turn means that a large number of parents in the community whose children require the services of child care centres are not able to have their needs met. The fact that some centres that I know of in South Australia have waiting lists of something like 20 to 30 children is an indication that there is a growing pool of people in the community who require, for one reason or another, the services of child care centres.

As Senator Walters pointed out towards the end of her comments, a lot of the people who require these services require them not because they want to go off and play tennis or squash or to get a spot of relief from their children, although as a mother of two rather lively children I acknowledge that we sometimes need that relief, but because they have definite financial needs to meet. Putting their children in a child care facility of some sort helps them solve that problem. The Government must be aware of this trend in society. It must be aware of the increasing needs of some lone income parent families or dual income parent families for child care facilities, particularly in view of the fact that, apparently in New South Wales, the Department of Social Security actively sought submissions from community councils asking them to outline their needs. Unfortunately it would appear that those submissions have been overlooked, ignored or, for some other reason, not been able to be satisfied. The New South Wales position though is not as bad as I understand the Victorian position is where, I believe, there have been cuts in the vicinity of 10 per cent in real terms for children's services other than pre-school services.

This leads us to another major problem. What happens in an area like children's services either when funds are cut-which, of course, has not occurred across Australia in this particular case-or where increased needs are not met? The answer is that something has to give. The something that gives is usually staffing, quantity of services or quality of services. All three of those elements cannot be met at the same time if the belt has to be tightened in the particular child care centre suffering from a dearth of funds.

I believe the assertion of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that the present Government is concerned about the quality of children's services in Australia. He is known to be a compassionate man. He is known to be concerned about these areas as well as about a whole range of other areas in social services. I repeat a comment that I made the other day: We all know that there is only so much money and it cannot be spent the way we would all like it to be. Nevertheless, I am still concerned that the present policies are working against the Minister's avowed commitment which I have just said I accept and certainly share, as do we all in this place. The fact as that the more services that are cut back, the more the quality suffers and the fewer the children who can be accommodated. That is a simple fact of life.

The cut-backs will also affect employment in the area. Children's services are high labour intensive areas and as a general rule, very high employers of women. It disturbs me that one of the direct consequences of insufficient funds will be a decrease in employment in the area and in particular a decrease in women's employment. Heaven only knows, women have a limited number of employment opportunities in areas in which they have access to employment. To have one of their traditional areas cut back is something which bothers me.

The Minister has made the point that it is the taxpayer who ultimately pays for funding of services such as child care services and other forms of social service, and this, of course, is so. Yet I repeat that the present situation seems to be operating against his intention and certainly is not helping the position that the taxpayer is in. Reduced employment due to staffing means fewer people able to earn incomes; therefore, fewer people are able to pay taxes. Decreased staffing and decreased provision of facilities mean that particularly those people from two income families who require the services of child care centres will have to rethink their position. In many cases one of those incomes will have to be forgone either because the facilities are no longer available or because the families concerned cannot afford the increased costs. Either way, taxes again will not be able to be picked up by the Government. So it is a rather circular sort of situation.

At least some of these problems, I suggest, could be solved if the criteria used for subsidising parents of children in child care centres were narrowed so that lower income earners took priority. This was a point that Senator Walters took up and discussed at some length towards the end of the comments that she made. I was pleased to note that the Minister earlier on, in answer to Senator Grimes, asserted that low income earners were going to be the priority area in funding children's services. However, it does seem to be a point that has so far been lost to the community generally and to the children's services area in particular; otherwise there would not be the uncertainty in that area. Whatever else we feel about the quantity of funding, the directions in which that funding is going and the effectiveness of the funding, the simple fact remains that there is uncertainty in the area of children's services. Whether it ought to be there and whether it is a communications problem are irrelevant. The problem is still there. I therefore hope Senator Chaney's assertion will go some way to alleviating the uncertainty in that regard. In concluding, I ask the Minister two questions, if that is not out of order at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no harm in asking.
—There is no harm in asking them.
—But do not expect a reply.
—I do not share the honourable senator's cynicism in regard to the present Minister.
—You will learn.
—Indeed, the opinion I have of the present Minister is one that I have gained already from experience.
—Flattery will get you everywhere.

—I was rather counting on that to get an answer to the questions. I feel that the Minister's bolt has been shot anyway in regard to recent events in Western Australia and that my lattering comments cannot do him any more harm. The first question is: Can he give any indication of when or whether the present Act is likely to be revised and whether it is likely to contain provisions for constant review and updating? I ask the question not to be frivolous or to try to worm policy decisions out of the Minister but because organisations like the National Council of Women and the South Australian Children's Services Council, among others in the community, have sent copies of submissions to me that they have either made or are planning to make in regard to the updating of that Act. They, like the Minister and all the rest of us in the Senate, are concerned at the need for quality children's services in Australia and see the updating of that Act as one way of providing it.

SPEECH.PARA: The second question that I direct to the Minister for his consideration, if not actually for his answer, relates to the special problems facing the disabled child in the community. Again this is something that Senator Walters raised. It seems appropriate in the International Year of Disabled Persons to ask the Minister whether he would consider making an additional subsidy available to disabled children attending or wanting to attend child care centres. The Minister must be aware-I think every parent would be-that ordinary offspring are hard enough to handle. They require a large amount of our time, a great deal of our attention and a lot of tender, loving care. Child care centres which do all of this in loco parentis, as it were, attempt to provide those services. The staffing requirements for a disabled child in a child care centre are quite different and much more strenuous than those applying to a child who is not disabled. This is particularly true, as Senator Walters mentioned, of the intellectually disabled child. Mothers of these children are particularly needful of some relief; yet, for a variety of reasons, they are the very people who are least likely to get it, either because they cannot come up with the extra costs involved or because, as child care centres need to cut their staffing, they are loth to accept either intellectually or physically disabled children-however much they would like to-into the centres since almost entirely a one-to-one caring situation is required for these people. I ask the Minister, if he manages to get through that rambling tirade, whether he would consider appropriating an additional subsidy.

I do not think that anyone in this chamber is anything but concerned that quality and sufficient children's services be provided in this country. What we are doing on this side of the House is asking that those in most need have their needs met first and that, above all, the Child Care Act, which was introduced by a Liberal government nearly 10 years ago to provide for this, be updated to take into account the changing social needs of the 1980s. I do not think that is too much to ask. We are not, as Senator Walters suggested, asking for money to be spent for the heck of it. We are asking that those funds which are available be spent according to the major needs of the community and that the criteria be regularly reviewed so that they remain relevant to changing social needs. Only in that way can the commitment of the Minister and the commitment of all of us in this chamber be achieved. I do not think that even Senator Walters would argue with the sense and the inherent justice of that desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance relates to the difficulties and uncertainty caused by the Government's policies in the area of children's services. All of the previous speakers in the debate seemed more or less to address themselves to the matter of child care centres and day care facilities. I think there are very many more aspects of this subject of children's services. I feel it is rather appropriate that I take the opportunity of speaking today because I have been involved in the sphere of looking after children for many years, firstly as a mother and now as a grandmother. I think it is quite appropriate that I have this opportunity of saying something on the matter which is before the Senate this evening. I have been given the honour of becoming the chairwoman of the Save the Children Fund next year. I consider that to be a very important task and one which I was very happy to accept. I feel there is a great need to help children right throughout the world.

SPEECH.PARA: It is particularly relevant during this Child Care Week that we spare a thought for all those millions of children around the world who are the innocent victims of starvation, homelessness, cruelty and war, and whose only hope for survival rests with the generosity of governments, such as our own, and with concerned individuals throughout the world. It is important that we, as parents, teachers, the community, governments and government agencies, work together towards providing our children with the financial, moral, spiritual and educational support which is fundamental to their proper development. I have always held the view that the family remains the best way of caring for Australian children and for guiding them to adulthood. The family unit provides the ultimate loving environment which is so much an integral part of a stable and stimulating upbringing for our children.

However, in these times of strict economic policies, the financial burdens and pressures on the average Australian family are enormous and sometimes unbearable. Often it is necessary for the mother to continue in the work force, to supplement the family income and to help cover the basic costs of living. In fact, with the increasing number of women who are finding it necessary to continue in the work force after having their children, the demand for child care services in the community is extremely high. It makes one wonder whether, in fact, a reduction in the burden on the Australian family, perhaps through less taxes, would help to lessen the demand on the child care services which are provided by the Government. Actually, the Government is looking at the question of how to meet the demands of families in the greatest economic need while at the same time providing for those in greatest social need. I agree with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that the obligation to look after children should rest primarily with the parents and the Government should be moving to provide assistance in circumstances where parents cannot afford child care.

I would remind the Senate that it is not only the children of working parents who are assisted through the Government's Children's Services Program. I heard Senator Walters speak of some of the ways in which they are helped. The children of lone parents, children from ethnic minorities, children who have physical, intellectual or emotional handicaps, those who are at risk because of maltreatment or whose family is likely to break down, children from poor families and even those who live in isolated areas-there are many of them scattered throughout the far parts of Queensland-all have to be helped through our Government's Children's Services Program. I can think of other ways in which children are helped. Children are assisted through the work done for handicapped children, through the programs which the Government helps to sponsor, and the work done for spastics. It was only on Monday that I had the opportunity of meeting the entrants in the Miss Queensland contest who were working very hard indeed for spastic children. They are helped by our Government. The funds that are raised are subsidised in that way. Many other people work for children in need.

The 1981-82 Budget saw an allocation of $80.1m specifically to the Children's Services Program. That is an increase of $6.07m over the expenditure on the program in the previous year. Of this, $33.09m will be provided to the States and the Northern Territory as a contribution to pre-school education. An amount of $47m will be available to assist a range of services for children and families. This tells me of a caring government attitude. This is something that we should emphasise. This caring attitude is seen by the vast amount of money that our Government is willing to make available for this work. The Federal Government's involvement in child care services has been designed to respond to local community initiatives because the Government believes that members of local communities are the best people to know what sort of services they need. They give those services the kind of support that helps to make them a success and the whole community receives a worthwhile return for its tax outlays.

Therefore, the provision of services for groups with special needs assumes a top priority. This means that children of low income families and single parents, disabled and Aboriginal children$ the children of migrants and children living in remote and isolated areas are top of the list. To cater for the requirements of such groups is of great importance to the Government. The enrolments under all child care services which are funded under the Children's Services Program are monitored constantly to ensure that this policy of priority of access is maintained. In conjunction with this, the Government also operates a policy of priority for those in particular financial need. Financial assistance which is made available through the Children's Services Program must be channelled as a first priority to those in the greatest economic need. Schemes which cater for so many children in economic need that they use up their available pool of grants for this purpose are entitled to apply for extra funds.

In the 10 or so years that the children's services program has been operational, the number of child care centres operating throughout Australia has increased dramatically. In 1970 there were estimated to be about 560 child care centres operating throughout Australia with a total capacity of 14,000 places. Only 40 of these received assistance from State or local authorities. There was no Commonwealth contribution to child care. However, in October 1980, there were some 1,350 centres operating, of which about 520 received Commonwealth Government assistance, and a further 163 were Commonwealth supported family day care schemes. I believe that further Commonwealth supported services have come into operation since then. The actual administration of the children's services program involves a mixture of funding directly to organisations and funding through the States. In this way, therefore, it is designed to be a joint Federal-State effort, ensuring the best possible services for those in the community who need the most help.

As far as Queensland is concerned, our Department of Welfare Services, under the direction of the Minister, Terry White, provides an excellent range of services for children. The Department of Children's Services, which is within the Department of Welfare Services, has a budget of $24.6m for 1981-82 and has 32 offices located throughout our State. I thought honourable senators would be interested to know some of the work they are doing in Queensland. They include a crisis care service, child protection services, early childhood services, adoption, fostering, social aunts and uncles programs-that sounds rather interesting to me-care for children away from their families through children's homes, family group homes, hostels et cetera, and juvenile correction. As at 30 June 1980 4,526 children were in the care of the Director of the Department of Children's Services, although this represents only a proportion of the children with which the Department's officers were involved. Through the various programs undertaken by the Department about 11,300 children are involved.

Honourable senators can see that the Queensland Government is doing its bit to care for our children in Queensland. Seven joint Commonwealth-State programs are being conducted in Queensland at present. One of them is the family support services program which is run through the Office of Child Care. The Commonwealth has allocated $316,713 to this program. The youth services program has been allocated $153,580. There is also a very interesting program of school vacation care in which grants are made to community groups offering a wide range of activities in caring programs for those children who would normally be unsupervised during school holidays. These are children of working parents or a single parent who works and other children in disadvantaged circumstances such as those who are handicapped, Aboriginal and newly arrived migrants. An average of 53 projects are funded each school holiday period throughout the State. Funding is provided by our caring Commonwealth Government. During 1981-82 $183,000 has been made available for a program such as this. A grant of $108,000 has been made available for child care in women's refuges. This work, of course, is concerned with the care of children.

The International Year of the Child special projects are still going on. Our Government is conducting a children's week in Queensland and the Commonwealth Government has given $2,000 for this work. Grants for disabled children were spoken about earlier. As a contribution to the International Year of the Disabled, Commonwealth funds totalling $29,711 were made available in this year to assist 26 organisations concerned with disabled children and their families. I believe that the Federal Government and the Government in Queensland are working together in the area of children's services to ensure that the best possible assistance is given to those in our community who are least able to help themselves-our children. I am very pleased to be able to say that the close working relationship between the two governments is to the advantage of our children in need. I only hope that this continues so that our future citizens of Australia are given every possible opportunity to equip themselves for the future. The Australian Labor Party is very good at criticising and whingeing but let us not be too upset by that because that is what it is all about. Much progress has been made--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I refer to the Standing Orders regarding senators reading their speeches. It is perfectly clear that Senator Bjelke-Petersen is doing that. If she has any thoughts on this subject it would be better for the honourable senator to put her thoughts instead of Allen Callaghan's.
—I think Senator Bjelke-Petersen is using copious notes.

—I am just helping myself to make a good speech so that I can get my points over. It is only when one starts to make any reference to the Labor Party and its problems that one finds anybody on the other side even mentioning such a matter. Much progress has been made over the past years in the area of children's services. I have just been mentioning to the Minister many areas in which Queensland has been able to help in this regard. I commend the Minister and his officers on the work they are doing for the care of children. That is what I have been mentioning and I do not see that there are any difficulties and uncertainties. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the business of the day be called on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know I am quite out of order. Some questions were asked during the debate. I have a note on child care for disabled children.
—Order! Senator Chaney, are you seeking leave to make a statement?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chaney

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I seek leave simply to have a one-page document on disabled children and the child care available to them incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Disabled children are a priority need group under the Children's Services Program. A large number of projects dealing with the needs of disabled children and their families have been funded. It is not possible to estimate accurately expenditure on these services since they are not always identified as separate components. However an approximate estimate suggests that some 90 services over the last three to four years have received in the vicinity of $3m. Examples of these projects include;
an art project for the mentally retarded
multifunctional centres for children with learning difficulties, including occasional and afterschool care
a grant to Technical Aid to the Disabled
grants to the States to stimulate projects for IYDP
