In addition a condition of the block grants to the States for pre-schools is that they cater for speical need groups, including disabled children.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Judges' Pensions Act 1968, which replaced similar Acts of 1948, 1956, 1958 and 1961, provides for pensions to be payable to Federal judges and certain other judges for whom the Commonwealth is responsible. The 1981-82 estimate for these pensions is $1.14m, not in itself a large sum. Nonetheless some quite important questions of principle are raised by this amending Bill. The judges covered by the legislation are either judges or former judges of the following courts: The High Court of Australia; the Federal Court of Australia; presidential members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; presidential members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and certain other Commonwealth tribunals; judges of the Family Court of Australia; judges of the Australian Capital Territory and other Territory Supreme Courts; and also Papua New Guinea Supreme Court judges if appointed before 1 December 1973. Of those courts or bodies which are no longer in operation or in full operation, the scope of the legislation also extends to the Australian Industrial Court; the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration; and the Federal Court of Bankruptcy.

SPEECH.PARA: The object of the Bill before us is to clear up various anomalies and to make various improvements in the administration of, and entitlements under, the judicial pensions scheme and, in particular, to introduce a pro rata entitlement for judges who retire from their positions after less than 10 years in office. There is a preliminary consideration which needs to be adverted to right at the outset in considering the terms of this Bill, although it is a matter which has continued without change in the text of this Bill. That underlying matter is the non-contributory nature of the present judicial pensions scheme-a characteristic, it must be acknowledged at the outset, however, that is shared with the pensions schemes for judges in all the States of this country as well as, of course, in a good deal of the private sector. As the system operates at the moment judges do not pay any contribution at all for the very substantial pensions they receive upon retirement.

The situation at present is that a judge who retires after serving for not less than 10 years is entitled to a pension equal to 60 per cent of what is described in the Bill as the 'appropriate current judicial salary' which, in most cases, is the salary which he or she would have received if he or she had not retired. That is obviously a very generous provision. It is all the more generous because, obviously, of its non-contributory nature. As the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) admitted in his second reading speech, a non-contributory pension scheme is unusual in public employment, although it is not at all unusual in the private sector. Nonetheless, the Attorney made a quite spirited defence-I suppose that would be putting it rather strongly for the Attorney; of the non-contributory nature of the pension by reference to comparisons with the private sector and also by reference to two points of view, which he described as principle and pragmatic considerations, concerned with the political and financial independence respectively of the judiciary.

In essence, the first point made by the Attorney goes to the question of the continued independence of the judiciary and its immunity from temptation by way of financial inducements in the form of ex gratia payments from the Executive upon retirement or, as is increasingly common, the prospect of having part time jobs to do under the patronage of the Executive after retirement. The idea is that, if we can provide sufficiently well and comfortably for judges upon their retirement, to that extent we are contributing to the maintenance of the integrity and independence of the judiciary from Executive blandishments of this kind. That is a familiar and ancient justification; it remains to be seen whether it stands up in present day circumstances.

The other more practical inducement for the non-contributory and generous pension schemes provided for judges that was referred to by the Attorney is the one that judges, by and large, were earning prior to their elevation to the Bench very substantial incomes in their professional careers at the Bar-very often two, three, four or more times the income they can expect to get while on the Bench. Hitherto, I suppose, it has been thought that the honour and glory associated with appointment to judicial office did much to compensate for that financial disadvantage by way of income, but perhaps the slings and arrows that are increasingly being meted out to judicial officers make the honour, not to mention the glory, rather less obvious than it used to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes even in this Parliament.

—Indeed, it has been known to happen even in this Parliament. It is a welcome development that judges are less immune from criticism, and fairly robust criticism on occasions, as far as their judicial performance is concerned. That is a view I have always adopted. But one of the considerations associated with that is that it is necessary to offer something by way of inducement-perhaps increasingly these days-for judges to accept judicial office; maybe not much by way of inducement when one talks about the High Court and the higher reaches of the Federal Court and so on but, given the large number of Federal judicial appointments now being made, it is arguably necessary to be able to offer some financial compensation for the income loss that will usually be experienced.

SPEECH.PARA: Traditionally it has been argued, reasonably plausibly, that it is necessary in this context to make very generous provision for judicial pensions. But notwithstanding the Attorney's defence of the status quo by arguments along these lines, he states:

. . . I propose to give some thought to the question whether there should be a change in the basis of the Judges' pensions scheme by making pension rights depend in part upon a contribution being made by the Judges from their salaries.

That, in the Attorney's mind, is something for the future. However, we of the Opposition are inclined to believe that that is a subject which ought to be of concern here and now, in the present. Regrettably, there is nothing in this Bill to deal in any way with this rather fundamental issue about the basis of the whole pension scheme in question. We believe there should be such a provision and that does seem to be a view which we share on this occasion with the Australian Democrats, not to mention Don Cameron and one or two other fairly lively dissidents in the Government's ranks on this issue, as demonstrated in the House of Representatives debate a few days ago. We of the Australian Labor Party do not believe that it is really possible to draft a contributory pension scheme for judges, or anybody else, on the run, particularly in the period of less than a week we have had to deal with this Bill since its introduction, although it seems that such was, at least at one stage, an aspiration contemplated by the Australian Democrats. We note that they are proposing to circulate for discussion a suggested contributory pension scheme based on the not ungenerous scheme that we have for ourselves as parliamentarians. But rather than endeavouring to deal in this debate or in any other debate on this legislation with the kinds of amendments that might be necessary to get a rational and acceptable pension scheme introduced on a contributory basis, we believe that the sensible way through this issue-this has been discussed between all the parties in this chamber-is to put on record a second reading amendment expressing the Senate's support for a serious investigation of a contributory basis for such a pension scheme in the future. Such a second reading amendment will be formally moved later in this debate by Senator Haines and I indicate now that the Opposition will support it for the reasons I have mentioned.

I turn now to the matters specifically raised in this Bill. There are four which require comment. The first is the proposed new pro rata provision, the second is the change in the salary reference points by which the pensions are calculated, the third is the new provision made for the children of judges and the final one is the question of appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The question of pro rata pensions is the one that engendered all the excitement when this matter was debated in the other place. The provision made in the Bill which is before the Senate is for judges who retire after a period of less than 10 years in the job but after serving for not less than six years to get a pro rata entitlement of the pension that they would otherwise get, calculated on the basis of 0.5 per cent of current salary for each completed month they have been in office up to a maximum of 60 per cent of that salary. The reason for the introduction of a pro rata provision of this kind in the legislation is related to the introduction, following the 1977 constitutional amendment, of a compulsory retiring age for Federal judges-70 years in the case of High Court judges and all other Federal judges unless the Parliament otherwise provides. The Parliament has otherwise provided in the case of Family Court judges, for whom the retiring age is now 65 years, and for presidential members of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for whom, equally, there is an age of 65 years now set.

There were judges who, by virtue of this new compulsory retiring age provision, would have missed out on a pension had the existing 10 years threshold rules continued to operate-notably Mr Justice McGregor of the Withers royal commission fame and Mr Justice Gibson of the Family Court. Representations were made in respect of these two gentlemen by Mr Lionel Bowen of the Labor Party, and it is in response to those representations that the Government, although dragging its heels, appears primarily to have responded in the initial draft of this Bill, the one introduced into the House of Representatives, which set a seven-year threshold for the entitlement to the pro rata pension in question, being a period sufficient to accommodate the two judges I have mentioned who were thought, apparently, to be the only ones affected by the introduction of the new compulsory retiring age. The trouble was however, that one judge was left out of contemplation. That was poor old Mr Justice Marks of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission who needed a six-year threshold period to be set in order for him to be covered if he was to collect a pension before he was compulsorily retired under the new provisions. This ever-obliging Government responded in the House of Representatives with an amendment reducing the threshold period from seven years to six years in order to accommodate Mr Justice Marks. That amendment was the subject of a good deal of criticism in the debate which occurred in the House of Representatives, both by the Opposition and also by individual government members, particularly Mr Don Cameron.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was the only one who spoke.

—I think he was the only one who spoke. Certainly he was the only one who spoke critically on the Government side, senator. Let me make it clear, however, that the Opposition reaction in the House of Representatives to the Government's amendment, which was rather sprung upon our members in that House, was based on a belief that Mr Justice Marks's position may indeed have been the subject of an explicit promise made by Mr Street, the then Minister for Industrial Relations, at the time of Mr Justice Marks's appointment which, if indeed it were the case, would raise serious questions of ethics and principles of the kind which were adverted to by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith, Mr Lionel Bowen, in that chamber. But subsequent to Mr Bowen's contribution to that debate-
—No one would be silly enough to make promises about what Parliament might do.

—Not these days, and not in this chamber; I acknowledge that, Attorney. But subsequently Mr Bowen was informed by Mr Street, as indeed he then got up to tell the chamber, that Mr Street had, in his own words, made no such promise or no such deal with Mr Justice Marks, and as a result of that assurance which has been put on the record by Mr Street, we in the Opposition in the Senate where the issue is before us again for debate are not disposed to press the point, to press the opposition, that is, to the threshold now being set of six years rather than seven years. We have acknowledged, by virtue of the representations that we have publicly made on behalf of judges who missed out on pensions because of the introduction of the new compulsory retiring age, that there is nothing necessarily obnoxious about making particular legislative provision for specified individuals who find themselves on the receiving end of some disadvantage as a result of a change in public policy for good public policy reasons. There is no reason in principle against such an exercise, provided that there is some other independent justification for the provision in question.

SPEECH.PARA: We note in this respect that in all those States where there is provision for pro rata entitlement by judges to pensions for periods of service less than 10 years or some large equivalent thereof the most common provision is either five or six years service for people to become eligible for pensions. Against that sort of standard, which appears to be the norm in the States, the proposed six-year threshhold set in this legislation is not perhaps objectionable.

The next matter dealt with in the Bill is the question of the change in the salary reference points for the operation of the pension scheme, a matter dealt with by clause 3 of the Bill which makes certain amendments to the definition of 'appropriate current judicial salary'. Clause 3 (1) of the Bill makes appropriate changes to the titles of senior judges in Papua New Guinea in conformity with changes which have taken place in that country since independence. Obviously we make no objection to that essential updating exercise. Clause 3 (2), however, is rather closer to home insofar as it amends this same definition, that is, of 'appropriate current judicial salary' in section 4 of the principal Act, so as to base the pensions and pension entitlements which are presently based on the salaries payable in the Australian Industrial Court and the Federal Court of Bankruptcy on, now, salaries payable to judges of the Federal Court.

To that extent these changes are not opposed. They make perfectly sensible accommodations to take account of the transfer of functions of those former courts to the new Federal Court. Federal Court salaries will continue to increase under the control of the Remuneration Tribunal and it is appropriate that the continuing pensions should be linked to these salaries rather than to the salaries of courts which have either actually, or for all practical purposes virtually, disappeared. However, there is one particular point which I think should now be brought out when one is considering salary relativities between these various federal courts, new and old. In his second reading speech the Attorney says that these amendments:

. . . will also have the effect of restoring, for pension purposes, the relativity that existed until 1977 between Judges of the Australian Industrial Court and Presidential Members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

So far, so good. That in itself is reasonable enough. But what is not said is that there is now a different relativity, that which existed between the Family Court judges and the Federal Court judges in respect of their salaries, which has not been maintained. That, I believe, is the subject of quite legitimate grievance on the part of the Family Court judges.

In June 1976 the Government introduced a Remuneration and Allowances Amendment Bill in relation to which, in the course of the second reading speech, the then Minister for Administrative Services said:

The rates of salaries and allowances of judges of the Family Court, which are at present prescribed in the Family Law Act 1975, have fallen behind the rates for judges of other Federal courts of comparable status. This has occurred largely because the Family Law Bill occupied so much of the time of both Houses during its passage through Parliament last year.
A little further down the page the Minister said:

The rates proposed for the Chief Judge and for senior judges of the Family Court are equivalent to the rates for the Chief Judge and the judges respectively of the Australian Industrial Court. The proposed rate for ordinary judges of the Family Court-at which level the majority of judges are being appointed-is $5,000 less than that for senior judges.
The point was further made that:
It is important both to the judges already appointed and for the appointment of further judges that the salary increases provided for in this Bill be made, and made as soon as possible.

In 1976, then, a new catch-up relativity was established between the Chief Judge and senior judges of the Family Court and the Chief Judge and the judges respectively, of the Australian Industrial Court. What has happened since then is that these salary relativities have once again got substantially out of line. That is indicated by the 1981-82 Estimates. The Chief Judge of the Federal Court is now getting $73,000 whereas the Chief Judge of the Family Court is now getting $67,000. So the Federal Court, which has become the successor to the old Australian Industrial Court, has now leapt ahead in terms of the relative entitlement of the Family Court judges. The senior judges of the Family Court are getting $59,000 compared with ordinary judges of the Federal Court who get $67,000. Ordinary judges of the Family Court are getting $55,000 compared with an equivalent notional figure for the Federal Court of $62,000. That, I think is a matter that does and ought to cause some concern.

The Attorney, in his response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, was in fact full of praise for the judges of the Family Court. He said, with a great deal of enthusiasm:

The Judges of that Court have been selected, not only for their expertise in family law, but also for their suitability as judges in the very sensitive area in which they work. It is regrettable that so many people seem to misunderstand and devalue that work.

If he is serious about the problem that is being felt in some quarters of a devaluation in the status of Family Court judges, in the view of the Opposition and certainly in my own view, he ought to do something to restore the relativities between Family Court judges and other Federal Court judges.

It is only by that means, given the regrettable extent to which status, prestige and professional worth tend to be measured in dollars and cents, that within the legal profession at large and among the opinion makers of this community, the true worth and capacity of the Family Court judges will be recognised. A pension Bill is not an occasion on which to pursue this point beyond merely referring to it. Obviously, it will need to be the subject of further and different legislation, perhaps in the context of the Family Law Bills which are now before the Senate. But the existence before us now of a pension Bill based, as the pensions in it are, upon salaries set at the Federal Court level, is an occasion to draw attention to that particular relativity problem, which I fear has been rather too long neglected.

The remaining matters dealt with in the Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill can be much more briskly disposed of. The next matter concerns the provision made for the children of judges in the event, in the first place, that a particular judge dies or retires. Under the present Act, the widow, or widower, as the case may be, receives an actual sum of $208 per annum or $4 a week in respect of each eligible child-an eligible child being a child under the age of 16 or a dependent student up to the age of 25. The dollar figure and the Bill, in respect of the entitlement of those children, substitutes for that dollar figure a percentage of the pension that would have been payable to the deceased judge had he lived. This represents a reasonable improvement. Although the percentages in question-12 1/2 per cent for one eligible child, 25 per cent for two eligible children and 37 1/2 per cent for three or more eligible children-of the pension otherwise payable are undoubtedly generous both by Public Service pension standards and general pension standards, they are not out of line with the reasonable expectations of high level professionals of the kind that we are talking about.

The other matter provided for, as far as judicial pensions are concerned, in respect of children concerns the children of deceased judges, in situations where there is no surviving spouse. Again, the dollar figures provided in the 1968 legislation have become devalued and outdated by the passage of inflationary time, especially in the last five years, when inflation has continued unabated despite all the protestations and professed intentions of this Government to the contrary. Under those circumstances, the dollar figures are manifestly inadequate. The percentages proposed-45 per cent for one eligible child, ranging up to a full 100 per cent-of the pension that would be payable where there are four or more eligible children seem to the Opposition to be quite reasonable, particularly insofar as they parallel exactly the Public Service orphan pensions which prevail elsewhere.

The final matter, with which I can deal in a sentence or so, relates to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. A welcome provision has been inserted to ensure that application for review of pension decisions may be made under a number of heads to that Tribunal.

The key question which emerges from all these miscellaneous and often detailed and complex provisions is the basic underlying question whether judges, alone in the public sector, should continue to receive non-contributory pensions. On that score, I have made clear the view of the Opposition that times have changed and that the justifications advanced in the past have not the same force and credibility that traditionally, perhaps, they have seemed to possess. On this matter, as we have indicated, the Labor Party will support the second reading amendment that will be moved formally by the Australian Democrats after the suspension of the sitting for dinner.

On all the other matters dealt with in the Bill some of which have been controversial in other places, our position is to accept the terms of the Bill as they are now before us and not to oppose them now or at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in rising to support the Government on this Bill. I would like to say a few words in line with the thoughts of Senator Evans. This Bill deals with the provision of superannuation or, more accurately, the payment of a pension to judges employed by the Commonwealth. My concern is, firstly, one for equity within the community-that people who are employed in the public sector should have equivalent status in the eyes of the Commonwealth with its employees. Secondly, and more importantly, my concern is that people in private industry who provide the backbone of the economic development and strength of this country should have the opportunity to provide for themselves by an adequate superannuation fund. I believe that people should be encouraged to provide for their own retirement and needs. I do not believe that it is the duty of the Government to provide for everyone in the community. It is far more effective and economical if such provision is made by people during their working lives. Indeed, that is the philosophy of the party that I represent.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to this Bill, we are not discussing the degree of remuneration that Federal judges enjoy. By and large it is fair enough and is subject to review by various remuneration tribunals on an annual basis. I must say in passing that I am always amused by the great seriousness with which the legal profession takes the matter of its remuneration, which it seems to think puts it at a level that is above that of anyone else in the community. My mind goes back to the four tortuous years that I spent learning French as a schoolboy. One of the fables that we used to translate was that of La Fontaine about the oyster. Two Frenchmen were walking along a beach and found an oyster. They had a great argument over who had found it and eventually submitted it to arbitration. The judge ruled in favour of himself and ate the oyster. I rather think that, where salaries and conditions are concerned, times have not changed much for the legal profession.

The point that interests me is the non-contributory nature of the scheme. That is why I described it as a pension. It is not a superannuation scheme at all because the generally accepted definition of such a scheme is that you provide some of your salary towards it. When we had only four judges employed by the Commonwealth, it was probably fair enough that judges made no contribution to such a scheme; but nowadays, when they are adequately rewarded, it is a different matter. I support completely the view that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) expressed in his second reading speech when he said:

The independence of the judiciary from the parties to litigation is absolutely fundamental. It is of the utmost importance that a Judge should not, by reason of financial inducement or financial pressure, be thought to be in a position where he may be influenced by a particular party to litigation . . .

I support that statement without reservation but believe that, with the present level of judges' remuneration, and in the light of current community attitudes, it is quite reasonable to expect judges to support their own superannuation scheme by making some contribution from their salaries. Indeed, I am heartened by that part of the second reading speech of the Minister in which, recognising this, he says:

Nevertheless, I propose to give some thought to the question whether there should be a change in the basis of the Judge's pensions scheme by making pension rights depend in part upon a contribution being made by the Judges from their salaries.

I would like to add a little reinforcement to the Attorney-General's thinking on this point. The fact that in most States judges make no contribution at all to their superannuation scheme is a complete irrelevance. We are the Commonwealth and can decide what terms we set. We have subtle ways, I would imagine, through the income tax law and so on, of influencing the States. I would think that there would be ways of getting over the superannuation scheme of the States without too much trouble.

One of the exceptional terms of the Bill relates to the widows and children of judges. They deal with a point of very real importance. As a father of four children I think about what would happen to them if something happened to me. It seems to me that the Bill has gone a little astray in perspective in this respect.

We are told that people who earn very high salaries at the Bar have to take a cut in salary if they become judges. It is argued that their families have to be provided for in the event of their death. That is fair enough, but let us think about what would happen if they died when they were at the Bar. I think the situation in that case would probably be worse in that the superannuation schemes that are available to them are not as good as the superannuation scheme that would be available to them if they were in Commonwealth employment.

I would like to move on very briefly to the subject of private superannuation schemes in this country because I think this is an area of great concern. We need to allow the private sector to provide for itself. However, at present it is quite simply not able to do so under the income tax law. It is not possible for people working in the private sector to provide adequately for their retirement. The starting point in cleaning up this matter is the income tax legislation. However, Parliament has a responsibility to look at the superannuation schemes that apply to politicians and members of the Public Service. I believe that parliamentary superannuation schemes should be better than those available to public servants or people in private industry. We want people who have established themselves in their own profession to come into this Parliament. Ideally they should come here in mid-life and contribute a number of years to the service of this nation. A career in politics is one of the most unpredictable careers on earth. All of us who come here accept that, wide-eyed and fully conscious of the risks we take. I do not think that one can make a case that we should participate in precisely the same superannuation schemes that are available to the rest of the members of the community who serve a lifetime. This would not be appropriate in view of the risks involved and the calibre of the people we want to attract.

I think that in establishing a superannuation scheme which is better than any other scheme we should define the terms by which it is better. We should be able to codify or quantify how much better we think that scheme should be. This information should be open to public perusal. There should not be any concern in the eyes of members of the public as to the formula that led to the derivation of that scheme. Once we have put our house in order we can look at schemes in the public sector which I think by and large are far too generous. They are schemes which private industry simply cannot match. I do not believe that the types of pension and superannuation schemes that apply to State and Federal public servants and to officers of public and statutory authorities could be funded by private enterprise. I do not think these schemes have been actuarially costed. This is one of the great nightmares that lie ahead for future Federal and State Treasurers. I do not propose to go into this matter in great detail at present. However, I think it is wrong that we legislate in such a way that the private sector cannot provide for itself in the way that the public sector can. I have much pleasure in supporting this Bill.
Sitting suspended from 5.58 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating the Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill 1981. As Senator Evans has already kindly foreshadowed, it is my intention to move an amendment to the motion that this Bill be now read a second time. In fact, I take this opportunity immediately to move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add:
', but the Senate is of the opinion that the establishment of a contributory superannuation scheme for Judges should be investigated'.

I have taken this route to indicate the Australian Democrats attitude to the way in which the pension scheme for judges should operate because it is tidier and less contentious than moving a more positive amendment at the Committee stage, particularly as a wide range of options could apply to judges' pensions. At an appropriate time during the rest of my comments I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an amendment which has been suggested by the Democrats and which has been circulated for discussion purposes.

I would like to make a few remarks about the history of this Bill. It has, as everyone is aware, attracted a lot of publicity in the last few days apparently, it would seem, because certain members of the Opposition in the lower House have a tendency to run off at the mouth before checking on their facts. When they have the facts presented to them, they are in the unfortunate predicament of having to resile from some of their comments. That is a habit that members of the Australian Labor Party appear to be getting themselves into lately. It is unfortunate that in doing so they attracted some unnecessary and undue publicity for one particular judge. I would hate to think that they did this with any malice intended. It is unfortunate that initially the Government made an error by inserting the word 'seven' instead of 'six' in the relevant clause of the Bill. It was even more unfortunate that the Opposition in the lower House turned this into some sort of vendetta against Mr Justice Marks. It has, however, had one interesting and fairly useful result, and that is that the whole matter of judges' pensions, and for that matter other peoples pensions, has raised before the public a number of questions about anomalies and so on relating to judges' pensions and the other prerequisites of their office, particularly in relation to Federal judges vis-a-vis State judges.

At this point I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which sets out relative details of the pension schemes for judges which operate in the various States. I have shown this table to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). He has no objection to its incorporation.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I appreciate the courtesy of the Senate. This table indicates the discrepancies that exist in the operation of the schemes from State to State and from State to the Federal Government in respect of the qualifying period; the age of retirement or resignation; whether there is any contribution towards the scheme; and other details.
—There is practically no contribution, is there?

—No. The only State in which there is any contribution of any real sort appears to be Tasmania where the contribution is 5 per cent under the Judges' Contributory Pensions Act which gives a pension of 50 per cent on retirement. It would seem appropriate in view of the other sorts of pensions-I say this having listened to Senator MacGibbon argue otherwise-that the pension schemes for judges be brought into line, in some way if possible, with the pension schemes which apply to everybody else. I said earlier that this legislation had attracted a good deal of attention, and indeed it has, from the Premier of Queensland down or up depending on your view of where the president of Queensland-the Premier of Queensland, although I dare say he would like to be a president-is on the social scale. On the 17th of this month the Australian carried a story in which it was said that the Premier of Queensland was critical of this legislation. But I have had other indications of disquiet about this from amongst the community. I would like to read a very brief letter on the matter from an ordinary pensioner.
—What contribution do they make to their pensions?

—This pensioner seems to believe, from other correspondence I have had from him, that in the tax he has been paying over the last 70-odd years he has made a reasonable contribution to general revenue. The pensioner writes:

SPEECH.PARA: I attach a cutting from today's Advertiser. You will remember that Senator Chaney's reply to me--
Obviously there was some previous correspondence engaged in with Senator Chaney-
included two objections to my request to amend the regulation to give the over 70s increases-as ordinary pensioners get.
(1) He said it would 'disadvantage the ordinary pensioners'.
(2) In any case it was not desirable to spend from limited funds to increase pensions of those 'well off'.
You may consider his double standard worth using on behalf of we people whose standards although above the ordinary pensioners are well below those of judges and the like.

The point this pensioner is making is that there appears to be one standard for 'ordinary people' and another for a higher class of people. I would also like to refer to another discrepancy which has occurred in the last week, and that is the inconsistency on the part of both the Government and the Opposition in their attitudes to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Amendment Bill which was before the Senate last Wednesday night. That night the Australian Labor Party moved an amendment to cover special cases. The Attorney then said that Senator Mason's argument that you should not move for special case consideration for superannuation purposes was put at least as well as he could put it, or words to that effect. Yet the very next morning the Government introduced what was apparently a piece of special case legislation and the Opposition opposed it. It would appear that in this instance the inconsistencies are anywhere but with my party.

This legislation has caused a great deal of interest because, as I said, it does point out the anomalies that exist amongst pension schemes for judges and those schemes which apply to everybody else. I agree that the courts need the best possible judges, although even when they get them they never seem to be able to agree amongst themselves. Sometimes they are forced to take a drop in salary. Nevertheless we do not believe that judges or for that matter their lesser brethren, lawyers, should receive any special consideration. Unlike the profession itself I do not share the view that its members are second only to God in their position in society and then only by a very small margin.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is doctors.

—No. One must argue that doctors come third. I agree by a very small margin, but nevertheless they come third. I believe it is valuable to have some sort of community discussion. It is for this reason that we have concentrated our approach, as has every other speaker, on looking at whether it is feasible and whether it is in fact desirable for judges to participate in some sort of contributory superannuation scheme. In fact, that is the purpose of the amendment I have moved to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time. In doing this I have, as I said earlier, circulated for discussion purposes only details of a possible way of achieving it; that is, to consider judges, whose salaries are set by the same tribunal as those of members of parliament, in the same light as members of parliament when it comes to organising their superannuation scheme. The circulated document which honourable senators have before them tonight sets out a suggested scheme working on just that basis. It argues that the contribution rate of a judge who has held office for less than 10 years should be 11 1/2 per cent of the monthly amount of his salary, which is, in fact, what members of parliament contribute towards their own not ungenerous scheme, and that the contribution rate of a judge who has held office for more than 10 years should drop to 5 3/4 per cent of the monthly amount of his salary. Again, that is consistent with the varying amounts that members of parliament contribute according to the years they have been in office. I seek leave to incorporate the distributed document in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
JUDGES' PENSIONS AMENDMENT BILL 1981
Amendment suggested by the Australian Democrats
Page 7, after clause 13, insert the following clause:
''14. The Principal Act is amended by inserting after section 18 the following sections:
Contributions
'19. (1) Each Judge to whom this section applies shall pay contributions to the Commonwealth, as follows:
(a) where that Judge has held the office of Judge for less than 10 years-at the rate per month of 11 1/2 per cent of the monthly amount of his salary;
(b) where that Judge has held the office of Judge for more than 10 years-at the rate per month of 5 3/4 per cent of the monthly amount of his salary.
(2) For the purposes of sub-section (1), the monthly amount of a Judge's salary shall be deemed to be one-twelfth of the annual amount of that salary.

(3) The contributions payable under this section shall be deducted from payments of salary made to a Judge, and each deduction shall, so far as practicable, be made in respect of the same period as that in respect of which the payment is made.
(4) Amounts so deducted shall be paid to the Commonwealth.
(5) In this section, ''month'' means one of the 12 months of the year.
(6) This section applies to a Judge appointed to the office of Judge after the commencement of the Judges' Pensions Amendment Act 1981.

'20. Where a Judge who ceases to hold the office of Judge is not eligible to be paid a pension in accordance with this Act, there shall be payable to him the sum of any contributions paid by him to the Commonwealth in accordance with section 19 and an amount equal to two and one third times such contributions.'.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really would have hated to have had to read out the legalese in this document.
—It would have been worth listening to it.

—I am sure it would have been, since tonight I seem to be challenging Senator Evans for the position of talker of the year-a not inconsiderable challenge. Furthermore, since there is within the parliamentary superannuation scheme provision for certain moneys to be paid to a member of parliament if, for one reason or another, he does not see out the prescribed period before being entitled to a pension, I have included in this suggested amendment something similar for judges; that is:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a judge who ceases to hold the office of judge is not eligible to be paid a pension in accordance with this Act, there shall be payable to him the sum of any contributions paid by him to the Commonwealth in accordance with section 19 and an amount equal to two and one third times such contributions.

The same provision applies to a member of parliament who involuntarily leaves the service, if I can put it that way, before his or her time for getting a pension has arrived. However, I stress that this is only a suggestion. There must be other ways of approaching the task of arriving at some legislation that will make the judges' pension scheme a contributory one. It should also be possible to compare judges with senior public servants or, if the Government sees fit, to come up with some unique piece of legislation pertaining only to judges. However, it would seem appropriate to me that it be based on some existing precedent. I have selected one of those precedents.

There is no intention on the part of the Australian Democrats to oppose the amendment by the Government to lower the qualifying period for pro rata pensions from seven years to six years. I accept, as the Opposition now does, that it was not introduced specifically to pay off or satisfy a promise to a particular judge, that it was a genuine mistake on the part of the Federal Government. I am pleased to know that it is prepared to admit that it makes mistakes since it has a penchant for directing such accusations at everybody else-my party in particular. It is pleasing to me to know that we are all human and that in fact the Government is more human than others in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Frequently.

—Yes, frequently more human than others; conscienceless but more human. Having made those few remarks about the Bill, I do not want to launch into what would be only a repetition of Senator Evans's definitive statement about the Bill-'definitive' being in this instance a euphemism for long-winded, as usual.
—The romance is starting to waver.

—Senator, if I wanted to indulge in that sort of dalliance there are other places I could start, and I am not implying that you are it. Levity aside, bearing in mind that this is a grave piece of legislation, having moved, as an amendment to the second reading motion, that the Senate is of the opinion that the establishment of a contributory superannuation scheme for judges should be investigated, I make the point that we are quite content with the Bill as it stands. I commend this amendment and our circulated document to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill.
—And our amendment.
—I will get to your amendment, Senator Haines; do not be too hasty. I do not intend to do anything nasty about your amendment, either. We have heard three interesting speeches tonight.
—What sort of speeches?
—Order!

—Mr Deputy President, I think I can manage to keep myself together. I would not agree with what Senator Haines said about Senator Evans making a long-winded speech tonight. In fact, I thought his speech was relatively to the point and was very moderate. I am sorry to see the lack of a unity ticket between the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party spreading even to the Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill. Nevertheless, I will say a few words about the argument raised because I think some ought to be replied to.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans pointed out at the beginning of this debate that underlying the debate was some suggestion in regard to the non-contributory nature of judges' pensions. In fact, that has crept into the argument publicly and in respect of the debate that has taken place in both chambers. But, of course, this Bill is not about that. Non-contributory pensions have been in existence for some time. As is pointed out in the document which Senator Haines incorporated in Hansard tonight, there are non-contributory judges' pensions in practically all the States of Australia. That has been the tradition in regard to judicial pensions for some considerable time. My colleague Senator MacGibbon expressed the view that perhaps we should influence the States to change their view. I am amazed at the audacity of Senator MacGibbon, who comes from Queensland, in suggesting that the Commonwealth could persuade the State of Queensland to change its legislation in regard to its judges. I think we have to accept that the principle of non-contributory judges' pensions has been adopted for many years. I recognise that the Attorney-General has said that he will give some thought to the possibility of such pensions being made contributory. I will express some arguments as to why this should not be so. I certainly agree that it is a matter that ought to be looked at.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even with the present compulsory retirement age, you still maintain it should not be contributory?

—I say even more strongly with the compulsory retirement age. Judges are different from people from most other walks of life. Persons who become Federal judges are generally persons who have been barristers for some years, who have established substantial practices in many cases, and who in the latter part of their professional lives become judges. They are not in the situation that one finds with many people in so many other walks of life who are for many years contributing to a contributory scheme. In this case judges will be expected to contribute for a much lesser period. The relative age at which people become judges is one reason. There is a lesser period in which they may serve, as we have introduced a compulsory retirement age of 70 years for most Federal judges and 65 years in the case of judges of the Family Court of Australia. There is a limited period in which judges will be expected to contribute either a substantial amount or a nominal amount. If the amount is nominal there is no reason why such a provision should be brought in.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, we know that, if the Commonwealth is to obtain the services of judges of considerable eminence in their profession, it must get people who will give up a great deal of their practice and present income to become judges. Therefore, I think it is necessary that the judges be paid an equivalently reasonably high salary. To expect them now to give back part of that salary by way of the contribution suggested will, I think, make it more difficult for people to be persuaded to go on to the Bench. It is a fact that there is competition between the Commonwealth and the States to retain the best calibre for the Bench. In my opinion the Commonwealth ought to have the best calibre. Quite often in recent years we have seen that State judges are paid more than Commonwealth judges. I am not sure the difference is so accentuated at present, but until recent years the Chief Justice of Queensland was, I think, receiving more than the Chief Justice of Australia. The judges of Queensland are generally paid at a much higher rate than Federal judges.

Therefore, it is natural that people will not very often be persuaded to leave their residences in a State where their friends, families and associations are, to go interstate, either to a court or a position that requires them to travel and where they will find the conditions are not so pleasant. Consequently, if the Commonwealth is to compete in obtaining the services of the best and most qualified lawyers in this country for the Bench, it must take into account the comparison of the conditions between the States. If all the States except Tasmania are in the process of providing non-contributory pensions, it would make things very difficult if the Commonwealth were to change its mind on this and force a contribution from judges. These are the arguments. By all means let us have a look at the whole situation, but I will take a great deal of convincing before I am persuaded that the Commonwealth ought to change its present conditions for judges.

There was not very much criticism, either in Senator Evans's speech or in any other debate in this chamber, of the provision in regard to the six years pro rata. In another place there has been some criticism of this provision by one of our more vocal back benchers and by the Labor spokesman on this matter. To my mind the provision is a reasonable one. It is true that the position of one judge, Mr Justice Marks-who I understand is a very popular and able judge and who is very much welcome to the Bench-was not included in the first provision and so the period was reduced to six years. But, as honourable senators know, most of the States have a five-year provision; so it is not as though this is a matter of considerable importance. I think it important that the Government acknowledged that there had been an oversight in regard to that particular judge and that it should make the provision that covers him also in these ranks. This is certainly the best way of doing it. A provision ought to be inserted in the statute. It should not be done, as I suppose it could have been, by some ex gratia payment or some other means whereby one could have made some contribution to take into account the situation. That is a very undesirable way to deal with the financial position of judges in this country. It should be done in the statutes of the country and not by ex gratia payments on the part of governments.

We must recognise the fact that we have recently imposed the restriction on judges of a younger retiring age. As one who advocated that action and was glad to see it come into operation, I note that it has the effect, particularly in regard to the Family Court, that in the early years of the operation of that court it has not been so easy, with the new judicial system and the new system of family law operating, to obtain the services of people greatly experienced in that area unless one selects some judges who are perhaps a little older than the average age of appointment. There have been cases where lawyers nearer the end of their careers have been appointed to that Bench. This step is welcomed. It has added to the field from which the Attorney-General has been able to appoint judges. But, at the same time, we should ensure, by the passage of this legislation, that such judges are not dealt with unjustly by the Commonwealth.

In the course of his speech, Senator Evans referred to the relativities between the salaries of judges, one of the aspects dealt with in this Bill. The salaries of New Guinea judges have been linked to those of a judge of the Federal Court of Australia. That comparison will be made. Senator Evans pointed out that the Family Court judges have not yet been treated on the same basis. I hope that will happen. Legislation amending the Family Law Act is yet to be debated in this Parliament. I would be surprised if, in the course of debating that legislation, this anomoly were not satisfactorily resolved. I think it is a matter of injustice at present that the basis on which Family Court judges salaries are determined is salaries of judges of the Australian Industrial Court, a court which is going out of existence, and not the Federal Court of Australia which has been brought in to replace it.

I do not want to say very much about what my colleague Senator MacGibbon said. He was making a case in respect of the contributory nature of pensions. Of course, this is a pension. It is described as a pension and that is an argument which I think we will hear more of at another time. I am pleased that Senator Haines incorporated the table which sets out the position in respect of judges in the States. I believe that she is right to point out that there should be no invidious distinction dealing with an individual judge. I think it is clear now that this Parliament will not do that. I suggest to Senator Haines that this Bill is not about the contribution or otherwise that is made. That is not the subject at this time. I believe that the various provisions that are made in this Bill are ones that desirably improve the situation of judges' pensions. A number of the provisions are well overdue and it is desirable that they should be incorporated now in the substantial legislation. For these reasons, I strongly support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating proposals to amend the Judges' Pensions Amendment Act 1968, which I introduced into the Senate and which were passed in the House of Representatives a few days ago. I thank the Senate for the support which it, from all sides, has indicated for the measures that are contained in the Judges' Pensions Amendment Bill 1981. Any legislation dealing with judges is of very great importance and the Parliament should always give such measures very close attention. Obviously I am pleased that the Parliament has done so on this occasion, even though I believe that some of the remarks that have been made, particularly in another place, in relation to this measure have been rather unfortunate, if not misplaced. However, I will say one or two things about that in my remarks. Certainly the level of debate in this chamber, as we normally expect to find, has been of a greatly superior nature to that in the other place. That is how it should be. I am sorry that any parliamentary debate in either chamber on a subject of such importance should fall below the standards set-unfortunately they sometimes do-by the Senate this afternoon and this evening.
—Senate chauvinist.

—It might even have been implicit in Senator Evans's own remarks that he was a little regretful of the way the matter was dealt with in the other place. Although this measure in compass is a small one, it is certainly important. The role of the judiciary in our community is a vital one. It is recognised by the Constitution as having equal status with the Parliament and the Executive. As such, it has its own constitutional status. Senator Haines had something to say about the pecking order in the community.
—From God down.

—Without having anything to say about the deity, doctors or lawyers, the fact is that Australians do not accord very much honour to anybody. That has a lot to do with the character of Australians, but there is a very widespread respect for the integrity and the honour of our judiciary and judges. I think a gallup poll which was conducted on this subject indicated that Australians have the highest regard for the judiciary and our judges.
—Is that the one that recorded that members of parliament are the lowest?

—I regret to say that I think members of parliament are well below that. I was a little surprised to find that Cabinet Ministers were a little higher in the pecking order than I expected them to be, but that is by the way. The fact is-I am trying to deal with the matter seriously-that both Federal and State judges in Australia are held in very high esteem. It is pleasing that they should be because the work they do and the role they play in the community is of the greatest importance. That is why I say that any subject which is dealt with in this chamber and which involves aspects of the judiciary or terms of service is of great importance.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to describe this measure again. The details have been set out in my second reading speech and have been repeated to a large extent by Senator Evans in his speech. However, I do want to emphasise-I do not know whether this came across clearly-that the proposal for a pro rata pension which is contained in the legislation applies only where a judge is required to retire compulsorily before he or she has served a period of 10 years. This follows the constitutional amendment of 1977 which requires judges of the Federal Court and the High Court of Australia to retire at 70 years of age and judges of the Family Court of Australia to retire at 65 years. As a result of parliamentary enactment unrelated to the constitution, the deputy presidents-that is, the judicial members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-are also required to retire at 65 years.

The judges' pension scheme has been based, as indeed was the Public Service pension scheme, on a minimum of 10 years' service. Judges will still have to serve 10 years before qualifying for a pension. Indeed, they have to be over 60 years of age before they can qualify except in one case which this Bill proposes, that is, where they are forced to retire at 70 years as a result of constitutional amendment, they will be entitled to a pro rata pension provided they have served for six years. I do not think that this provision came out clearly in the debate, high though the level of the debate has been. I want to reiterate that the provision is applied only when judges are compulsorily retired before they have been able to serve the 10 years.

We have heard a bit of potted history about this measure, but I am afraid that it has not been entirely accurate. Certainly, Senator Evans's contribution to the history of the matter was totally inaccurate. I do not blame him for that because it arose out of some outlandish claims made by his opposite number in the House of Representatives, Mr Lionel Bowen, who claimed that he was the first person to raise the matter of pro rata pensions which he did, he said, in 1979. I do not doubt that he did. But the fact is, as I explained in the Senate on 8 March 1979 in answer to a question from former Senator Cavanagh, that in February 1978 the Government had decided upon certain amendments to the Judges' Pensions Act, which included the proposal for the pro rata pension.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why has it taken you three years to introduce it?

—As is revealed in this answer, I indicated in October 1977, when I offered Mr Justice McGregor an appointment to the Federal Court, that I believed this was a necessary result of the constitutional amendment which had been passed in July 1977. Those proposals were, in fact, formulated by me in 1978 and were similar to the State schemes. I proposed that there would be a similar scheme to that which applies in the States where the qualifying period for a pro rata pension-this is the case in three States-is five years. It was always my view that we should be on all fours with the States and there should be a five-year minimum qualifying period. As was also revealed in the answer to the question, I did run, probably not surprisingly, into some political difficulties in getting that legislation into the Parliament. It is only this year that the matter has been reactivated. In view of the difficulties which had arisen earlier, I decided that it might perhaps mollify certain opponents of the measure if a longer qualifying period were selected. Seven years was thought to be adequate but then we ran into a problem, which has now become well known, in relation to one judge. The proposed period is now six years. However, I want to emphasise that in my opinion, and in conformity with the States, there is a very sound case for the period being five years, but that is by the way. I only mention that because the history of the matter has been raised here. I hope that has put the record straight.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans mentioned the question of relativities between judges of the Family Court, the Federal Court and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I can assure him and the Senate-Senator Missen also raised the matter-that this has given me a good deal of concern. I have taken up the matter with the Remuneration Tribunal in the last two years in the hope that the Tribunal might rectify the position. I believe the Family Court judges have a very sound case, particularly some of the senior judges who were appointed at the commencement of the Family Court. They were given very specific undertakings and accepted appointment on the basis that legislation would provide clear relativity.

It has been the policy of the Government that the remuneration of judges, as is the case with members of parliament, senior public servants and so on, should be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal and not by legislative fiat. Up until now I have been endeavouring to rectify the problem in accordance with that policy. But as we now are left with the problem, I realise that it will probably only be possible to rectify it by legislation. I hope-the Government has not yet made any firm decisions on the matter so I cannot announce them-that by the time we come to debate the Family Law Amendment Bill next year I will have some proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next year?

—The Bill will not be ready-if Senator Evans wants to debate it this year-as this part of it will not be ready until next year. I hope I will have some additional proposals to make in relation to this matter. Obviously, the majority of the Family Court judges would not be on par with the Federal Court judges. They never were. There have always been two categories of Family Court judges-the senior judges and the others. It was only the senior judges who had, at one time, relativity. I have been discussing this matter particularly with the Chief Judge. I have had discussions with other judges of the Court. I am well aware of the problem and I hope that next year I will have some proposals which will solve it. I think I have really covered all the matters regarding the Bill that I wanted to raise. However, Senator Haines on behalf of the Australian Democrats has moved an amendment stating:

SPEECH.PARA: ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the establishment of a contributory superannuation scheme for judges should be investigated.'

Senator Evans has indicated his support for that amendment and so has Senator MacGibbon who sits on this side. Indeed, Senator Missen has supported the investigation of the matter. I have already indicated in the second reading speech that I propose to look at the matter. It has been in other places and in another place before our debate took place today. I have certainly been giving the matter some thought. Indeed, I have, in fact, had some preliminary discussions about it with the Chief Judge of the Family Court quite recently. I have not pursued the matter with other judges as yet but I have certainly asked officers of my Department to investigate it immediately. I have no problem whatever in supporting, on behalf of the Government, the amendment Senator Haines has moved.

For the reasons I have given in the second reading speech I think there are a lot of arguments against a contributory scheme. I do not want to indicate for one minute that I will be readily accepting it. I think there are major arguments against it. I think there are major problems in its path, not the least of which is the Constitution. There is a very specific provision in the Constitution about judicial remuneration and there are limitations on the ability of the Parliament to diminish judicial remuneration.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could not apply to existing judges anyway.

—It could not apply to existing judges, but I think there are some other problems as well which I do not want to go into because I might be giving legal opinion on the subject. The position is that there are many difficulties and there are not many precedents for such a scheme. In fact, as Senator Haines has recognised, there is only the Tasmanian scheme in Australia. We want to look at what happens in Britain and the United States as well as in Australia. I propose to have the investigation and to put down a discussion paper in the Parliament as soon as it has been completed. We can then have a basis for public debate about the matter. A discussion paper may be helpful to any of the parties represented here which may want to take the matter further.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, in the first place, I guess the Government will have to decide whether it will support such a measure as a result of the investigation I will make. But ahead of any legislation I will make available the result of the investigation in the form of a discussion paper and table it in the Senate. As I have said, I am very pleased that the Senate has supported this measure in its entirety. I have been very pleased indeed with the serious approach the Senate has adopted on this measure. I hope it will have a speedy passage.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The primary objective of this Bill is to amend the Customs Act 1901 to introduce new provisions for the valuation of imported goods for Customs duty purposes. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill and I will spend only a few minutes explaining why. New valuation procedures contained in the Bill are designed to give effect to the agreement on the implementation of Article VII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. I simply hope that the Government, in attaching itself to GATT again in this way, will demonstrate through its senior Ministers slightly more appreciation of the nature of those obligations than seems to have been the case in other contexts in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Presently, Customs valuation is based on what is known as the Brussels Definition of Value-the BDV-which provides for the valuation of imported goods on an essentially notional basis by comparing each actual transaction with an ideal transaction in which all the circumstances conform with an entirely open market or an arms length situation. The proposed new system differs from the present one in that it is a positive system, using the actual prices and charges paid to arrive at a dutiable value for Customs purposes. The primary new method of valuation contained in this legislation is the actual transaction value, that in turn being measured by the free-on-board price actually payable for imported goods when they are sold for export to the country of importation-in this case Australia-after certain defined adjustments have been made to that price.

Where, however, the transaction value of the imported goods cannot be used as the basis for valuation there is a whole sequence of five alternative methods of valuation provided in the legislation. If these methods fail to establish a value for Customs purposes there is a provision in the agreement which is reflected in the legislation in proposed new sub-section 157 (8) for the Comptroller-General of Customs to determine the value. The legislative package, quite complicated as it is, nonetheless appears to be exactly in acordance with the Customs valuation code agreed to at the Tokyo round of GATT. The Australian Labor Party sees a potential disadvantage in the new valuation system to the extent that it could certainly involve greater administrative burdens upon importers who have to adapt to these new procedures.

But we nonetheless support the Bill because of three even more obvious advantages. In the first place the valuation system proposed is internationally agreed and therefore not only contributes, by virtue of that international agreement, to the promotion of trade between nations but also ensures that there is not a proliferation of different valuation systems operating in the major trading nations which, to the extent that this happens, can of course result in a number of unfair valuation methods being applied as artificial barriers to trade. The second advantage of the new system is that it is clearly going to be capable of easier administration by the Collector of Customs. Thirdly-I suppose this relates to the second point-it is an objective rather than subjective measurement of value.

We do, of course, have some concern that any changes to the valuation system should not result in a reduction of tariffs by stealth following from the fact that any method of valuation that artificially lowers the valuation at which goods are assessed will lower thereby the actual duty payable on them and can produce a situation accordingly of lowering the tariff payable. In this respect we accept the Government's assurances, clearly made in the other place by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) and to some extent in the second reading speech, that the new code will be closely monitored, that it will not have any widespread consequences for the level of tariff assistance and that the Industries Assistance Commission or the Temporary Assistance Authority will investigate if any problems do arise. It is clear that many members of the Government parties believe that the tariffs should be cut, either as an article of almost biblical faith or at least as a response to the massive capital inflow we are experiencing, one hopes temporarily. But, as our spokesman on industry and commerce, Mr Chris Hurford, and others of us have repeatedly said, we reject the notion that Australian manufacturing industry should be dismantled to make way for that inflow. That is to get the priorities totally end-about. In the situation before us tonight, however, I do not want to embark upon a major discussion in any way of--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were going to review the Gregory thesis.
—There might be a time and a place to do that but tonight is not it, bearing in mind Senator Haines's strictures and those of some of my colleagues.
—You are all heart.

—Just take advantage of this sensitivity while I am demonstrating it as it does not happen too often. We accept in this respect as well the Government's assurances at this stage that the Bill will not have this kind of impact. If any reasons develops to show those that assurances are misleading and our confidence is misplaced, we will undoubtedly have much more to say on the subject of this Bill than I have offered tonight. For the moment, I simply repeat that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for its support of the legislation. In order to try to set Senator Evans's mind at some kind of rest concerning the monitoring role of the Government in this area, it might help him to know that over the last 12 or 18 months or so the Industries Assistance Commission has taken into account the new method of valuation. This has been a vital element of its decision-making and recommendation process. I think the general feeling that has emanated from that source has been that the general level of tariff has not been affected as a result of these processes and consequently one would hope that that will maintain in the future. Nevertheless, the Government's undertaking in this regard to monitor and to advise remains and I can assure Senator Evans that that will be the case. Since the Opposition has so strongly supported the Bill, I wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this reforming measure. It is very pleasing to see that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has returned to the chamber. He will be able to go overseas tomorrow with his reputation untarnished as one of the reforming Attorneys that this Commonwealth has produced. It may surprise people to hear that commendation falling from the lips of an Opposition senator, but this is a reforming measure of some significance. I speak of the Bill entitled 'A Bill for an Act relating to Domicile'. On the surface it seems to be a very dry and technical subject. The domicile there referred to is not the simple matrimonial home but is a legal concept, a sort of link word, which bridges the distance between a person and a system of law. It links any particular Australian to a system of law which might determine his or her matrimonial status, capacity to make wills or whatever. This measure was decided upon within the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. I understand that similar legislation has been passed or introduced into all the other Australian parliaments, both State and Territory.
—Except Western Australia, I understand.

—I believe it has been introduced into that Parliament, according to the Attorney's second reading speech. The point is that we are concerned with establishing rules governing questions arising in relation to laws of the Commonwealth and in relation to certain Territories, such as the Australian Capital Territory and Jervis Bay. We are here making a law which will override or exclude any competing law passed by any State parliament or put forward by any State or Territory court within Australia or, indeed, overseas. In other words, we are acting as an Australian parliament in order to make clear what the law of domicile shall be for the future in Australia. The mere fact that this has been agreed upon by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General might lead some cynics to conclude that in fact we are dealing with law of a very dull and technical kind. I repeat that, though the title of the Bill might suggest such, we are dealing here with a reforming Bill of a sweeping and fundamental kind because it overturns some six centuries of common law whereby the domicile of a wife always followed that of her husband.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been the case, as far as my research has been able to discover, since Bracton's day and certainly since the thirteenth century that a wife's domicile always slavishly followed that of her husband for the purpose of determining what jurisdiction she should go to in relation to matrimonial affairs or her capacity to make wills or dispose of personal property. One uses the words 'slavishly followed that of her husband' quite deliberately. They are apt words because there was a situation of servitude of the wife to the husband. That grew, of course, out of the concept that upon marriage the husband and wife were one. But there was always then the rider that the one was the husband. The law of unity was always in favour of the husband. The Bill asserts the independent integrity of the woman in a marriage situation insofar as she can make an independent choice of the law of domicile which will govern the jurisdiction to which she might resort in the case of marital breakdown or deal with the making of a will or whatever situation occurs in that type of personal law.

We are engaged in a quite important project. The Bill generalises a position which has been reached under the Family Law Act already within federal parliamentary statutes. It makes general this particular principle of abolishing the dependence of the wife on the husband for her legal status before the courts. It must be the right principle to abolish that particular aspect of servitude which has lingered over the centuries. From now on the wife's own choice of residence will determine the correct jurisdiction for the determination of matters relating to her personal property or status. I give some examples that come to mind. If a couple were married in the United Kingdom, migrated to Australia, marital discord ensued and the husband went to the United States, under the common law rules the woman might well find that rather than the law of Australia governing the dissolution of the marriage the law of the United States, where she has never set foot, would determine the matter because her domicile would be that of her husband. That situation has been overcome in the Family Law Act and now, in a more general way, is being overcome in this legislation.

The legislation goes further than that and brings the law of domicile into a more realistic relationship to the present situation within Australian society in a whole range of matters. As one would expect with a principle of common law which was developed six centuries ago, it sits very awkwardly with the type of society which has evolved in Australia. Let me give some examples. Our population is characterised by high mobility where people move from States to State. At present, if a migrant came to Australia and perhaps worked in the construction industry and moved around from State to State it would be very difficult, if not impossible, for a court to determine in which State of Australia that person had his domicile for the purpose of deciding under which State law relating to wills or the passing of property, if that person died without making a will, the matter should be governed.

This Bill makes it clear in clause 11 that a person who moves around within the Australian Federation from State to State in a way which makes it difficult to determine that the person has formed a settled intention to reside indefinitely in any one State rather than another is to be regarded as domiciled in the State with which he has, for the time being, the closest connection. In that way many of the difficulties which apparently are of a technical nature but of a very real nature are overcome. I have already given the example of a construction worker who moves from State to State in the course of seeking employment and who finds it impossible to ascertain under which State law he should make his will. This legislation very neatly deals with that problem.

The Bill also enables a person of the age of 18 or over to acquire an independent domicile; that is, an intention to reside in a particular place independent of that of the parents of the person who has attained 18 years of age. This merely brings the law into harmony with the social mores in Australia which say that a person who attains 18 years of age has, for all purposes relating to participation in democratic life or for the purpose of accepting legal responsibilities and liabilities, attained that status.
