It occurred to me that perhaps the age ought to be 16 years because a female who is 16 or 17 years of age has the right to marry quite independently of judicial or parental permission. That does not apply to the male, but it certainly applies to the female. It is a fact that the Bill is drawn in a way which permits a married person under 18 to acquire a domicile of choice quite independently of the parents, and in the case of the wife, now, even of the husband, although commonly the domicile will of course be that of the husband where the married couple lives together. But why the Bill has not been drafted in a way which allows a domicile of choice, an independent domicile, to be acquired by an Australian on attaining the age of 16 years seems to me to be somewhat odd when, as I say, a female certainly can attain a married status without any judicial or parental intervention.

Nevertheless, having said that, it is good to see within the legislation a recognition of the fact that on attaining 18 years of age, as in the exercise of all other democratic and legal rights, a person ought to be able to acquire a domicile of choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can a person aged 16 to 18 make a will?

—That depends on the various State or Territory jurisdictions. To be honest I would not know what the overall answer is for Australia. Perhaps the Attorney-General will enlighten us on that point when he replies. I thank the honourable senator for raising that important matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The importance of the Bill in relation to that aspect is that of course the 17 year old boy leaving Tasmania to go to Victoria to undertake his apprenticeship is not, under this legislation, able to acquire a domicile of choice in Victoria. If the law there were more favourably drafted in a way which would enable him to exercise greater legal rights in Victoria than Tasmania he would not be able to take advantage of that, say, in relation to the making of a will. Let us presume that in Tasmania a person below the age of 18 could not make a will, but in Victoria a person between the ages of 16 and 18 could. On going to Victoria, under this Bill an apprentice would not be able to take advantage of the Victorian law, which seems to me to be somewhat odd. That is the point I was trying to make.

The Bill also recognises another less pleasing feature of Australian life but it is a reality of Australian life that where one has growing numbers of couples who are separated or divorced and the custody of children is awarded to only one of the parents naturally, then, it is clearly inappropriate that the common law rules should apply whereby the domicile of the father is automatically the domicile of the child or, to put it the other way, that the domicile of the child is automatically the domicile of the father even though that child may be living with the mother in her residence. This Bill makes it very clear that the child should have the domicile of the parent with whom he or she has his or her permanent home. That is a straight-forward common-sense amendment which is to be welcomed. The Bill also makes it clear that an adopted child is now to be treated by the law in every respect as if he had been born to the adopter or the adopting parents. Accordingly the domicile of an adopted child under 18 years of age will be determined as if he were the legitimate child of his adopted parents or parent.

Let me return to the central reforming task of this Bill. It generalises those steps already taken under the Family Law Act. It places a married woman in the same position as any other Australian citizen or Australian resident of mature age and sound mind. It enables her to acquire a domicile of choice independent of that of her husband. If, for example, a couple were separated and the wife moved, say, to South Australia-the husband remaining in Victoria-under the common law, the State which governed the making of a will by that woman would be that of Victoria. Now the law relating to that matter will be that of South Australia. In other words, it will be the law of the place where she has taken up residence and evinced some intention to remain indefinitely.

In placing a woman in the same position as all other citizens, one removes that constraint of servility, that slavish dependence upon the husband, which has been a carry-over of the common law attitude of six centuries ago, whereby the husband and wife were one, but the husband was 'the one'. The legislation recognises the independent personality and integrity of the female partner in a marriage relationship, in a fairly technical area of our concerns.

As to the technical matter of intention-if I may just conclude on this note-the Bill does change slightly the common law. As I recall it, the common law generally required that an intention to reside permanently be evinced. Whilst that was modified-a modification that was somewhat accepted-so that if one evinced an intention to reside indefinitely in a place that was sufficient, the Bill makes it very clear that that will be sufficient intention, coupled with evidence of residence. That requirement is not as easy to satisfy as might appear. For example, if a Tasmanian moves to the north west of Western Australia with the intention of working there for six years in order to save money and return to Tasmania, having made his fortune up in the Pilbara, the question is: Has that person evinced an intention to live indefinitely in Western Australia?

If I may give a more difficult example, a refugee may come to Australia with an intention in the back of his mind that, if political conditions in the country from which he has fled permit, he will return, given favourable conditions in his homeland. Has such a person, in coming to Australia, formed such a frame of mind that one could say there had been an acquisition by him of Australia as a domicile of choice? In that situation, are the Vietnamese refugees able to take advantage of our system of law. Or, if there is an intention on their part to return to Vietnam if conditions prove favourable, are they still bound in matters relating to their marriages, and perhaps the making of wills, by Vietamese law? That is just a matter of interest, involving a difficult matter of evidence which might come before the courts in the not too distant future.

The Opposition welcomes the Bill. We believe that, despite its rather dry and technical appearance, it is part of a very fundamental reform of our legal processes which does recognise the independent personality of women, in particular those women who are married but do not want to be totally and automatically subservient in their legal relationship to the legal status of their husband. For that reason, the Opposition welcomes the Bill and wishes it a speedy passage through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are debating tonight the Domicile Bill 1981 and the Domicile (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1981, the major measure, of course, being the former. This is a particularly sensible and not insignificant piece of legislation, both for women and for children, as Senator Tate has already mentioned, since it ends a number of outdated provisions relating to the domicile of certain groups of women and children in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: It is particularly important for women, of course, since it now enshrines in law a woman's right to independent domicile from her husband. It gives her in effect a choice with regard to domicile that did not exist previously. In fact, it is depressing to know that, for some 600 years, a wife's domicile was determined wholly and solely by that of her husband. It is, contrary to what Senator Tate maintains, exciting to note that, in his second reading speech the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) makes this statement:
It is clearly no longer appropriate that a wife's domicile should automatically be the same as that of her husband.
I heartily endorse that statement and, in doing so, have the support of the rest of my party.

Furthermore, this Bill now removes the stigma of chattlehood from married women-a state to which Senator Tate referred as a form of slavery. The law finally has managed to catch up with some aspects of twentieth century social moves and the Attorney-General is to be applauded for that.

In passing, it is interesting to note that some years ago the then Premier of South Australia, Don Dunstan, and his second wife, asserted their rights to retain not only their own names after marriage but also to independence of domicile. They argued that they were individuals and, furthermore, independent units; that they operated better in that way; and that they had the right to behave and to be treated as independent units.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a different domicile.

—It does not seem to matter to most people whether the domicile is down the street, in the next suburb, in another city or in another State or country. The principle of independence surely is what counts. I forget offhand now just how close their home bases were but the point they made is a valid one. It is enshrined on a more general basis in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The clause which grants 18-year-olds the right to independent domicile is a similarly sensible one, bearing in mind other modern laws which Senator Tate mentioned, on the legal voting age in particular, and the age at which males, if not females, can be married. Senator Tate raised an interesting point about women being entitled to marry, without parental or court interference, at the age of 16. However, I do not share his apparent opinion that that justifies dropping the age to 16 for everybody, since the marital situation is covered separately.

All in all, it seems to me that the Bill ends a number of very discriminatory practices, not the least of which is that of defining a child's domicile according to the marital status of the parents. The Attorney-General, in his second reading speech, made this further point:
Under the common law rules relating to domicile, a child born in wedlock aquires the domicile of his father while an illegitimate child has the domicile of the mother.
He goes on to make the further statement:
It is not appropriate--
I interpolate, certainly not in this day and age-
that a child should automatically have the domicile of one parent if the parents are separated and the child is in fact permanently living with the other parent.

So the Bill provides that in such a situation the child has the domicile of the parent with whom he-or, I presume, she-has his or her principal home. That is an infinitely more sensible arrangement than has applied previously. In fact, in its entirety, this is a sensible Bill, a modern Bill, one which accepts that common law should come under scrutiny according to changing social needs and be amended, where necessary. I commend the Attorney-General for bringing the Bill forward at this time and support, and in fact applaud, the measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to what Senator Haines said, I do not commend the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) for bringing this legislation forward at this time. The reason for that, without canvassing the merits or otherwise of the Bill, is that I understood the package of Bills listed under Notices of Motion on the Senate Notice Paper of Tuesday, 20 October, would be left to lie on the table for wide consideration by the community and for debate in the next session of Parliament. The Attorney-General gave five notices of motion. Notice of Motion No. 1 seeks leave to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Family Law Act 1981. Notice of Motion No. 2 seeks leave to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Maintenance Orders (Commonwealth Officers) Act 1966. Notice of Motion No. 3 seeks leave to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Migration Act 1958. Notice of Motion No. 4 seeks leave to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to domicile. Notice of Motion No. 5 seeks leave to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Marriage Act 1961 and the Family Law Act 1975 in consequence of the enactment of the Domicile Act 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: I might be labouring under a very false apprehension but I was clearly of the belief that this package of Bills which principally deal with matters relating to family law, maintenance and so on, was to lay on the table for wide public debate before it was pushed through this Parliament. Of course, many of the matters and clauses that are contained in the Domicile Bill are quite sensible. I am a bit concerned about the glib phrase 'modern social attitudes'-whatever they are-used in the Minister's second reading speech. That type of phrase was used by the previous Attorney-General, former Senator Murphy, in respect of the Family Law Act and the liberalisation of family law in Australia. Quite frankly-and I make no bones about this-the 'liberalisation' of the Family Law Act in Australia has inflicted untold cruelty and misery on many thousands of Australian women particularly in respect of the no fault aspect of that legislation. Many of us have received representations from women in great distress because their husbands had simply opted out of their responsibilities by using the period of separation as a precondition for divorce.

TALK.START.PARA: —And vice versa in one out of three cases.
—Senator Martin says 'vice versa in one out of three cases'. Of course, this proves my point that the weight of damage-

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, whatever else the Domicile Bill may be about, I put it to you that it is not about no fault divorce under the Family Law Act 1975. Senator Harradine is using this Bill to stray very far indeed from the matter before the Senate to canvass matters that have nothing whatsoever to do with this legislation.

—I am listening very closely to Senator Harradine. I expect that Senator Harradine will relate the argument he has so far expressed to this chamber back to the Bill under discussion. I call Senator Harradine.

—Thank you, Mr President. In fact I was referring to the point made in the Minister's second reading speech about modern social attitudes. I was indicating that the same sort of words were used by a previous Attorney-General in respect of this whole area. I made the point first up that the Minister had indicated that this group of Bills would be laid on the table and that there would be wide ranging discussion about them.
—They are two different packages.

—They are not two different packages. As I see it, the two Bills before us-I imagine we are debating this legislation cognately-and the consequential Bills will be amendments to the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that this piece of legislation has been brought in quite hurriedly. I certainly have not had time to look deeply at its ramifications. For example, what are the ramifications in respect of the rights of a woman who has been deserted by her husband, whose domicile under common law is the home where the husband resided and whose husband has now gone to another domicile? What right does she have under this piece of legislation? What right does this legislation give to a woman, in the event of a divorce being forced upon her by reason of separation under the Family Law Act, in respect of an entitlement to the cut up of the property of both domiciles? These are the sorts of things that ought to be given consideration.

Senator Tate dealt with the definition of 'independent domicile'. He also dealt with the definition of 'domicile' in respect of the part of the union. This is the first time I have heard Australia, or any part of Australia, referred to as the union. I suppose that is fair enough. Those matters seem to be eminently sensible. However, as I said, I believe the legislation before us is part of a group of measures relating to family law and marriage matters and that we would be given time to consider the legislation. I frankly admit that I have not had time to study the legislation in the manner I would have liked. I hope that the Attorney-General takes cognisance of that and at least allows the legislation to lay on the table for some further period. Unless he can provide the Senate with some indication as to why this piece of legislation ought to be pushed through this session he ought to follow this course. I am concerned about the possible ramifications of this Bill. I hope that the Minister will understand that and allow the Bill, if possible, to lay on the table for some further period, as he has allowed the other Bills to lay on the table, so as to allow wide ranging public debate and consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Domicile Bill and the Domicile (Consequential Amendments) Bill, as has been said, make some major changes in the ordinary rules relating to the law of domicile. The legislation deals with the definition of domicile, the way domicile is lost, the way new domicile is obtained and so on. It is a general measure relating to common law rules. The concept of domicile runs through a great many parts of our different laws. It is also particularly a part of those laws which select what other laws apply. It is known in legal parlance as conflict of laws rules. I think that aspect of it has become quite clear in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems that Senator Harradine is concerned about arise under specific laws. Where there is a specific law about a matter then of course that law prevails over the general law of the kind that we are debating in this legislation. As I had made clear in my second reading speech this law is the result of lengthy discussions that have taken place in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General over a number of years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not kidding; they have been going on for years.

—I am not kidding; that is right. It has taken many years for this legislation to come to light. The fact of the matter is that-this may be of some assurance to Senator Harradine who is concerned about the haste of the measure-it is certainly not a measure that has been dreamt up by me and introduced into this place overnight. It is the result of very lengthy consideration by all the State Attorneys-General. In fact, it has been going on for so long that many more Attorneys than the existing ones have had a finger in the pie. Finally agreement was reached some time ago and each of us undertook to introduce and pass, if we could, this measure in our own parliaments. In fact, the Commonwealth is lagging behind in this exercise at this stage because similar legislation has been passed in all the other States except, I think, Western Australia, although it has been introduced into the Western Australian Parliament. I think this is the last of the parliaments in which legislation has been introduced. There is a certain urgency about it because I had undertaken to get this introduced and I had hoped to get it through the Parliament as soon as possible so that we would be able to get the benefits of uniformity. That is the reason why it is being pressed on with during this session. It has been categorised by the Government in its program as being legislation for passage this session. I am sorry it has been rushed on a little earlier than it would othewise have been, Senator Harradine, but because I am going overseas at the end of this week I wanted to get the measure through before I left. However, it has still got to be introduced and debated in another place and before that occurs there will be time for any last minute consideration which the honourable senator or anybody else wishes to give it. However, the matters which have been introduced here, I think, have been overwhelmingly supported by the Senate. I doubt very much whether, after all the consideration and the widespread support it has had in this place, any problems are likely to be found with the legislation by delaying its passage through this Parliament any longer.

SPEECH.PARA: When I introduced the five different Bills into the Senate yesterday, notice of which had been given last Thursday, I placed before the Senate a specific motion to make clear what the family law package of legislation was. Those Bills are listed in that package. They are listed quite separately on the Notice Paper. There was a separate motion which made up the package of the two domicile Bills. So I fail to see how there could be any misunderstanding created by me that it was ever intended that this domicile package would be part of the family law package. However, I am sorry if that misunderstanding has occurred but I do not think the Senate should hold up the passage of this legislation which, as I have said, is widely supported in the Senate.

As to the particular matter that is worrying Senator Harradine-he asked what effect the new provisions might have on a wife who had been deserted by her husband who had gone to another country. He asked what effect that would have on her maintenance and custody rights and so on. I can assure Senator Harradine that it will have no effect whatsoever in reducing her rights whatever they may be under any Australian laws. In fact, the provisions might assist her as she does retain her Australian domicile even though her husband may have gone somewhere else and acquired another domicile. Insofar as domicile may be relevant to the determination of those rights about which the honourable senator is concerned, the wife would retain her Australian domicile in whatever State of Australia her domicile may be. So I really do not think the honourable senator need be concerned about those sorts of matters. If there are any other particular concerns that the honourable senator would like to make known to me I will have them checked out before the Bills are passed through the House of Representatives. I hope the Bills will have a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 8 of the Domicile Bill. I would like to take up the matter that I raised earlier concerning the fact, which is welcomed, that under this Bill a person is capable of having an independent domicile if the has attained the age of 18 years or he is or has at any time been married and not otherwise. I raised the point that a 16-year-old or a 17-year-old female can marry without the consent of either parent or any particular court. It seems to me that certainly within that sphere of law there is a recognition of the independent status of females of 16 or 17 years of age. I am wondering why it ought not to be recognised in this Bill that a young Australian person of 16 or 17 ought to be able to acquire an independent domicile. We live in a society in which young people do leave home perhaps at the conclusion of their high school education; upon taking up employment or seeking employment; because of marital stress or family breakdown; or for any other reason and they are not residing with their parents in the parental home or with either parent if indeed the parents are separated. In that situation where a 16-year-old or 17-year-old Australian is living in a State other than that in which the parents live, why should not that person be able to acquire an independent domicile? It would seem to me to be in harmony with that feature of Australian life to which I have drawn attention.

—The short answer to the matter raised by Senator Tate is that this is a uniform Bill and it was the decision of all the Attorneys that this provision of 18 years of age rather than any earlier age for a female should be the one adopted. I would not want to change that unless there was some overwhelming reason. In any event, I would not change it here before raising the matter again with the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, and I am sure the honourable senator would not want me to do that. It would throw the whole thing back into confusion. The capacity of a female to marry at an age earlier than 18 years is a specific provision of the Marriage Act. Here we are dealing with general provisions, whereas that is a specific provision. I think that really is a rather special case. Uniformly in Australia 18 years has now been selected as the age of majority, as against the former age of 21 years. For the purposes of the domicile legislation, I think we should adopt the same general rule.

—The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) mentioned in his reply at the second reading stage of the Bill that the rights of people under quite a number of laws will be affected by this Bill. I found the second reading speech to be inadequate as to details of what laws of the Commonwealth would be affected by this legislation being passed. As a corollary to that I ask: Were the Parliament not to pass this Bill at this stage, what effect would that have? In other words, what pieces of legislation would be affected? Would it affect only the Marriage Act and the Family Law Act in the Federal jurisdiction? As I understand it, matters relating to wills and so on are matters of State law?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give the chamber a schedule of all the Acts of the Commonwealth that refer to domicile. Wherever the word 'domicile' appears in legislation and there is not a special definition of it, the Domicile Bill will apply. A good example is the Income Tax Assessment Act, which defines 'resident' or 'resident of Australia' as a person who resides in Australia and includes a person whose domicile is in Australia. The word 'domicile' there will be interpreted in accordance with the Domicile Act. Certainly the laws relating to the making of wills, marriages and so on tend to have specific provisions about age rather than talk about domicile. It would be a major exercise to select all the laws in which there is reference to domicile.
—You've got it on the computer, haven't you?

—I suppose we have it on the computer. I do not think it is necessary to extract this information because the answer is that wherever the word 'domicile' appears and there is no special definition of it this Bill will apply. As I explained, the reason for passing this legislation now is that it is a joint exercise with the States and it is really a matter of keeping faith with the States. We have said that we will join in passing this uniform legislation so that throughout Australia, in both Federal and State jurisdictions, the word 'domicile' has the same meaning. I really am anxious to keep faith with the States. As Senator Evans has said, it has been a long process in reaching this agreement. I do not want the Commonwealth to be the last jurisdiction actually to pass the legislation. We are jolly well nearly the last. I would not like to be the last.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Durack) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crimes Amendment Bill 1981 makes a number of important and innovative changes to the law governing the sentencing of Commonwealth offenders. Commonwealth offenders are those who commit offences under the laws of the Commonwealth or the Australian Capital Territory. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill. Indeed, to the extent that it seeks to implement progressive reforms in the sentencing area, we welcome it. But the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) will be relieved nonetheless to hear that we have not entirely changed our spots and we certainly do not support the Bill unreservedly. There are a number of matters in respect of which we will be moving amendments at the Committee stage; one or two of those matters I will foreshadow towards the end of this speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill must be seen in the context of the Australian Law Reform Commission report on which most of it is based. As the Attorney indicated in his second reading speech, the question of the sentencing of Federal offenders was the subject of a reference to the Law Reform Commission on 11 August 1978. The Commission, led in this instance, as usual, by Mr Justice Kirby, who was assisted in the context of this reference by Professor Duncan Chappell, an internationally known criminologist, completed a hefty 636-page interim report in January 1980, following the usual very intensive consultative procedure. Not only did the Law Reform Commission engage in widespread consultation, public hearings and so on around the country with written submissions and the appointment of specialist consultants, but also it conducted a number of special surveys of judges, magistrates, prosecutors, Federal prisoners and public opinion generally which produced a quite unique body of survey material which the Commission was able to utilise and which constitutes a good deal of the bulk of this very bulky Law Reform Commission report.

The report was tabled in the Federal Parliament on 21 May 1980. It contained two draft Bills as well as 129 specific recommendations. Most of them were of a final kind but a number of them were expressed to be of an exploratory, tentative or interim character. Indeed, the Commission indicated that this was very much an interim report and that much of the subject matter of it should be the subject of community debate plus further attention by the Commission before it would be shaped up in the form of legislative recommendations. But the Commission did specify two steps in particular as being urgent. This is contained in the report tabled in May 1980. It was in respect of those two matters that the Commission supplied draft legislation to concentrate the mind of the Government. The two matters were, firstly, the establishment of an adequate Commonwealth victims compensation scheme and, secondly, provisions to give guidance in the use of imprisonment in the case of convicted Federal offenders and also to facilitate the use of non-custodial sentencing options where appropriate for persons convicted of offences against Commonwealth law. It is now October 1981 and I suppose we should be grateful that only 17 months have elapsed since the report was tabled and that at least one of the two urgent steps has been taken in this Bill, that is, the provisions in this Bill relating to the sentencing of Federal offenders and non-custodial options and the pecuniary penalties associated with fining.

The other matter recommended as urgent, the crimes compensation machinery for Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory jurisdictions, remains, so far as the Government's intentions are concerned, quite an unknown quantity. It is a serious indictment, as one is obliged to say so often, of this Government-which promised, I seem to recall, in August 1979 that legislation was to be drafted in respect of this matter-that two years later we still have not got anything at all. The urgent step which has, albeit tardily and finally, been taken is that, as I said, concerning the sentencing of Federal offenders. It must, however, be said that this Bill goes further than the Law Reform Commission draft Bill in a number of respects and it does implement a number of the other ALRC recommendations which were not set up in legislative form and which were expressed to be not as urgent as others. I suppose this is what in the mind of the Attorney-General justifies the 17-month delay in the introduction of this legislation.

Be that as it may, before dealing with the most important specific provisions of the Bill, I think it is important to draw attention to the general recommendations of the Commission about sentencing reform. At the outset, I think I should read the Principles of Punishment which are articulated by the Commission in its Summary of Recommendations 1, 2 and 3, based on paragraphs 66 and 67 of the report. First of all, it expressed the general rationale of punishment in the following terms:

No single rationale of punishment can or should predominate in guiding reform of Commonwealth laws concerning sentencing. Punishment may, in varying degrees, take into account elements such as deterrence, the denunciation of abhorrent behaviour, the reinforcement of community moral and ethical values and, perhaps with less confidence than in the past and within limits required by just deserts, reformation of the offender and his restoration to society.
Secondly, it states:

Punishment for persons convicted of Federal offences should, as far as possible, be certain, consistent and proportional to the gravity of the crime for which the offender is being sentenced. The principle of economy in the imposition of punishment, which limits the amount of punishment imposed to the minimum necessary to achieve community objectives, should also be observed.
Thirdly, and finally, it states:

So far as is consistent with social protection, preference should be given to the use of non-custodial sentencing options and the use of such options should be facilitated by reform of Commonwealth law.

That is the philosophy which guides the recommendations of the Commission and which seems, within certain limitations which it is necessary to deal with later, guides the philosophy of the Government in accepting those recommendations. It is important to note also that the Commission placed particular emphasis on uniform treatment of Federal offenders when it said, in recommendation 16 of the report:

Commonwealth laws should implement the principle that offenders against the laws of the Commonwealth should be treated as uniformly as possible throughout Australia. Commonwealth laws and procedures which hinder the achievement of uniformity should be changed to bring them into accord with this principle even if doing so results, for a time, in differences in the way in which Commonwealth and local offenders are treated within a State or Territory jurisdiction.

Might I simply say that the Opposition endorses very strongly that principle as being an essential requirement of a fair and equal criminal justice system. I add that to aid in the achievement of uniformity and consistency the Law Reform Commission did make some quite specific recommendations, the status of which in the Government's mind again we remain quite uncertain about. Rather than canvassing those matters in any detail now, might I simply seek leave to incorporate in Hansard these recommendations under the three headings: Firstly, Sentencing Council of Australia; secondly, Sentencing Guidelines; and, thirdly, Machinery to Achieve Uniformity.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
(a) Sentencing Council of Australia

21. Establishment. A new and authoritative body should be established by the Commonwealth with the mandate not only to gather information about the existing sentencing practices of the courts as they concern Federal offences and offenders but also to review these sentencing practices, and in the light of the review to issue guidelines for judicial officers involved in the sentencing of Federal offenders. The body which should conduct the review and disseminate guidelines, as well as perform a number of other functions, is the Sentencing Council of Australia. Such a national Sentencing Council should be established by legislation. There is undoubted power in the Commonwealth to establish such a Council and it should do so by legislation without delay.
(Para. 441)
24. Functions. The functions of the Sentencing Council should be provided for in Commonwealth legislation and should include in particular:
The review of present sentencing practices concerning Federal offences and offenders and the development of non-mandatory sentencing guidelines.

The review of present charging and prosecution practices as they affect Federal offences and offenders and the development of policy guidelines in regard to these practices, including plea negotiations affecting Federal offenders.
The review of existing statutory penalties provided in Commonwealth law concerning Federal offences.
The monitoring of minimum standards for the treatment of Federal prisoners and offenders in State and Territory institutions and otherwise.
The development of guidelines in relation to parole, including, if parole is abolished, the consequential changes to sentencing practices relating to Federal offenders.
The provision of various services to judicial officers including the development of studies in sentencing and the supply of detailed statistics . . .
(b) Sentencing Guidelines

25. Study of Sentencing Practices and Development of Guidelines. The Sentencing Council should initiate a study of sentencing practices throughout Australia affecting offences and offenders. Based on this study, the Council should develop and disseminate to all judicial officers involved in the sentencing of Federal offenders in Australia detailed information on Federal criminal matters, including a set of broad guidelines indicating the range of penalties that might be applied for specific categories of Federal offences and offenders. These guidelines should not be prescriptive, but should be intended and designed to assist rather than coerce the exercise of judicial discretion.
(Para. 446)
(c) Machinery to Achieve Uniformity

60. General Approach. Greater guidance should be given to judicial officers sentencing convicted Federal offenders. A more scientific and principled approach should be adopted which retains the best elements of judicial independence and discretion but incorporates institutions, information and procedures which encourage rationality, consistency, publicity and general uniformity of punishment for like offences.
(Para. 402)

61. Three Targets of Reform. Three broad areas of reform are required to guide judicial discretion in a way which will lead to a reduction in disparities in the sentencing of offenders convicted of offences against the laws of the Commonwealth whilst not removing a proper degree of judicial discretion in sentencing. These are:
the provision of more appropriate and consistent penalties in legislation;
the provision of a new right of appeal to the Federal Court of Australia in Federal criminal matters; and

the establishment of a Sentencing Council to review existing sentencing practices and to publish sentencing guidelines and statistical and other data for the guidance of judicial officers who sentence convicted Federal offenders in Australia (see rec. 21 above).

65. Appeals to the Federal Court of Australia. If uniform and consistent national principles of punishment for Federal offences and offenders are to be attained by the traditional method of appeal court review there should be a court, below the High Court of Australia, which reviews Federal sentences. This court should be the Federal Court of Australia, which already has a limited criminal jurisdiction in specialised areas and more generally hears appeals against the conviction and sentence from Territorial courts. The Federal Court should also hear appeals brought against conviction and sentence from decisions of the various State Supreme Courts and intermediate courts in the case of persons convicted and sentenced of offences against laws of the Commonwealth.
(Para. 435)

66. Power to Transfer to State Courts. The Federal Court should be empowered to transfer a case to a State Supreme Court if it considers that the case would more appropriately and conveniently be dealt with by the State Court. The exercise of such a transfer would ensure avoidance of unwarranted multiple hearings or any abuse of the appeals process, particularly in the case of conviction for both Federal and State offences.
(Para. 439)

TALK.START.PARA: —These recommendations are clearly all in themselves major reforms. They are all reforms which are eminently capable of implementation. The key point-this is one that the Opposition wants to emphasise-is that sentencing reform cannot be achieved piecemeal. If the objectives of uniformity, consistency and priority to non-custodial sentences are really to be achieved, the other parts of the Law Reform Commission package must be pressed vigorously. They do not involve great expense. They do not involve dislocation of the existing system. They are essential if any reforms in this area are to be effective. If the process stops, as I fear it might, with this particular Bill, the efforts of the Law Reform Commission will, to a very large extent, have been wasted. Then the recommendations of the Commission that this whole subject be an occasion for a major national debate on sentencing issues and criminology generally will be rendered nugatory. I would appreciate it if the Attorney-General, in his reply on this second reading debate, would give a fairly precise indication of what exactly his intentions are so far as these various mooted complementary reforms are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two further reforms which I have not mentioned but which were also the subject of the Law Reform Commission's proposals and which do form part of its overall approach to sentencing law and procedures. Again, rather than canvassing these matters in nauseous detail at this stage might I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the relevant extracts from the Law Reform Commission report, this time under two headings: Firstly, Parole Abolition or Reform, and, secondly, Reform of Prison Conditions and Prisoner Grievance Procedures. I seek leave accordingly.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
(1) Parole abolition or reform

A second major proposal of this report relates to the abolition of parole. Parole probably originated in a humane endeavour to modify harsh aspects of punishment, to encourage good conduct in prison and to afford the prisoner a hope of restoration to society. Unfortunately, in practice, parole causes deeply felt and, in many cases justifiably resented injustices. Parole has many failings. The chief of these are:
it promotes indeterminance and uncertainty in criminal punishment;
it is founded on the unacceptable assumption that conduct in society can be safely predicted at all and, specifically, can be predicted on the basis of conduct in prison;
its proceedings are conducted in secrecy and parole decisions, which affect the liberty of individuals are unreviewable; and

it is a 'charade'. The spectacle of a long sentence of imprisonment no longer deceives the community which knows that the offender will serve a much shorter period in prison before being released on parole.

Of all the defective systems of parole in Australia, the Commonwealth's system is the most defective. The current administration procedures are too complicated. The system is not even uniform in its application in different parts of Australia. No subject has caused more bitter resentment and criticism on the part of prisoners than the operation of the current system for the parole and licensing of Federal prisoners in Australia. Much of this criticism is justified. The preferable course is to abolish parole for Federal prisoners and to return to a system by which judges impose sentences which are actually meant to be served, less standard and uniform remissions for good behaviour and industry. It must be frankly acknowledged that the abolition of parole is not without difficulties and that careful adjustments to the sentencing system will have to be made. Attention is called to these.
If the proposal that parole be abolished is not accepted or if its acceptance is delayed for a time, urgent steps are needed radically to reform parole for Federal prisoners. These steps include:
amendments to the language of the Commonwealth Prisoners Act so that it applies, in terms, uniformly throughout Australia;
introduction of standard non-parole periods and remissions for Federal prisoners;
the giving of reasons for the refusal of parole;
prisoner access to records considered by parole authorities, save in exceptional and defined circumstances;
prisoner participation and representation in parole hearings affecting his liberty;
the nomination of an identified Commonwealth officer responsible for providing parole information to prisoners and their families;
the publication of parole guidelines for release decisions; and
the creation of a Commonwealth Parole Board to replace current procedures by which parole decisions are recommended to the Governor-General by a busy Federal Minister, the Attorney-General.
Prison Conditions and Grievances

The fifth major area of attention in this report relates to the disparities and inequalities that arise from the differing standards in State prisons where, under present arrangements, Federal prisoners in Australia are kept. The standards differ from State to State and within particular States. Many Australian prisons in which Federal prisoners are kept do not meet internationally agreed and nationally suggested minimum standards. Loss of liberty necessarily involves many deprivations and inconveniences. Deprivation of liberty is the most serious punishment we have left to mark society's disapproval of crime and to punish an offender. But it is not appropriate to add to the loss of liberty inhumane, degrading or substandard conditions. That these exist to any degree is a rebuke to Australia as a civilised, confident and relatively prosperous country. It is not appropriate that the Commonwealth should continue to ignore its clear, separate constitutional responsibilities for the conditions under which Federal prisoners are held. This report proposes that certain steps be taken by the Commonwealth to ensure that prison conditions for Federal prisoners comply with minimum standards of treatment for Australian prisoners. The general public and even lawmakers have little idea of actual conditions in Australian prisons. Authoritative reports by a number of impeccable and independent inquiries in recent times (and lately a decision of the High Court of Australia and decisions of superior courts) bear witness to the deep concern that is felt amongst those who know about prison conditions in some Australian prisons.

A fair system of punishment will permit those sentenced to imprisonment to have access to independent machinery for the just determination of complaints about methods relating to prison administration according to law. Ombudsmen already perform useful work in this regard. In this report specific suggestions are made for the handling of prisoner complaints and for improving access to ombudsmen, including the provision of a facility of confidential correspondence with the ombudsmen throughout Australia. As to prisoner access to the courts, the ancient rule that convicted capital felons do not have access to the courts should be repealed in the Commonwealth's sphere as it has already been repealed elsewhere. Information should be provided to Federal prisoners concerning their rights and duties, including in respect of parole, remissions and complaints. Most Federal prisoners have committed 'white collar crimes', typically fraud and property offences. Many of them lived peacefully in society and most will return to do so. The provision of fair machinery to uphold the rule of law even within the walls of our prisons is a special feature of our form of society. Taking rights seriously, including the right of people temporarily outcast from the community, marks off countries such as ours which proclaim adherence to the Rule of Law and fair administration by government officers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I mention these specific areas simply to highlight their importance and to express again my concern that they be not ignored by the Government in the aura of self-congratulation in which it is no doubt wallowing in having finally got around to introducing this legislation. The strong view of the Commission is that reform in these areas is necessary. It is important, I think, to adopt and to accept its approach that sentencing reform must be seen as an integrated whole and not just a collection of peicemeal measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now turn to the major provisions of this Bill. The most important thrust of it is in the direction of alternatives to imprisonment. This was one of the areas of reform, obviously recommended by the Law Reform Commission, and forming part of the integrated approach to which I have already referred. The Commission summarised its reasons for moving in this direction of alternatives to imprisonment in the following terms in the introductory page xxvii of the report. I think it is important to put this on the record. It said:

The pressure for finding effective alternatives to imprisonment is not motivated solely by altruism. It is only now that Australian society is coming to realise the enormous capital and recurring costs of building and maintaining prisons. One estimate recently put the cost of keeping a married person in gaol (allowing for social service payments to the family) at more than $20,000 per annum. Whatever the precise sum, it is high and it is growing quickly. The costs in money terms are high but so are the costs in human terms. Many of Australia's prisons are unsatisfactory as recent Royal Commissions of inquiry and other reports disclose beyond doubt. Conditions in some Australian prisons in which Federal offenders are kept fall well below international and proposed national standards. There is strong evidence that far from contributing to the reform of offenders, present prison conditions foster deep resentments and actually contribute to continuing criminality.
The Commission went on:

For these and other reasons the search has begun in many countries for effective alternatives to imprisonment which, whilst punitive, avoid many of the financial and human costs of imprisonment. Whilst this search has progressed somewhat in the Australian States, it has not made any real progress in the Commonwealth's sphere.
So the Commission says:

The third major proposal in this report is to suggest steps designed both to control the use of imprisonment in the case of Federal offenders and to facilitate and encourage the use of non-custodial sentences, where these are available in the local jurisdiction.
In pursuing that theme, the Commission goes on to recommend a number of specific measures to implement this objective. Firstly, it refers to legislative directions of the following kind:

. . . imprisonment is to be used as a punsihment of 'last resort' i.e., where no other sanction would achieve the objectives contemplated by law; reasons should be given when a sentence of imprisonment is imposed; and imprisonment should not be automatic on failure to pay a fine-

The Commission then recommends the adoption and use in appropriate Federal cases of non-custodial sentencing options which are available now in State or Territory jurisdiction. If further recommends that there be a further more realistic and up-to-date range and gradation of penalties in Commonwealth legislation. The Commission further recommends that there be provision made for general sentencing guidelines to be determined by a sentencing council and that appeals in Federal criminal cases be available to the Federal Court of Australia. Many of the recommendations contained in the report are picked up by the Bill. Proposed new section 17A of the Crimes Act seeks to implement the recommendation that imprisonment be expressly a punishment of a last resort. We in the Opposition support that proposal, but we note that the Bill which was presented by the Attorney does not, unlike the Law Reform Commission draft Bill, specify the matters to which the court is to have regard in deciding whether any other penalty is appropriate. The Commission, in fact, outlined a series of criteria to which the court should have regard in determining whether to impose a penal sanction in the form of imprisonment, those criteria being:
(a) whether the person has endangered the life or personal security of others;
(b) whether the offence is of such a nature that no punishment other than imprisonment would be sufficiently severe, having regard to the seriousness of the offence or to the harm done;
(c) whether the person has previously been convicted, whether in the State or Territory in which he is convicted or not, of an offence similar to that in respect of which he is to be sentenced.

Whereas those criteria are suggested in the draft Bill provided by the Commission, by contrast the Bill with which we are confronted tonight contains no such criteria at all but rather only a generally expressed nostrum that judges should, where possible and appropriate, impose non-imprisonment sentences with a further criterion actually being embodied in the legislation to require that even that limited direction does not apply where the offence in question is one punishable by imprisonment either for life or for more than seven years. This cut off point which the Commonwealth and the Attorney-General have decided to put into the Bill does not seem to have any relationship to any recommendation of the Commission. As I say, it is a provision that requires the court to have regard to specific criteria and certainly not to have regard in any overriding way to the period for which the person is capable of being put in gaol by virtue of the particular crime which he or she is alleged to have committed. It is a very odd divergence from the recommendation of the Commission and it is not explained in any way by the Attorney in his second reading speech. We would appreciate from him an explanation of why this route has been chosen to implement what is undoubtedly a worthy aim.

The Bill goes on from there to identify, again properly and appropriately, what those non-custodial alternatives actually are. I suppose proposed new section 20AB is the centre piece of the Bill to the extent that it describes as appropriate non-custodial sentences any of the following: Community service orders, work orders, sentences of periodic detention, attendance centre orders, weekend detention and attendance orders. There is a final catch-all category which consists of any prescribed sentence or order that may subsequently be added to the list by executive decree. That is fair enough. Certainly, the Opposition welcomes the quite specific legislative focus that has now been given to the non-custodial alternative.

The next main area which is dealt with-it is the only other one on which I wish to comment in any detail at the second reading stage-relates to the payment of fines. Proposed new section 18A of the Crimes Act ensures that the full range of alternatives to imprisonment is available to the courts in the enforcement of fines against Commonwealth offenders-that is, a court can specify non-custodial options as being available in default of the payment of the fine in question. Instead of saying that a person is fined $500 or, in default of that, will go to gaol for three months, it is now provided that the court can and, in fact, should be encouraged to provide that in default of a fine of $500 a person can spend 15 weekends of attendance at a periodic detention centre or something of that kind. That is perfectly good as far as it goes and it is consistent with the general change towards these alternatives.

The Bill seeks to insert a new section 18B into the Act which will make provision for application by a Commonwealth offender for time, or for further time, to pay a fine. Where such an application is made the court, after hearing evidence as to the person's financial circumstances and his ability to comply, may direct that time, or further time, be given and that payment be by specified instalments or by different instalments from those originally ordered. All of this is again a welcome addition to the armoury which is available to the court. It introduces a welcome element of flexibility in the sentencing of offenders in the first place and also in the enforcement of sentences thus imposed. So far so good. All this was discussed by the Law Reform Commission at paragraph 386 of its report but was not the subject of a draft legislative proposal.

The Law Reform Commission distinguished-we accept that distinction-between the right of an offender to apply to the court for time, or for further time, to pay-preferably before the actual default arose, so that any change in his financial circumstances could, in fact, be accommodated-that being the provision which has been picked up in the legislation now before us. But, on the other hand, the distinction was made between the situation that I have just mentioned and that where there is a default in the payment of a fine. The Commission drew attention to the importance of applying a non-custodial sentence in that situation. The Commission's strong recommendation was not only that a non-custodial sentence be an option available to the court when confronted by some straggler who has been unable to pay his fine, but also, more strongly than that, that there be a legislative requirement that imprisonment not be imposed as a sanction for default except where there is wilful and unreasonable default.

Those are the two classes of recommendation which were discussed by the Commission. Of those two, it is the second that was stated by the Commission to be the more important since it seeks to implement still further the basic principle of imprisonment as a last resort. It also seeks to ensure a fresh assessment of the offender's financial position before any sentence of imprisonment is actually passed. That there is a necessity for this kind or provision in the law, I think, was amply demonstrated by the case of John Quayle, an Aboriginal from Wilcannia, a case which came to the attention of the public not so long ago. That person was sentenced to a period of six months imprisonment at Broken Hill for his failure to pay a $400 fine arising out of his non-lodgment of a tax return. In that case the court, by virtue of the Commonwealth legislation governing tax defaults, had no alternative but to impose a prison sentence. The fact that it had no alternative is a classic demonstration of some of the weaknesses in the law and the injustices which can be caused to certain classes of offenders, not just at the initial stage of imposing a sentence but also at the stage of enforcing it once it has been imposed.

What I am leading up to is that we are concerned about the failure of the Bill which is before us now to create explicit legislative rules to govern the situation of someone who is actually in default of an initial penalty of a fine that has been imposed upon him. As the Bill stands at the moment a court, when confronted by someone who has defaulted in a fine, has the flexibility under the provisions of the Bill to allow further time to pay. A court does not have the flexibility to introduce at that stage non-custodial orders and it certainly is not subject to any overriding declaration of legislative policy that, in those circumstances of a default, imprisonment should be imposed only as an absolute last resort.

It is that absence from this Bill of such a provision as recommended by the Commission that we regard as perhaps the most serious omission from the Bill and one that we hope to rectify at the Committee stage. It is to that issue-I will not go through the arguments again in the Committee stage-that our amendments Nos 1 to 3 are, in fact, addressed. I conclude by saying that subject to that concern, and to several other areas of concern which I will sketch out rather more briefly in the Committee stage and which are the subject also of Committee stage amendments, we certainly do not oppose this Bill. It is a path-breaking one. It is an innovative one. It is long overdue and we welcome it very much indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Senate for the support of this measure, which is a very important one. It gives some implementation to a report of the Law Reform Commission on a reference that I gave it on the sentencing of Federal offenders. However, my interest in and concern about the provisions of the Crimes Act and the limitations of its provisions in regard to the sentencing of Federal offenders have gone back for some time. I became particularly concerned about the limitations of the Crimes Act when I attended an inaugural meeting of the Australian Association of Magistrates in 1978. It was really as a result of that that I decided that we should prepare a paper for what was then going to be an international crime conference in Australia. The reference I gave the Law Reform Commission was for the purpose of getting the background for the contribution Australia was to make at that conference.

SPEECH.PARA: In the event, the report of the Law Reform Commission ranged over a much wider area than I had anticipated. The Commission interpreted its reference in no doubt a permissible way, but also in the widest possible sense. The report which Senator Evans has been referring to, reading from and so on, is quite a huge document covering a vast range of penology in the Commonwealth and making a great number of reforms way beyond the question of the actual sentencing of Federal offenders. As I have said, the report made some helpful suggestions about sentencing and in that respect this Bill, subject to my consideration of it, partly implements those recommendations. However, as I have said, they relate to deficiencies in the Crimes Act that have been known for some time. For that reason it is important that the Bill should be passed as soon as possible. The Bill also updates the pecuniary penalties in the Crimes Act which have become very much out of date. That is really another urgent and important part of this legislation, although it was not mentioned by Senator Evans.

The most interesting aspect of it, I believe, is the general statement that imprisonment should be a last resort. I think that is really only stating what is the better view of sentencing and one which is adopted by judges and magistrates who are fully seized of the modern principles of sentencing and of the attitude to imprisonment as against other forms of punishment. Insofar as that proposition has never had legislative endorsement in Australia, this amendment to the Crimes Act will set that standard and I hope will give a lead to legislatures in Australia in adopting that general principle. Hopefully it will make some contribution to a more uniform use of imprisonment throughout Australia, certainly in the Federal sphere, but possibly in the State sphere as well.

The other important aspect is the making available of magistrates and judges who are sentencing Federal offenders of a choice of various alternatives to imprisonment, which have been developed in the State systems in recent years, such as community service orders and so on. These have been rather experimental alternatives to imprisonment in recent years. They seem to have been well received and to have worked well. Certainly they ought to be available to magistrates and judges sentencing people under Federal laws. That has not been possible because of the limitations of the Crimes Act as presently drafted.

All in all I believe it is a useful measure. Senator Evans obviously agrees with that. However, he, in his usual vein, would have wished that the Commonwealth had rubber-stamped the report of the Law Reform Commission. We are familiar with this debate. We have it a number of times in the Senate when Senator Evans takes the view that parliament should really implement the Law Reform Commission reports and I take a very different view, namely, that these reports should be very closely examined by government, and that governments and parliaments are entitled to have their own views in relation to those matters. I believe that law reform commissions are useful bodies which do valuable work and make very valuable suggestions but that the responsiblity for implementing their decisions is that of the Government and the Parliament.

This report, to which Senator Evans referred, is a voluminous document and it ranges over a vast field. It involves the whole subject of penology in Australia and, particularly, the area of State responsibility. A great number of the recommendations in this report are really the basic responsibilities of the States. The State governments have expressed very considerable concern about a number of these recommendations. I have said that apart from the matters dealt with in this amendment these recommendations will be the subject of very detailed consideration with the States before I will propose any implementation of them. They raise in a very major way the matter of prison conditions and prisoners' rights. Of course, Senator Evans will be well aware that the States under the Constitution have the responsibility for accepting into their goals Federal offenders. They are very much State gaols. They are not Federal gaols. No doubt the Federal Government could build its own gaols and, if it was minded, adopt the standards, the rights or prisoners and so on as recommended in the report. I would be interested to know whether Senator Evans and the Australian Labor Party propose to embark upon that course. I can assure the Senate that that is not going to be the course followed by this Government. We intend to proceed along traditional lines in this area. It is the responsibility of the States.

I turn to the rights of certain Federal offenders to parole and other matters. The question whether those rights should be uniform throughout Australia or whether they should be uniform in the particular gaol in which the Federal offender is imprisoned is extremely difficult. People may favour uniform treatment of Federal offenders wherever they are in Australia but there is an equally strong argument-in my view it is a better argument-that the uniformity should be between all the inmates of a particular gaol. One is really looking for serious trouble if one applies different rules to prisoners in the same gaol. These questions are untouched here and unresolved. I believe that they are matters than can be resolved only by lengthy discussions with the States. I do not believe that there are any easy answers to them.

I indicated in my second reading speech that I have written to my colleagues in the States suggesting the establishment, administratively, of a sentencing council comprising State and Federal judges with a view to discussing the matter of sentencing guidelines and, one would hope, uniform sentencing decisions. I have not yet had any reaction to that suggestion but it will no doubt be the subject of early discussion in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. I hope that the Attorneys-General will agree with my proposition that we establish an Australian sentencing council in the not too distant future.

Senator Evans raised the matter of the Government's attitude to the compensation of the victims of crime. That is a matter on which I have been asked questions from time to time. The latest position is that the ordinance has now been drafted. I have it on my desk in the Senate at the moment. Subject to one or two small details to which I want further consideration given, that ordinance is ready to send to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Commonwealth as distinct from the Australian Capital Territory?
—It is in relation to the Australian Capital Territory.
—What is happening as far as the Commonwealth is concerned?

—This ordinance relates only to the Australian Capital Territory because that is where the urgency lies. It is under Australian Capital Territory criminal law that injuries are more likely to occur, whereas under Federal laws generally there is not the same likelihood of injury.
—There are a few areas.

—There are a few but that is the next subject I will look at in this area. I think that covers the major matters that arose in the second reading debate. As I have said, I am very pleased to have had the opportunity to bring forward this measure. I recognise that it is one that has been required for some time. As I have said, the reason for the delay is that the matter was referred to the Law Reform Commission and the Commission's report, although dealing with the subject of sentencing, raised all these other wider subjects as well. There has been a certain diversion of the effort of my officers because we have had to look at the wider issues as well as the specific recommendations in the report. However, the Bill is now with us and I hope it will have a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move together amendments Nos (1), (2) and (3) standing in my name. They are amendments to clauses 6 and 7 of the Bill. There are six amendments altogether. Nos (1) to (3) relate to the subject matter which I canvassed in the second reading debate; Nos (4) and (5) relate to the duration of conditional release orders; and No. (6) relates to the capacity of a probation officer to make application to a court for release of a person from a conditional release obligation. That is the way in which we want to break up the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, clause 6, sub-clause (1), after paragraph (c), add the following new paragraph:
''(d) by adding at the end thereof the following sub-section: '(3) this section has effect subject to section18C.' ''.
(2) Page 5, clause 7, sub-clause (1), proposed new section 18B, sub-section (5), line 18, at beginning of proposed sub-section, insert ''Subject to section 18C,''.
(3) Page 5, clause 7, after sub-section (2) add the following new sub-clause:
''(3) The Principal Act as amended by inserting after section 18B the following section:
Enforcement of orders for imprisonment
'18C (1) In this section, ''fine'' includes pecuniary penalty, costs or other amount of money ordered to be paid.

'(2) An order awarding imprisonment in default of payment of a fine ordered to be paid by an offender (being an offender against a law of the Commonwealth) shall not be carried out unless the court by or before which the offender was convicted directs that the order for imprisonment be carried out.
'(3) The court shall not give a direction under sub-section (1) unless it is satisfied that the offender had the means to pay the fine and wilfully refused to pay it.

'(4) Where the court is satisfied that the failure of an offender to pay a fine was not wilful or was, having regard to the financial circumstances of the offender, not unreasonable, the court may make one or more of the following orders:
(a) an order reducing the amount of the fine;
(b) an order giving the offender time, or further time, within which to pay the fine;
(c) an order awarding any other available punishment, not being an order for imprisonment, in lieu of the fine.

'(5) An application for a direction under sub-section (2) may be made by the person who was the prosecutor in respect of the offence of which the offender was convicted or, by leave of the court, by another person.

'(6) The several courts of the States are by this section invested with federal jurisidiction, and jurisidiction is by this section conferred on the several federal courts and courts of the Territories, to hear and determine applications under this section.'.''.

I endeavoured to canvass the effect of these amendments during the second reading debate and I do not want to repeat that argument, except to say that these arguments are about the insertion of a new section 18C into the Crimes Act to provide that where there is a default in payment of a fine the court is enabled to impose, even at that late stage, a non-custodial penalty as well as further time to pay or as well as a custodial penalty in respect of that default, and, more importantly, the proposed new section 18C imposes an obligation upon the court not to allow the imposition of a custodial sentence for default in payment of a fine except where there is wilful and unreasonable default on the part of the offender. The object of the exercise is to implement that Law Reform Commission recommendation which deals with this matter. The draft before us is squarely based on the Law Reform Commission report. There does not seem to be any great resistance from the Government, so far as I can elicit, to the principle of these amendments because, after all, they are entirely consistent with the thrust of the Commission's report and of the rest of the Bill; namely, to broaden and to make as flexible as possible the range of options open to the sentencing or enforcing judge and to reiterate the emphasis on non-custodial sentencing with its corollary that imprisonment should be only an absolute last resort. For all those reasons, I urge the chamber to support this package of Committee stage amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I would like Senator Evans to clarify the words 'package of amendments'.

—I am referring to amendments Nos (1), (2) and (3) on the sheet which has been circulated, each of which relates to a proposed new section 18C. Amendments Nos (1) and (2) essentially are consequential; the main one is No. (3), which imposes this new provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not prepared to accept these amendments. It is a matter to which a good deal of consideration was given before we adopted the provision in clause 7, which provides for a new section 18B, as set out on page 4 of the Bill. This deals with the way in which the courts may consider the position of a person who has been fined. The new clause provides for an application to pay by instalments to be made by a person who has been fined or, if the fine was to be paid by instalments, by lesser instalments if he does not have the means to pay. Senator Evans's amendment would, of course, go very much further than that and provide that a person should not be imprisoned in default of paying a fine unless the person had the means to pay it and wilfully refused to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of whether a person has the capacity to pay a fine or not really ought to be considered by a court in the first place; but it is, of course, the case that that is not always done and indeed these people's capacity to pay may change. So the reason we adopted what might be considered a fairly cautious approach in proposed new section 18B is that we do not want a situation to develop which could develop if Senator Evans's amendment was the one which was chosen. Indeed, as Senator Evans said, that was based on the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission, but we felt that there were some very practical problems. The effect of the amendment, in our view, would be that a defendant who was fined could neglect to pay the fine and require the prosecution to satisfy the court that the defendant had the means to pay the fine and wilfully refused to pay it. That would be a very time consuming process and the result could be that people, we believe, would be able to get out of paying fines in very many cases.

As I said the proposal in the Bill that we have adopted will afford the opportunity to an offender to seek time to pay the fine by instalments or by reduced instalments and will not place an unreasonable burden on the courts really to ascertain whether the person had the ability to pay and was wilfully in default of paying. I think that would be a very difficult thing to endeavour to prove. I think if we adopted Senator Evans's amendment the use of fines as an alternative to other sentences may be drastically reduced because it would really be so easy for people to avoid paying them. Therefore, that is the reason why we did not adopt the Law Reform Commission's recommendations and why we developed the particular alternative that appears in proposed new section 18B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to ask a question of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). It is something which is as much applicable to the Opposition's amendment as it is to the Government's Bill, and no doubt results from the fact that I am a lay person and not a lawyer. I should like some clarification of the definintion of a person's financial circumstances and his ability to comply with the terms of the conviction or order by which the fine was imposed. How far beyond a person's own assets does the court go when it makes these decisions? The question is prompted by instances that I know of in which people have made over assets and finances and so on to children, spouses or others thereby depriving themselves of a large amount of finance and assets. Will the Attorney-General please explain?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about a discussion which may take place on this matter before a person is fined at all. That question does not arise here. This proposal is simply to give a person who has been fined an opportunity, if the cannot meet the fine as such or the instalments if there has been an order to pay by instalments, to come back to the court and have the matter reviewed. That is our proposition; it does not relate to the original imposition of the fine.

SPEECH.PARA: The question no doubt arises in many cases as to what will be the financial circumstances of the person and his ability to pay. How a court determines that is very much at large. I am not aware of any particular rules as to how a court does so. It is just a matter largely of what the defendent, or his counsel, tells the court about financial circumstances. I think that would be the same way in which this matter would be investigated under either of the proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Haines that I agree with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that the formula here used would be one which would be treated as allowing the court to engage in a very much at large investigation of the person's financial circumstances in the most general sense of that word, enabling the court, for example, to have regard to finance that was not perhaps technically legally in that person's name but rather in the name of another member of the family but to which that person clearly had access for the purpose of discharging a fine. If that is the nature of Senator Haines' concern I think I would share the Attorney's view that the court would have an open-ended capacity to take all that into account rather than just purely technical questions of cash in hand of the person concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to prolong this debate too long, but the fundamental objection I have to the Attorney's response is this: The Government seems willing to pay lip service to the notion of imprisonment as a last resort, but when it comes actually to applying in practice the notion of imprisonment as a last resort the Government in fact retreats from the legislative provisions needed to ensure that imprisonment will in fact be a last resort. We are talking here about a situation in which a person is fined possibly a large sum of money, in default imprisonment perhaps for many months, and trying to devise a formula to deal with what happens when a person is in default of paying that particular fine.
