The provision that is in the Bill, which we do not seek to alter, gives the court power under those circumstances to look again at the fine which has been imposed and to vary the amount of the fine at least by way of giving the accused further time to pay. But it gives the court no more flexibility than that and if ultimately the time to pay runs out, then whatever the degree of wilful default that may be involved on the part of the accused under those circumstances the original sentence of imprisonment in default of paying the fine would apply and the person would just go to gaol.

The Opposition wants to insert a further provision which adds further flexibility, which gives further powers to the court and indeed imposes further responsibilities upon the court in that situation, to re-evaluate a person's financial circumstances if he makes any claim that he has had difficulty in paying the fine and to enable the court not only to allow further time to pay but also to allow the court in those circumstances to impose at that point in the process another form of non-custodial punishment, for example, periodic detention or attendance at a centre or something of that kind. Of course, it may be difficult for a court to determine whether someone has been wilfully defaulting so far as the payment of the fine is concerned. But the way the Attorney left it, one could be forgiven for having the impression that if the court found it self unable to make up its mind on that question, the person would go absolutely scot free. That of course is not the case.

Under the proposed legislation that I am putting, if the court has difficulty in making up its mind as to whether there has been a wilful default, the way it can satisfy itself in practice is to impose a non-financial penalty, another form of non-custodial penalty involving a weekend detention, periodic attendance, work or something of that kind. For all those reasons I do not think there is any practical difficulty about the Government's accepting this amendment. It has been thought through rather carefully. It should be acceptable in principle and I hope that the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the amendment is an eminently reasonable refinement of proposed new section 18B. I might just mention for the information of the Senate that I have had a long experience of, and association with, the idea of non-custodial alternatives for persons who have been sentenced. In fact, it is now 15 years since the idea was introduced in the State of Tasmania on the initiative of the then Attorney-General Mr Max Bingham, after discussions between his Government, that of the succeeding Labor Government, myself as Secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, and various other organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: I consider that what has been put forward by Senator Evans is in fact a refinement of what has been put forward by the Government. It is, as Senator Evans has said, a recognition of the fact that there are in the community some people who may be fined at a particular time at which they are unable to pay the fine. What Senator Evans is doing is to enable the court, in those circumstances, to give full consideration to that fact and vary the sentence, using the new provisions to issue, for example, an attendance centre order, a sentence for Saturday work or what are commonly known as community service orders. That is eminently reasonable.

For my part, I feel that the more messages the legislature can give to the judiciary, that fines must impose a cost that is in relation to the individual's income, the better. In other words, one person might not notice a $2,000 fine, but for another person it might almost mean the destruction of his life. Any message that we can give to the judiciary on those lines is well given and, I hope, received. I support Senator Evans's proposition and will do so when it comes to a vote.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 8, clause 9, sub-clause (1), proposed new section 19B, sub-section (1), paragraph (d), sub-paragraph (i), line 11, leave out '3 years', insert '12 months'.
(5) Page 9, clause 9, sub-clause (1), proposed new section 20, sub-section (1), paragraph (a), sub-paragraph (i), line 20, leave out '5', insert '2'.

The proposed amendments are to clause 9 of the Bill and proposed new sections 19B and 20 respectively. They relate to the maximum periods for which a conditional release order may be imposed. Under the Bill, when someone is made subject to a probation or conditional release order, without an actual conviction being imposed, such order can be made for a maximum of three years. Certainly, that is an improvement on the existing law, but a maximum is nonetheless included. After conviction, where a probation or conditional release order is imposed, the Bill proposes a maximum period of five years. That is certainly an improvement on the present law, which provides no limitation at all as to the period for which a conditional release order can in fact be imposed. It is our object, by these two amendments to reduce the period in both cases-in the first case, the without conviction order, from a maximum of three years to a maximum of 12 months, and in the case of the post-conviction order from a maximum of five years to a maximum of two years.

In both cases, the proposed amendments are based again on the recommendations and arguments of the Law Reform Commission. I propose to indicate briefly in each case what that argument is in the hope that at this stage I may persuade people whose minds might not be closed on the subject. In the case of discharge without conviction, recommendation 42 of the Commission's sentencing report is that there should be a maximum period of 12 months in the case of a discharge order imposed on an offender. The argument is expressed in paragraph 360 in the following terms:
Given the fact that such an order can only be imposed for an offence which is 'trivial' and in which there are 'extenuating circumstances'--
That refers to the way in which the Act is drafted at the moment-

it is doubtful whether an upward limit of three years in relation to a release without conviction would often be appropriate. It has frequently been pointed out, in studies of bond and recognizance systems, that the terms and conditions contained in such sentences can be breached quite readily by relatively minor transgressions. They can create a situation in which, for relatively minor crimes, persons are enmeshed for a very long period in the criminal justice system.

The argument goes on to state that the expression 'good behaviour' is particularly vague in its practical application and can easily be interpreted differently by the offender, by the court, by police, by probation officers and by persons in authority. Given the vagueness of that particular, familiar term in this context, it is inappropriate that someone's behaviour should be subject to the potential operation of the criminal law in this way for such a long period.

As to the situation of discharge after conviction-of someone being subject to a conditional release order of this kind after conviction, but in lieu of imprisonment or perhaps a fine-the amendments, as I have said, propose a maximum of three years rather than the open-ended period presently provided under the Act or the period of five years that is proposed by the Commission. The Commission's argument, as set out in paragraph 369 of the report, is as follows:
Whilst a minimum period should not be set for discharge orders, a maximum time limit should be set of two years for this type of penalty. The research available--
The reference is to Potas's book of 1976 entitled The Legal Basis for Probation--

has shown that the largest proportion of all existing supervised probation orders in Australia are for periods no longer than two years. The second largest proportion of such orders is for periods no longer than one year. Similar findings have been made in the United Kingdom, where it has also been suggested that a maximum time limit on all probation and discharge orders should be two years. A period of two years is sufficient time for discharge orders following conviction, including those involving supervision of an offender. The provision of a maximum period is preferable to the existing unlimited discretion given to courts when sentencing Federal offenders to set any time period they wish in regard to a discharge order following conviction. The longer the period, the less likelihood there is that the offender will benefit, and the greater the danger of his committing minor offences and continuing his involvement in the criminal justice system. Section 20 of the Crimes Act 1914 (Commonwealth) should be amended to provide for such a maximum period.

The maximum period referred to is two years. Those arguments seem to me and to the Opposition to be quite compelling. We are puzzled as to why again, except out of an abundance of conservatism and caution, the Government has apparently resisted that argument. We urge the Senate to accept its force and to support the amendments accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats might like to hear the Government case before they make up their minds. The Government is opposed to these amendments. We have accepted in the amendment the principle that there ought to be an upper limit on the power of the courts to order probation rather than the unlimited provisions that prevail in section 20 of the existing Act. To that extent we agree with the Law Reform Commission. However, whether one chooses a period of three years, five years or one year is very much a matter of judgment. The Government believes that there ought to be a reasonable amount of flexibility in discretion given to magistrates or judges in fixing these terms and that the actual periods that the Law Reform Commission recommended are too short and too restrictive and limit to too great an extent the discretion of judges. For those reasons the Government has chosen the figures that are included in these clauses of the Bill. Anything that Senator Evans has said has not convinced me that they ought to be changed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could have spared the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that explanation since it coincides fairly accurately with ours. While the Australian Democrats are quite happy to support Opposition amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3, we are not prepared to extend that support to amendments Nos 4 and 5--
—You will lose your trendy vote.

—I am sorry; we will leave the trendies to Senator Evans. I am sure he will know better what to do with them. It seems to me that if part of Senator Evans's argument rests on the basis that a good behaviour bond is defined by different people in different ways, the answer to that is to make sure that communications are better and that the offender in particular has a precise idea of just exactly what is meant if a good behaviour bond is applied to him.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of cutting back the maximum sentence applying under clause 9 which refers to the discharge of offenders without proceeding to conviction, I cannot see a great deal of benefit in lowering the period from three years to 12 months. There does not seem to be any point in decreasing a maximum sentence when the maximum is hardly enormous. As the Attorney-General has just pointed out, such a step would diminish the number of options available to the court. It overlooks the fact that an upper limit is not a mandatory term but a potential maximum. It seems to me that it could lead in some instances to the courts choosing to err on the severe side-that is in not opting for the good behaviour bond in the first instance if the maximum is only one year, which is really a very short period. I think the same argument applies to the conditional release of offenders after conviction. The Opposition's amendment No. 5 proposes that the maximum term be lowered from five years to two years. If the court wishes to make it two years it can do so regardless of whether the maximum is three years, four years, five years or two years. Again, I support the Attorney's assertion that such a proposal could tie the hands of the courts, that it could limit their options to an unnecessary extent. We do not support the two amendments.
Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I short circuit this by saying that the Government will accept Senator Evans's sixth amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is marvellous. I would not wish to disrupt that decision by saying anything that could possibly undermine it except to move formally amendment No. 6 standing in my name. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 13, clause 9, sub-clause (1), proposed new section 20AA, sub-section (1), leave out proposed sub-section, insert the following sub-section:

'(1) Where a person has entered into a recognizance in pursuance of an order made under sub-section 19B (1) or 20 (1), an authorized person, the person who entered into the recognizance, a surety for the last-mentioned person or, where a condition of the order is that the person will be subject to the supervision of a probation officer appointed in accordance with the order, the probation officer so appointed, may apply to the court by which the order was made for the discharge of the recognizance or for a variation of its terms.'.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits-Alleged Human Rights Violations: Czechoslovakia

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Senate and the other place deal with extremely important issues from time to time. However, I do not wish to raise one of those. In fact, I wish to raise a very minor issue, one which is of very little importance to the nation as a whole. However, I think it is the type of issue which concerns many people in this country in their day-to-day lives. I think this is best put in a letter I received from a constituent that spells out in very clear detail what is happening to thousands of people in this country. I would like to read sections of the letter because I think it expresses better than I could the position that these people are in. After some introductory remarks, the person wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I have never felt compelled to complain before-perhaps I have been too apathetic-but I would like to tell you what happened to my husband recently-a war-blinded, ex-P.O.W. in Changi, he was critically wounded in Singapore, where he remained with little or no medical treatment.

My husband, . . . volunteered to protect this country. He was 35, strong, virile, full of the joy of living, holding a good job. He came back from the hell hole, broken in health but not in spirit. I don't think I know anyone who has been so courageous in the face of such odds-but I know there are 1000s more like him. We, his family, gave him all the support he needed, even tho' for many years it was hell on earth trying to help him adjust and to see his frustration. He has been in and out of hospital like a yo-yo for most of the time. You know, he even lost his manhood during those awful years in Changi-something we have had to live with all this time. We thank God for the support of our family. Never did my dear husband complain and fought desperately to rehabilitate himself. We battled through rearing and educating three sons, . . .

We are proud of our sons who all hold good positions . . . to help them achieve their goals we had to live from week to week. We had our first holiday since the war in 1969, when my husband was 65 and I was 58; that was paid for by our sons.

We never were able to have any money in the bank until this year, when we had approximately $6,000 about the time I filled in the income assessment forms-I have always been honest with the department but I was foolish in not stating that about $2,000 of that money was about to be paid out in accounts like insurance, house, furniture, car, light, phone, rates etc., plus our living expenses. As my husband had just come out of an 8 week spell in hospital, and is even unable to water the garden, I decided to buy a little boat for him, and one son gave us a small motor for it. A kind neighbour was going to take him out on the lake to help him fill in his day. The boat cost me $500. My dear husband then insisted I buy myself a comfortable chair for my 70th birthday-$400. We also had hoped to go to Western Australia at Christmas to visit our son who lives there.

I know I have been a long time getting to the point, but I am so angry. We received a letter about a month ago telling my husband because of the interest we received, his service pension had been cut by $1.30 a week. The interest, by the way, amounted to $65 for the year. I think this is so paltry, and we probably won't miss the $1.30. Another thing I omitted to tell them is that we are, and have been for years, supporting two World Vision children out of our pension.

I think when one gets a letter like that-probably most honourable senators have received such letters from time to time-one feels so frustrated that our bureaucracy and our organisation in terms of the support that we give people in this country can be so paltry, so mean and so debased as to take $1.30 from people like that. It is not a matter of economics because as every honourable senator here knows, it probably costs upwards of $15 to process that $1.30. Yet this is what we do and this is what we continue to do. There are thousands upon thousands of people who have, as these people have, sacrificed for their country, who have worked hard, who have paid their taxes and who have asked for little. Yet when we get to that stage when indeed we should be supportive of our senior citizens, our ex-service people and other people such as that, we set about prying into their lives, asking them to fill out forms and, of course, if they are honest we then set about penalising them, as this person has said, by taking away $1.30 a week.

I do not think this person is unexceptional. I think the point is-I have spoken to her since she wrote me the letter-the fact that she can seek to help others despite the enormous burden shows the type of people that we have in this country, people who are generous and who will go out of their way to support other people whom they see as less advantaged than themselves. But I think it says little for our Government; it says little for this country, if in fact we can then turn around and penalise such people such paltry amounts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is some time since I spoke in the adjournment debate. I do so only when I gather it is most necessary as I do on this occasion. I raise with the Government and with the appropriate authorities my concern about certain people who appear to have been unjustly persecuted by the authorities in Czechoslovakia. I refer to the following persons who were arrested on 10 September 1979 but who, on the intervention of Pope John Paul II, were temporarily released. They were subsequently arrested again and they have stood trial and have received certain sentences. The persons to whom I refer are Father Frantisek Lizna S.J., Father Rudolf Smahel, Jan Krumpholc, Josef Vlcek and Josef Adamek. They have been charged with illicit trading under paragraph 118/1 of the penal code because the authorities preferred not to admit that it is illegal to print the Pope's encyclical 'Redemptor Hominis' which is the Pope's letter in 1979 to all priests.

SPEECH.PARA: In brief, Father Lizna was sentenced to 20 months imprisonment and he is awaiting another trial. Jan Krumpholc, who is 54, was sentenced to three years imprisonment. He has since broken his leg. I make the point about the latter, that he and his wife in fact took two foster children out of an orphanage and gave them a great deal of support. There is testimony from people who were dealing with these children to the effect that these parents gave such loving care to these children that there was a remarkable improvement in them since they came to the Krumpholc home. This man was sentended to three years on that outlandish charge; imprisoned and taken away from those children. Josef Adamek, who is 67, and Josef Vlcek, who is 61, received 20 months and in view of their ages that could mean the death sentence. Adamek is the father of 11 children.

Father Smahel, who is 31 years of age, is a member of the Salesian order. Those honourable members who know of the Salesian order would recognise the great work that it does, particularly with poorer families and in the development of skilled trades. I am not sure whether the order is involved in that way in Czechoslovakia, but it is certainly involved in that way in other areas and its work is important to particular countries. Father Smahel received two years imprisonment for receiving some money from a West German priest and not reporting it to the authorities within 14 days. He was not aware of that law. All the persons I have mentioned have been charged, tried and sentenced on trumped up charges because the authorities prefer not to admit that they consider it to be illegal to print the Pope's encyclical.

The other person whom I wish to mention tonight is Jan Litomisky of Vyskytna, who was detained on 17 February 1981 and charged under paragraph 98-1 of the Czechoslovak penal code with attempting to subvert the republic. This person is a member of VONS, the Committee for the Defence of the Unjustly Persecuted. In fact, he has peacefully drawn attention to possible violations of Czechoslovak law by Czechoslovak authorities. For this he has been detained. This is a matter of concern that I raise in the Senate. I am not too sure what has finally happened to this person, other than that he was detained in February 1981 and was told by his interrogator that his crime was his membership of VONS.

For the same charge Rudolph Battek-a fellow member of VONS-received 7 1/2 years imprisonment at the end of July 1981. These people are really prisoners of conscience. As honourable senators would know, these matters are given consideration from time to time by Amnesty International. I think it is important that they be aired from time to time in the parliaments of the democratic world in the hope that some people in authority will take note of them and recognise that the people of Australia feel that citizens of this type are not acting contrary to the interests of their countries. Basic human rights, such as freedom of religion and freedom to express opinions, should be safeguarded. I thought I should take this opportunity to raise this matter in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has brought to our attention the question of persecutions and the captivity of persons in Czechoslovakia. Of course, it is well known that he has a special interest in these matters. He is well known amongst the communities in Australia of persons from captive nations, if that is the correct term, for his activities in those areas. Knowing nothing of the cases he has brought to our attention, I think that the best thing I can do is refer the matter to the relevant Ministers and seek some more information for Senator Harradine about the various claims that he made.

SPEECH.PARA: I take it that the remarks of Senator Macklin were aimed more at the general propositions with regard to the effect of the income test on service pensions and, by implication, age pensions in the social security area. They are matters of very broad concern and policy. The Government's policy is to apply the income test as defined at present. Naturally, it is a Budget matter which would need consideration at the appropriate time for any change to occur. As to the individual case to which Senator Macklin referred, if there is any suggestion that the test has been wrongly applied in the case of his constituent, I would appreciate it if he could provide us with the details and a copy of the letter so that we can ensure that the matter is investigated and see whether, in fact, the test has been correctly applied.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.16 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does reciprocal recognition exist between the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters (NAATI) and State Government Ethnic Authorities in connection with the status and grading of translators and interpreters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters (NAATI) was established in 1977 with the objective of prescribing the standards and conditions leading to professional status for translators and interpreters in Australia. NAATI has determined five levels of competence at which interpreters and translators may be accredited.
NAATI is the only Authority which accredits interpreters and translators Australia-wide and its accreditation is generally recognised by employees.

Because of the size of the Authority's task (it has received approximately 5500 applications since its inception from interpreters and translators seeking accreditation in more than 80 languages at Levels I to V in both interpreting and translating) NAATI has not yet been able to arrange tests in all languages or at all levels for which there is a demand. However, the national testing program for October 1981-July 1982 aims to test as many as possible of the remaining applicants.

Generally, State Government employment authorities require applicants for interpreting and translating positions to have NAATI accreditation at Level II or Level III. In those cases where NAATI has not tested in the language or at the level required, some States Governments conduct their own tests. These tests are not recognised by NAATI, but interpreters and translators are able to apply to NAATI for recognition which may be granted with status at Level II where they are able to provide proof that they are working as interpreters or translators.

As with any profession whose practitioners are not bound by law to be registered before they are able to practise, employers are not required to insist that applicants have NAATI accreditation. However, experience has shown that as more interpreters and translators are accredited by NAATI, employing authorities will increasingly require accreditation by NAATI as a pre-requisite for appointment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How does the Government intend to define the term 'initial tertiary qualification' for the purpose of imposing tuition fees at tertiary education institutions, as announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions.
(2) Will the Minister for Education list the 'recognised double degree or diploma combinations' which are to be exempt from fees.

(3) Will the Minister, in relation to the loans scheme to be introduced from the beginning of 1982 as a supplement to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, advise whether the scheme will be available equally to all tertiary students.
(4) Will students be required to obtain a guarantor for loans provided under the scheme.
(5) What amounts will students be able to borrow under the scheme, and how many years will be allowed for repayment.
(6) What will be the interest rates on the loans, and will interest be calculated at a flat rate or on the reducing balance.
(7) Will students be required to make repayments of (a) the interest and/or (b) the principal during their studies.

(8) Would the Minister clarify the meaning of the statement in the Government's announcement that eligibility for the Adult Secondary Assistance Scheme would be ''restricted to those needing qualifications for employment''.

(9) Will the Minister, in relation to the Government's decision to bring about the amalgamation of several colleges of advanced education by the end of 1981, guarantee that the total number of student places available in tertiary institutions will not be reduced as a result of the amalgamations.
(10) Has the Government estimated the cost of carrying out the amalgamations; if so, what is the estimated cost.

(11) Why has the Government decided to close a number of engineering schools, and did the Government undertake a labour power study of the need for engineers in Australia as a whole before embarking on this course of action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For the purpose of exemption from tuition fees a student will be regarded as having obtained an initial tertiary qualification where he or she has completed the requirements for a degree, or an undergraduate diploma or an equivalent overseas qualification or an approved combined course.

(2) My Department has prepared a draft explanatory statement which has been sent to State authorities and institutions for comment on any points requiring clarification. The statement provides details of exemptions including lists of approved courses.

(3) to (7) In preparation for the introduction of the loans scheme, which will enable students to supplement their income by amounts which will be repayable after graduation, Ministers have been considering such questions as eligibility and administration. There have been fruitful discussions between Commonwealth officials and representatives of the Australian Bankers Association. Some aspects of the scheme have still to be settled which may cause problems in having the scheme operating at the beginning of 1982 but the Government is firm in its intention to set up a loans scheme as a supplement to existing forms of student assistance.

(8) The Government's decision that eligibility under the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme will be restricted to those needing qualifications for employment will mean that as from 1 January 1982, only applicants who have indicated an employment objective for which completion of matriculation level studies is considered to be essential or highly desirable will be eligible for consideration under the scheme. Acceptable employment objectives will include those requiring completion of a tertiary qualification for which matriculation is a prerequisite. It will be necessary in future for the employment objective to be stated on the application form.

(9) One of the objectives of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in proposing a program of consolidation of single purpose teacher education institutions into larger, more broadly based institutions was to increase the flexibility available within higher education in responding to changing needs. The result of the amalgamations will be that, within the Commission's planning ranges for the student places for the 1982-84 triennium which is similar to that for the current triennium, institutions will be able to meet increased demand in some fields of study, particularly the technologies and business studies, while adjusting to reduced demand in other fields.

(10) The Government expects that costs which are associated with the amalgamation of colleges will be met from within the funds available, and that overall the amalgamations will result in savings which will be applied elsewhere in the tertiary education sectors to bring about the re-distribution of resources required under the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Guidelines.

(11) In its 'Report for 1982-84 Triennium', the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission commented (paragraph 4.22) on proposals to rationalise the provision of engineering courses in Victoria. It stated that, in view of the large number of engineering schools in Victoria and the small size of some of them, some rationalisation was required if the quality of engineering education was to be maintained. It expressed the view that, given the small size of the schools involved, the effect of such rationalisation on output of engineers would be small and the more effective use of resources which would be possible was likely to increase the overall capacity of higher education to meet Australia's future needs for well qualified professional and other technological manpower. The Government supports the Commission's view.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Education been advised that the executive of the Australian Teachers Federation carried a resolution in June which was highly critical of the Commonwealth Government guidelines detailing Government decisions on spending programmes for schools in 1980.
(2) Is the Minister aware that other sections of the community such as parents and citizens associations are similarly concerned.

(3) Will the Minister be prepared to discuss the terms of the resolution of the executive of the Australian Teachers Federation with State Ministers for Education, with a view to bringing about a more equitable approach to educational expenditure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Various organisations and individuals have made known to me their views over aspects of the Government's 1982 guidelines for the education programs administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

(3) The views of all State Ministers for Education were taken into account in the development of the Government's policy and guidelines for schools programs for 1982. The views of the State Ministers have also been taken into account in the Government's consideration of the Commonwealth Schools Commission Report for 1982, prepared in response to the guidelines issued in June.

It cannot be claimed that the distribution of Commonwealth funds for schools in 1982 is inequitable. Much of the 1982 allocation reflects the needs basis of Commonwealth funding for all schools. About 86 per cent of the increased allocation for non-government schools in 1982 will go to the low resource schools classified at Level 6 by the Commonwealth Schools Commission.
The major policy objective underlying Commonwealth programs is to assist all schools to reach and maintain high standards of operation with no greater priority for one sector than another.

The combined resources of the States and the Commonwealth have resulted in great improvements in per pupil resource standards in government schools. While standards have also improved in non-government schools, the Commonwealth Schools Commission has reported that the great majority of such schools are still operating at about 70 per cent of average government school resource levels per pupil. The Commonwealth is concerned to ensure that freedom of choice and equality of opportunity continue to apply to all Australian school children.

If the total expenditure of taxpayers' funds on a per pupil basis is looked at, it is shown that the taxpayer is spending more than double the amount on education a student in a government school that is being spent in non-government schools: about an additional $1,000 per pupil in favour of government schools.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware of the delay experienced by community radio station 7CAE-FM in obtaining approval to set up a translator to improve the appalling reception in a significant part of its listening area.
(2) Did the Minister make a statement saying that the delay was due to the fact that there were 500 proposals relating to broadcasting and television services under consideration by his Department.

(3) Will the Minister find out how many of the 500 proposals relate to making essential improvements to existing services, and to equipment already bought and ready for installation, as is the case with the 7CAE-FM proposal.

(4) Will the Minister ask the Department to select such proposals for speedy consideration to ensure that existing services can be viable and do not discriminate amongst people in the relevant listening areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the problems being experienced by public broadcasting station 7CAE-FM. The coverage of 7CAE is inferior to that of the other public broadcasting station in Hobart (7HFC-FM). This inferior coverage extends across the bulk of the station's service area and my Department is presently endeavouring to determine the most appropriate means whereby 7CAE's coverage may be improved.

It may well be that the installation of a translator would improve reception in certain areas. However, it may also be necessary for the station to undertake various other corrective measures to improve its coverage overall.

My Department will be negotiating with the management of 7CAE in the near future with a view to reaching a conclusion, which would be acceptable to me amd the station, with regard to improving the station's overall coverage.

(2) My Department presently has registered in excess of 500 projects relating to the establishment of new broadcasting and television services or revised operating conditions of existing broadcasting and television services, and the number of expression of interest in establishing new services or revising operating conditions of existing services is growing.

(3) Amongst the projects registered, in excess of 350 relate to requests directly associated with improving reception of existing stations, either through the use of translators or by varying the operating conditions of the actual station concerned.

(4) As mentioned earlier, in the case of radio station 7CAE, the Department is soon to endeavour to prepare a suitable plan to improve the overall coverage of 7CAE. It is anticipated that a recommendation to this effect will be with me by end of this year. Most of the proposals presently registered by the Department relate in some way or another to either improving reception of existing stations or providing new services to areas where the choice of broadcasting or television services is limited or non-existent.

I am concerned about the delays evident in processing applications for new services or varied operating conditions to existing services and have directed the Department to examine the present procedures relating to planning and to make recommendations concerning streamlining the planning approach to enable proposals to be processed more quickly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister for Education explain the net benefit of (a) setting fees for second and higher degrees, and (b) the student loan scheme; and (c) give details of the amount of fees raised less cost of raising the revenue.
(2) What effect will the introduction of fees have in being a disincentive for Australians to get higher education and thus gain skills that will make them more productive citizens.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Concerning the net benefit of tuition fees in financial terms, on the basis of 1980 emrolments it is estimated that the partial introduction of tuition fees will result in revenue of about $8 million in 1982. It is not known to what extent enrolments in 1982 will be affected by fees. A benefit will accrue to taxpayers in that they will not bear the full cost of future studies now that students will be expected to make some contribution towards the cost of their tuition.

(b) The proposed tertiary student loans scheme will benefit students by providing a form of assistance additional to that provided under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS), thus widening opportunities for students to obtain support while studying. I cannot give further details about the proposed scheme at present as negotiations with the banks and tertiary institutions are not yet complete.

(c) See (a) for estimation of revenue in 1982. I would expect that the collection of fees would occur as part of the normal enrolment procedures adopted by the various institutions and for this reason it is not possible to calculate the costs of fee collection separately from the administrative costs involved in enrolment.

(2) It remains to be seen whether the limited reintroduction of tertiary tuition fees in 1982 will have any disincentive effect. It would serve no useful purpose to speculate at this stage. As I observed in answer to part (1) of the question, it is not known to what extent enrolments in 1982-or in subsequent years-will be affected by fees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Of the 1,200 Aboriginal people in Central Australia served by the Pitjantjatjara Homelands Health service: (a) do 98 per cent live in corrugated iron and canvas 'wiltjas' or in the open; (b) do 96 per cent have no access to bathing facilities; (c) do 69 per cent have to carry water more than 50 metres to their homes.
(2) What programs to provide adequate housing, water outlets and bathing facilities for these people are being implemented.

(3) Within what timescale does the Department of Aboriginal Affairs expect to be able to bring the standard of housing and essential facilities to an acceptable level for the Pitjantjatjara people of the Central Reserves.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) The statistics quoted have not been verified, but are not disputed. People have moved to homeland centres in recent years in the knowledge that a full range of services would not be available and indeed one of the aims of many people moving back to their homelands has been to lead a more traditional style of life. The provision of fixed housing and water reticulation at every camp site would not be compatible with a traditional life-style and the initial programs developed in consultation with each group have concentrated on the provision of basic water supplies, communications, transport and health services.

Future housing programs will be developed in consultation between the individual groups and the Aboriginal Development Commission. My Department is continuing to make grants for the improvement of water supplies, on the basis of plans developed in discussion with the groups about their priorities. The following amounts have been allocated for such improvements:
Communities

An amount of $150,000 has been provided for a further program of bore drilling in 1981-82 and this is likely to lead to future decentralisation from some of the larger, established centres like Pipalyatjara.

Programs of assistance to new and established homeland centres will continue to be developed by my Department and the Commission on the basis of the needs expressed by the particular groups concerned and in consultation with them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the funds for the Willuna Emu Farm in Western Australia been withdrawn; if so why.
(2) Was alternative funding sought for this project.

(3) Will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ensure that when a group of Aboriginal people who are determined to work for their money have brought a scheme to the brink of fruition every encouragement is given to them to continue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) No. Funding for the project will be provided by my Department for the Financial year 1981-82 to allow the Aboriginal Development Commission time to determine the level of its involvement in the project.
(3) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Primary Industry's attention been drawn to the discovery of dangerous levels of dioxin in a batch of 2,4,5-T manufactured in Western Australia.
(2) What guarantee can the Minister give that excessive levels of dioxin in 2,4,5-T have not already been sprayed into the food chain.
(3) What guarantee can he also give that such levels of dioxin in this chemical cannot escape detection in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that testing co-ordinated by the Department of Primary Industry had identified the presence of a dioxin level in a batch of 2,4,5-T produced in Western Australia which exceeded the 0.1 mg/kg limit recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Standards Association of Australia. The level found was 0.39 mg/kg. I am advised that recall procedures were instituted following the discovery.

(2) I am advised that the batch in question was supplied to New South Wales State Government authorities, namely the Forestry Commission, Prickly Pear Destruction Commission and the Soil Conservation Service, and that a substantial proportion of the batch has been recalled.

(3) Existing monitoring arrangements which are co-ordinated by the Department of Primary Industry and which resulted in the detection of the current batch will continue in consultation as necessary with State authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 15 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: In the cases before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where the Tribunal has recommended payment(s) by the Department of Social Security, has the Department made the recommended payments to the applicants:
(a) in full; (b) in part; or (c) not at all.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Social Security has made, or is arranging to make, payment in full of any monies recommended to be paid by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in cases in which it has reviewed decisions of the Director-General of Social Services or his delegate, except in those cases in which the Tribunal has recommended the making of an ex gratia payment. In the latter cases, details of the Tribunal's recommendations have been provided to the Department of Finance in order that the Minister for Finance or a person authorized by the Minister for Finance might consider making an act of grace payment pursuant to section 34A of the Audit Act 1901. Payments for which specific provision does not exist cannot be made under the Social Services Act. Such payments have to be considered on an act of grace basis pursuant to the provisions of the Audit Act.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Trade and Resources: Revenue

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister's Department aware of any information disclosed in submissions to it, advice available to it or public documents such as Auditor-General's Reports, which suggests that the Department and instrumentatlities under the Minister's responsibility are forgoing revenue because of insufficient staff.
(2) How much revenue is alleged to have been forgone.
(3) Approximately how much revenue does the Department estimate may have been forgone.

(5) What has been done to improve the situation.
(6) What are the details of any staff re-arrangements that have been made as a result of action in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) to (6) inclusive. Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who were the members of the committee of inquiry appointed to examine Commonwealth and State meat inspection systems.
(2) When was the inquiry initiated.
(3) When did the inquiry tender its report to the Minister for Primary Industry.
(4) What action has been taken in respect of each of the Committee's recommendations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The members of the Committee of Inquiry appointed to examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems were the Honourable C. R. Kelly C.M.G., Chairman and Mr W. A. Buettel, member.
(2) The establishment of the inquiry was approved by Cabinet on 15 November 1978.
(3) The report was presented to the Minister for Primary Industry on 11 February 1980 and tabled in the House of Representatives on 27 February 1980.

(4) The major thrust of the Committee's report was directed to the recommendation that an Australian Meat Inspection Service (AMIS) be established. Other recommendations followed from the adoption of this principal recommendation.
The AMIS proposal was subsequently examined by all States and the Northern Territory but rejected by a number of States.

Subsequently the Commonwealth in conjunction with the States has been examining other options which may lead to improved meat inspection arrangements. To that end the Commonwealth and Victoria are currently fully investigating a proposal for a joint Commonwealth-Victoria Meat Inspection Authority.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 553) Senator Sibraa asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned a report in the Sydney Morning Herald on the discovery of horse meat in export beef cartons of the Profreeze company by the Victorian Department of Agriculture.

ANSWER.PARA: I answered the honourable senator at that time and clarified my original answer to the Senate when further information became available (Hansard, page 578).
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

A considerable number of cartons of meat of the Profreeze company destined for the domestic market were examined whilst in cold storage. Although labelled as beef, the cartons were found to contain dye-stained horsemeat, presumably of knackery origin. These cartons of meat presented a serious threat to human health in that nothing was known of the disease status of the animals butchered not of the cleanliness of the premises in which it had been produced. All cartons were subsequently destroyed by rendering under the control of the Australian Federal Police and the Victorian State Department of Agriculture.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1981 (Hansard, page 728) Senator Robertson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the interstate movement of horse meat as pet meat from the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Northern Territory Department of Primary Production advises that a large quantity of horse meat regularly leaves the Northern Territory as pet meat. The Department also advises that, at present, there is no requirement for the registration of shooters or dealers in pet meat in the Northern Territory, but that new legislation is under consideration which may include such a provision.

Meetings at both ministerial and officer level have taken place between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. All parties are aware of the problems currently faced by the meat industry and are conscientiously addressing the matters raised.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1981 (Hansard, Page 722) Senator Coleman asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. Her question concerned the export of chicken meat from Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Department of Primary Industry does not provide inspection for export poultry meat and does not certify it as having been inspected. Rather certification is to the effect that the poultry has been killed and packed in export registered premises. This is accepted by those countries which import out poultry meat, hence the trade referred to by the honourable senator.

Contamination of poultry meat by salmonella bacteria cannot be detected by visual examination, requiring instead laboratory tests. Countries which import Australian poultry meat do not require such tests, and so there are no plans to introduce them with respect to export product. In regard to the domestic market, this is a matter for appropriate State or Territory authorities.

Salmonella bacteria are widely distributed and may contaminate poultry meat at various points in the distribution chain. However they are readily killed by adequate cooking and do not pose a health hazard under normal circumstances. The Department of Primary Industry therefore considers present controls adequate and has no proposals at this stage to increase its involvement in the poultry meat industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1981 (Hansard, page 844) Senator Macklin asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. He asked:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) whether I had taken note of the latest Bureau of Agricultural Economics' index of prices which shows farm inflation running 14.5 per cent in 12 months to June 1981;
(ii) could I inform the Senate of the Government's estimate of the inflationary effect that the sales tax increases announced in the Budget will have on farm costs; and
(iii) what other effects the Budget is likely to have on the inflation rate for farmers?
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:
(i) The Bureau of Agricultural Economics Index of Prices Paid by Farmers registered an increase of 14.5 per cent in the 12 months endang June 1981.

(ii) Primary producers are edigible to claim exemption from sales tax for most of their purchased inputs. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has estimated that the direct effect of the sales tax increases announced in the 1981-82 Budget will be a rise of 0.1 per cent in the BAE Index of Prices Paid by Farmers over a 12 months period.
(iii) The principal strategy of the Government in its 1981-82 Budget is to contain inflation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Communications been drawn to the action of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations in banning certain commercials produced by the New South Wales Health Commission.

(2) Did the commercials highlight the dangers of over-eating and obesity and were they part of a campaign by the Health Commission to impress on the public that two-thirds of serious health problems are the result of lifestyle behaviour of Australians.

(3) Has the Government indicated its displeasure concerning this action to the Federation; if not, will it do so in the strongest terms and draw attention to the responsibility commercial television stations have to consumers in return for use of the public airwaves.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) I believe the Health Commission claimed this to be the intention of the commercials.

(3) I have discussed the points raised by the honourable senator with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which is responsible for the oversight of the operations of commercial television stations and the administration of standards relating to television advertising. Following a request from the New South Wales Crown Solicitor, acting on behalf of the New South Wales Health Commission, the Tribunal examined the advertisements rejected by FACTS. In its Decision and Reasons issued on 9 July, the Tribunal found, pursuant to section 101 of the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, that one of the advertisements, 'Fruit', was objectionable in its present form because of the 'strong sexual overtones and suggestions', but that the other two-'Family' and 'Fat Man'-would not be offensive, nor objectionable nor that they contravened the Television Program and Advertising Standards.
The Tribunal also observed that it encourages self-regulation where possible and does not desire to interfere in the self-regulatory process.

The decision to broadcast any particular commercial is essentially for commercial television licensees. Neither the Government nor the Tribunal has the power or intention to oblige commercial television stations to broadcast specific items.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that the Queensland Deputy Commissioner for Veterans' Affairs has assured doctors and staff at the Repatriation General Hospital, Greenslopes, that he supports every word they have said regarding the problems at that hospital.
(2) Is the Minister planning to accept an invitation from the same doctors to visit the Greenslopes Hospital to acquaint himself more fully with those problems.
(3) Has the Queensland Deputy Commissioner for Veterans' Affairs communicated his support of these doctors to the Minister.
(4) If not, will the Minister ascertain his Deputy Commissioner's attitude on this issue.
(5) If so, what steps is the Minister considering to find a solution to the problems at this hospital.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Deputy Commissioner has advised me that he met with two representatives of the Medical Officers' Association and two representatives of the Specialists' Association in his office on Friday 4 September 1981. At that meeting the only assurance he gave was that he would convey their strong recommendations to the Department's Central Office, on ways and means as they saw it, of preventing a fall in the high standard of patient care. He subsequently did so.

(2) I have no immediate plans to visit the hospital but have been kept fully informed of the problems as doctors see them, relating to the numbers of community patients at the hospital and the charging policies of the hospital.
(3) and (4) See (1) above.

(5) The patient numbers and various types of clinical cases have been kept under review and since 1 September 1981 there has been no appreciable effect as the result of the charging policies on the community patient mix. There has been some reduction inattendances at the Emergency Accident Centre. I am keeping the matter under review, but at this juncture, trends do not support the concern expressed by the doctors.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) At the recent Outlook Conference on Agriculture, did the Minister for Primary Industry say that the cost of the grain embargo on Russia, recently lifted, must be borne by the whole Australian community and not only primary producers.
(2) Has the New South Wales Yellow Maize Marketing Board, in line with this statement, asked for payment of more than $50,000 compensation for losses due to the embargo.
(3) Has the Minister for Finance already rejected a claim for compensation by maize growers.
(4) What is the Minister's response to the suggestion that the New South Wales Oilseeds Marketing Board should also apply for compensation.
(5) Has the New South Wales Yellow Maize Marketing Board stated that it received repeated assurances from the Federal Government, some by telex from Mr Nixon, that it would receive compensation.
(6) Were guidelines drawn up by the Government some four months after the embargo was announced designed to exclude as many claims as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that at the National Agricultural Outlook Conference on 29 January 1980 the Minister for Primary Industry indicated that, if there were costs to pay as a result of the restrictions imposed on the sale of grain to the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics in support of similar United States restrictions in response to the situation in Afghanistan, the costs must be borne by the whole Australian community, and not just by primary producers.

(2) The Yellow Maize Marketing Board for the State of New South Wales (Maize Board) sought compensation of $89,533, which amount included $36,000 owing by it to the Oilseeds Marketing Board for the State of New South Wales (Oilseeds Board) as a result of undertakings provided by the Maize Board on 19 February 1980. The Maize Board subsequently indicated to me that it had advised the Oilseeds Board to take the matter up with the Government direct and sought compensation of $53,533 in respect of its other costs.

(3) The Government has rejected the Maize Board's claim for compensation. No other claims for compensation were received from maize growers (or indeed other primary industry bodies or producers) as a result of the Government's decision to support the US partial embargo on grain sales to the USSR.

(4) Following the Maize Board's letter informing me (a copy of which the Maize Board sent to the Oilseeds Board) that it had advised the Oilseeds Board to take up the matter of its outstanding debt directly with the Government, the Oilseeds Board wrote to me indicating that it did not have, nor would it have, a claim for compensation against the Commonwealth Government for $36,000 owing to it by the Maize Board; that it had never requested the Maize Board to make a claim against the Commonwealth Government on its behalf; and that it wished to disassociate itself completely and absolutely from the Maize Board's letter to me.

(5) I am advised that the Maize Board was never provided with assurances that it would receive compensation. Consistent with the Minister for Primary Industry's statement to the 1980 National Agricultural Outlook Conference, the Minister provided telex advice to the Maize Board on 31 January and 26 February 1980 that he was prepared to take a demonstrated case of loss to the Government for consideration. The Minister also indicated the evidence the Board would need to provide to enable the Government to assess any losses claimed. In particular, the Minister indicated that it would be necessary for the Board to provide detailed documentary evidence of relevant market circumstances prior to and after 5 January 1980, the date President Carter announced the US restrictions on grain sales to the USSR.

In terms of the advice provided by the Minister for Primary Industry, the relevant question is whether the on-farm returns to growers were less than they would have been in the absence of the embargo. On the basis of figures provided by the Maize Board, this was not the case. Because a premium domestic market had developed at the same time as a result of the drought feed requirement, the actual on-farm returns to growers associated with the proposed exports were above the returns that would have resulted from the embargoed USSR sale. Growers were therefore not disadvantaged by the Minister for Primary Industry's decision to disallow the proposed sale.

(6) As announced by the Prime Minister on 13 June 1980, the compensation guidelines were drawn up having regard to the essential principles which had been applied in consideration of such ex gratia payments by the Government over the last decade or so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the actual expenditure in 1980-81 prices, in each of the following areas in each Budget since 1975-76 (including the estimated expenditure for the financial year 1981-82): (a) assistance to industry; (b) investment allowance; (c) trading stock valuation adjustment; and (d) double depreciation.
(2) What percentage of Federal Budget outlay has each such area constituted since 1975-76 up to the 1981-82 Budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Assistance to industry is provided in a number of ways which include direct outlays and taxation concessions such as those mentioned by the honourable senator. Direct assistance and assistance through such concessions have similar effects on the Budget outcome, the former on the outlays side and the latter on the receipts side. Taxation concessions are, indeed, often called 'tax expenditures'.

Year by year, in Statement No. 3 of Budget Paper No. 1, a figure is given for what is described as 'net direct industry assistance'. This constitutes predonderantly direct outlays and can, therefore, be costed with a high degree of accuracy from Government accounts. Similarly, at first in Statement No. 3 but more recently in Statement No. 4, assistance to industry through the taxation system is summarised. Estimates are not, and cannot be, given for every form of assistance and, where estimates are given, the degree of accuracy varies with the concession.

Particular difficulties attach to estimating the cost to revenue of concessions like double depreciation which do not confer greater deductions over the life of an asset than would otherwise be allowed but do allow alterations of timing. The estimates of revenue forgone in respect of double depreciation that have been included in the Budget documents and in the table below represent the immediate impact on income tax revenue of the deduction in each of the years concerned.
I note that the cost to revenue of a taxation concession, not being a Budget outlay in a strict sense, can be expressed as a proportion of Budget outlays proper only in an analogous way.

I note also that the extent to which assistance 'provided' through a particular category of direct outlay or a particular taxation concession is reflected in the Budgetary aggregates of a financial year can? (and, in the case of taxation concessions, normally is) determined by decisions or activities of the businesses concerned in the previous financial year or years. TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1981 (Hansard, page 318) Senator Jones asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the Iwasaki property at Yeppoon.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
I refer the honourable senator to the answer to Question No. 2028 on page 3539 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 10 June 1981.
The Iwasaki company has advised the Government that it has no intention whatsoever of building an abattoir at its resort at Yeppoon.
The Foreign Investment Review Board is already monitoring the development of the tourist resort and the Iwasaki company's activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981, (Hansard, page 638) Senator Robertson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning Snake Bay television reception.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Definite steps towards meeting the Government's objective include the introduction of a national broadcasting development program solely for remote areas and a much broader three year plan for the extension of national broadcasting and television services. The areas included in these plans to date represent only the first stages of an ongoing concept which is reviewed annually.

Although there is at present no provision in the three year plan for the further development of the national broadcasting service in the Snake Bay area, I am advised by my Department that the district has been included in its engineering field survey program, with a view to recommending, in due course, that the provision of facilities to serve the area be included on a future three year plan.

Private funding of a national translator may also be an attractive alternative for the people of Melville Island to consider. In this regard I am able to advise that as a result of recent amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, it is now possible for a community group to fund the establishment of a national television translator station, and obtain, through the normal licensing process for broadcasting services, a licence to operate it. It is envisaged that communities wishing to pursue this option, as a means of obtaining an earlier service than possible under the Government's normal planning, will be reimbursed by the Commonwealth. However, such reimbursement would only apply to installations of an approved technical standard.

Notwithstanding the above, the proposed domestic communications satellite system, to be operational by the mid-eighties, may prove the most effective means by which direct national television reception could be provided to Melville Island. Accordingly, I have asked my Department to note your representations in regard to the future planning of domestic satellite services.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard, page 888) Senator Mason asked me a question without notice concerning the incidence of fatal crashes involving light aircraft in Australia. I partly answered that question at the time but undertook to seek further information from the Minister for Transport concerning erosion of safety standards and economic difficulties.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Economic difficulties do not necessarily involve an erosion of safety standards although it would be fair to say that safety standards may come under pressure in times of financial difficulty.
As I previously stated, the Government is greatly concerned about aviation safety and in fact has recently instituted two significant measures to increase the safety of operations of light aircraft.

Firstly, subsequent to a review of pilot standards conducted in 1977, the Department of Transport has introduced a requirement that all private and commercial pilots not subject to some other form of proficiency check by either the Department or industry approved pilots, shall have their flying proficiency and aeronautical knowledge reviewed at two-year intervals.

Secondly, following an extensive review of the standards for the conduct of commuter air services in 1979-80, the Department of Transport is phasing in requirements for higher standards for these services. Among the new standards will be a requirement for two-pilot crews for commuter aircraft carrying 10 passengers or more and improved airworthiness maintenance standards.
These measures will be accompanied by an increased emphasis on surveillance of operations to ensure that safety standards are maintained.
